Yoruba: Bí o bá fẹ́ ààbò tó kójú òṣùwọ̀n tí kò ní í jẹ́ kí olè lè jí ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ, ka àkàsílẹ̀ yìí kí o sì tan 2FA sílẹ̀ fún gbogbo ìṣàmúlò ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tí o ṣe kókó tí o gbẹ́kẹ̀lé.

English: Creating Strong Passwords Using Password Managers
Yoruba: Lílo Alákòóso Ọ̀rọ̀-Ìfiwọlé fún Ìṣẹ̀dá Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tó Lágbára

English: Reusing passwords is an exceptionally bad security practice. If a bad actor gets ahold of a password that you've reused across multiple services, they can gain access to many of your accounts.
Yoruba: Àtúnùntúnlò ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé jẹ́ ọ̀nà ààbò tí kò dára. Bí òṣèré ibí bá gbá ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tí o ti tún lò lórí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ iṣẹ́ mú, wọ́n lè r'ọ́nà wọ inú ìṣàmúlò rẹ.

English: This is why having multiple, strong, unique passwords is so important.
Yoruba: Torí ìdí èyí ni ó fi dára tí ó sì pọn dandan kí a ní ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tó lágbára, tó sì yàrà ọ̀tọ̀.

English: Fortunately, a password manager can help.
Yoruba: Ní rere, alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé lè ṣerànwọ́.

English: A password manager is a tool that creates and stores passwords for you, so you can use many different passwords on different sites and services without having to memorize them.
Yoruba: Alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ni irinṣẹ́ tí í máa ń ṣẹ̀dá àti fi ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé pamọ́ fún ọ, kí o ba lè lo onírúurú ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé lóríi onírúurú ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé láì sí wípé ó há a s'ágbárí.

English: Password managers:
Yoruba: Alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé:

English: generate strong passwords that a human being would be unlikely to guess.
Yoruba: Máa ń ṣàgbajáde ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tó ṣòro fún ọmọ-ènìyàn láti mọ̀.

English: store several passwords (and responses to security questions) safely.
Yoruba: Máa ń fi ọ̀gọ̀rọ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé sí ìpamọ́ (àti èsì fún ìbéèrè ààbò) pẹ̀lú ààbò tó péye.

English: protect all of your passwords with a single master password (or passphrase).
Yoruba: dáàbò bo ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ pẹ̀lú ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé olúwa (tàbí gbólóhùn ìfiwọlé ọlọ́rọ̀ kan).

English: KeePassXC is an example of a password manager that is open-source and free.
Yoruba: KeePassXC ni irúfẹ́ alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tó jẹ́ irinṣẹ́ ìṣísílẹ̀ ọ̀fẹ́.

English: You can keep this tool on your desktop or integrate it into your web browser.
Yoruba: O lè tọ́júu irinṣẹ́ yìí sórí ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá àgbélétábìlì rẹ tàbí kí o fi s'ínúu aṣàwákiri ibùdó-ìtàkùn rẹ.

English: KeePassXC does not automatically save changes you make when using it, so if it crashes after you've added some passwords, you can lose them forever.
Yoruba: KeePassXC kì í fi àyípadà tí o bá ṣe nígbà tí o bá lò ó pamọ́ fúnra rẹ̀, bí ó bá d'aṣẹ́ sílẹ̀ lẹ́yìn tí o ti fi ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé kún tilẹ̀, o lè pàdánùu rẹ títí láéláé.

English: You can change this in the settings.
Yoruba: O lè yí èyí padà nínú ààtò.

English: Wondering whether a password manager is the right tool for you?
Yoruba: Ò ń gbèrò bóyá alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ni irinṣẹ́ tó tọ́ sí ọ?

English: If a powerful adversary like a government is targeting you, it might not be.
Yoruba: Bí ọ̀tá ńlá bíi ìjọba bá ń lépaà rẹ, o lè máà jẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: using a password manager creates a single point of failure.
Yoruba: Lílo alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé máa ń ṣẹ̀dáa ìkúnnà kan ṣoṣo.

English: password managers are an obvious target for adversaries.
Yoruba: Alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé jẹ́ ìlépa gbangba fún ọ̀tá.

English: research suggests that many password managers have vulnerabilities.
Yoruba: Ìwádìí ṣíni níyè wípé ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ni ìpalára lè bá.

English: If you're worried about expensive digital attacks, consider something more low-tech.
Yoruba: Bí ọkàn-an rẹ kò bá balẹ̀ lórí ìdojúkọ orí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá olówó iyebíye, o lè lo èyí tí kò gba wàhálà púpọ̀.

English: You can create strong passwords manually (see "Creating strong passwords using dice" below), write them down, and keep them somewhere safe on your person.
Yoruba: O lè ṣẹ̀dá ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé àfọwọ́ṣe (wo "bí a ṣe ń lo dice fún ìṣẹ̀dá ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé alágbára" nísàlẹ̀) kọ ọ́ sílẹ̀, kí o tọ́júu rẹ̀ síbi tó l'áàbò.

English: Wait, aren't we supposed to keep passwords in our heads and never write them down?
Yoruba: Dúró, ṣe àgbárí kọ́ ni ó yẹ kí a há ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé sí àti kí a máa kọ ọ́ sílẹ̀ rárá?

English: Actually, writing them down, and keeping them somewhere like your wallet, is useful so you'll at least know if your written passwords go missing or get stolen.
Yoruba: Lóòótọ́, kò burú bí a bá kọ ọ́ sílẹ̀, kí a sì fi pamọ́ síbìkan bí àsùnwọ̀n ìkówósí àfisápò rẹ, èyí yóò ta ọ́ jí b'ọ́rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tí o kọ sílẹ̀ bá di àwátì tàbí bí wọ́n bá jí i.

English: Creating Strong Passwords Using Dice
Yoruba: Bí a ṣe ń lo dice fi ṣẹ̀dá ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé alágbára

English: There are a few passwords that you should memorize and that need to be particularly strong.
Yoruba: Ó ní àwọn ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé alágbára tí ó yẹ kí o há s'ágbárí.

English: These include:
Yoruba: Àwọn ni:

English: passwords for your device
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé fún ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ

English: passwords for encryption (like full-disk encryption)
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé fún ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò (bíi ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò díìskì kíkún)

English: the master password, or "passphrase," for your password manager
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé olúwa, tàbí gbólóhùn ìfiwọlé ọlọ́rọ̀ kan, fún alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ

English: your email password
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ímeèlì rẹ.

English: One of many difficulties when people choose passwords themselves is that people aren't very good at making random, unpredictable choices.
Yoruba: Ìṣòro kan tí àwọn èèyàn bá ń yan ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé fúnra wọn ni pé àwọn èèyàn kò mọ̀ bí a ṣe ń ṣe àṣàyàn láìròtẹ́lẹ̀ àti aláìsọtẹ́lẹ̀.

English: An effective way of creating a strong and memorable password is to use dice and a word list to randomly choose words.
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà ìṣẹ̀dá ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tó lágbára tí ó sì ṣe é rántí jù ni bí a bá lo dice àti àkàsílẹ̀ ọ̀rọ̀ láti yan ọ̀rọ̀ láìròtẹ́lẹ̀.

English: Together, these words form your "passphrase."
Yoruba: Lápapọ̀, àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ wọ̀nyí ni "gbólóhùn ìfiwọlé ọlọ́rọ̀ kan."

English: A "passphrase" is a type of password that is longer for added security.
Yoruba: Gbólóhùn ìfiwọlé ọlọ́rọ̀ kan ni irúfẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé aláàbò tó máa ń gùn.

English: For disk encryption and your password manager, we recommend selecting a minimum of six words.
Yoruba: Fún ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò díìskì àti alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ, ó kéré jù, yan ọ̀rọ̀ mẹ́fà.

English: Why use a minimum of six words?
Yoruba: Kí ni ṣe tí ó fi yẹ kí o lo ọ̀rọ̀ mẹ́fà?

English: Why use dice to pick words in a phrase randomly?
Yoruba: Kí ní dé tí ó fi yẹ kí o fi dice ṣe ìṣàjọ ọ̀rọ̀ onígbólóhùn kan láìròtẹ́lẹ̀?

English: The longer and more random the password, the harder it is for both computers and humans to guess.
Yoruba: Bí ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé bá ṣe gùn àti bí ó ṣe jẹ́ àṣàyàn láìròtẹ́lẹ̀, bẹ́ẹ̀ni yóò ṣe le fún ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣáà àti ènìyàn láti rò.

English: here's a video explainer.
Yoruba: fídíò alálàyé kan rè é.

English: Try making a passphrase using one of EFF's word lists.
Yoruba: Gbìyànjú kí o lo àṣàkalẹ̀ ọ̀rọ̀ EFF láti ṣe gbólóhùn ìfiwọlé ọlọ́rọ̀ kan.

English: If your computer or device gets compromised and spyware is installed, the spyware can watch you type your master password and could steal the contents of the password manager.
Yoruba: Bí adojúkọ bá dojúkọ ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣáà rẹ tàbí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ, tí iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú alamí wà lóríi rẹ̀, iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú alamí lè máa wò ọ́ bí o bá ń tẹ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé olúwaà rẹ.

English: So it's still very important to keep your computer and other devices clean of malware when using a password manager.
Yoruba: Torí náà ó pọn dandan kí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣáà rẹ àti ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ ó wà ní mímọ, kí o máà sí iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àìdára bí o bá ń lo alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé.

English: A Word About "Security Questions"
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ nípa "ìbéèrè ààbò"

English: Beware of the "security questions" that websites use to confirm your identity.
Yoruba: Kíyèsára fún "ìbéèrè ààbò" tí ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé ń lò fi ṣe ìfẹsẹ̀múlẹ̀ ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ.

English: Honest answers to these questions are often publicly discoverable facts that a determined adversary can easily find and use to bypass your password entirely.
Yoruba: Ìdáhùn òdodo sí ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí máa ń wà ní àrọ́wọ́tóo gbogboògbò tí yóò sì gbé ẹ̀rí tí ọ̀tá lè lò fi fo ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ kọjá yányán.

English: Instead, give fictional answers that no one knows but you.
Yoruba: Kàkà bẹ́ẹ̀, fi ìdáhùn tí kì í ṣe òdodo pọ́nbélé tí ẹnìkan yàtọ̀ sí ìwọ kò mọ̀ sílẹ̀.

English: For example, if the security question asks:
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, bí ìbéèrè ààbò bá ní:

English: "What was the name of your first pet?"
Yoruba: Kí ni orúkọ ẹranko ilé tí o fẹ́ràn àkọ́kọ́ọ̀ rẹ?

English: Your answer could be a random password generated from your password manager.
Yoruba: Ìdáhùn rẹ lè jẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé aláìròtẹ́lẹ̀ tí alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ gbàjáde.

English: You can store these fictional answers in your password manager.
Yoruba: O lè fi ìdáhùn àìṣòdodo pọ́nbélé wọ̀nyí s'ínúu alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ.

English: Think of sites where you've used security questions and consider changing your responses.
Yoruba: Ronú nípa ibùdó-ìtàkùn tí o ti lo ìbéèrè ààbò rí kí o sì gbèrò nípa ìyípadà èsì rẹ.

English: Do not use the same passwords or security question answers for multiple accounts on different websites or services.
Yoruba: Máà lo ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tàbí ìbéèrè ààbò kan náà fún gbogbo ìṣàmúlò fún gbogbo ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyéè tàbí iṣẹ́.

English: Syncing Your Passwords Across Multiple Devices
Yoruba: Ìmúṣiṣẹ́pọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ lóríi ẹ̀rọ gbogbo

English: Many password managers allow you to access your passwords across devices through a password-synchronizing feature.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ń fi ààyè gba ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ lórí gbogbo ẹ̀rọ - nípa àmúṣiṣẹ́pọ̀.

English: This means when you sync your password file on one device, it will update it on all of your devices.
Yoruba: Èyí ni pé bí o bá mu ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ ṣiṣẹ́ pọ̀ lórí ẹ̀rọ kan, yóò ṣàfikún lórí ẹ̀rọ ìyókù

English: Password managers can store your passwords "in the cloud," meaning encrypted on a remote server.
Yoruba: Alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé lè fi ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ pamọ́ "s'ínúu kùkukùru," tí ó túmọ̀ sí wípé a ti yí dátà rẹ̀ padà sí odù ààbò sínú apèsè àrọ́wọ́tó.

English: When you need your passwords, these managers will retrieve and decryptthe passwords for you automatically
Yoruba: Bí o bá nílòo ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ, alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé wọ̀nyí yóò ṣe àgbàjáde ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé, yóò sì tú ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tí a ti yí padà sí odù ààbò fúnra rẹ̀.

English: Password managers that use their own servers to store or help synchronize your passwords are more convenient, but are slightly more vulnerable to attacks.
Yoruba: Alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tí ń fi apèsèe tirẹ̀ ṣe ìpamọ́ tàbí ìrànwọ́ àmúṣiṣẹ́pọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ rọrùn bíi kàásínǹkan, ṣùgbọ́n ìpalára ìdojúkọ lè bá wọn.

English: If your passwords are stored both on your computer and in the cloud, an attacker does not need to take over your computer to find out your passwords.
Yoruba: Bí o bá fi ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ pamọ́ sí orí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá àti s'ínúu kùkukùru, adojúkọni kò ní í lo ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣáà rẹ láti mọ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ.

English: (They will need to break your password manager's passphrase though.)
Yoruba: (Wọ́n ní láti fọ́ gbólóhùn ìfiwọlé ọlọ́rọ̀ kan ti alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ.)

English: If this is concerning, don't sync your passwords to the cloud and instead opt to store them on just your devices.
Yoruba: Bí èyí bá kàn ọ́ gbọ̀ngbọ̀n, máà mú ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ ṣiṣẹ́ pọ̀ s'ínúu kùkukùru, kàkà bẹ́ẹ̀ fi wọ́n pamọ́ sórí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ.

English: Keep a backup of your password database just in case.
Yoruba: Tọ́júu ìkópamọ̀ ilée dátà ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ torí aìíṣeémọ̀.

English: Having a backup is useful if you lose your password database in a crash, or if your device is taken away from you.
Yoruba: Àkópamọ́ wúlò bí o bá pàdánù ilé dátà ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ látàrí ìdaṣẹ́sílẹ̀, tàbí tí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ bá di jíjí.

English: Password managers usually have a way to make a backup file, or you can use your regular backup program.
Yoruba: Alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé sábà máa ń ní ọ̀nà láti ṣe àkópamọ́ fáìlì, tàbí kí o lo iṣẹ́ àkópamọ́ tó wọ́pọ̀.

English: Multi-Factor Authentication and One-Time Passwords
Yoruba: Ìfẹ̀rílàdí Ọlọ́nà púpọ̀ àti ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ẹ̀rìnkan.

English: Strong, unique passwords make it much harder for bad actors to access your accounts to further protect your accounts, enable two-factor authentication
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé alágbára, aláràọ̀tọ̀ kì í mú u rọrùn fún òṣèré ibi láti r'áàyè wọ ìṣàmúlò rẹ fún ìfẹ̀rílàdí ọlọ́nà méjì.

English: Some services offer two-factor authentication (also called 2FA, multi-factor authentication, or two-step verification), which requires users to possess two components (a password and a second factor) to gain access to their account.
Yoruba: Àwọn iṣẹ́ kan a máa fún ni ìfẹ̀rílàdí ọlọ́nà méjì (tí a tún ń pè ní 2FA, ìfẹ̀rílàdí ọlọ́nà púpọ̀ tàbí ìfẹ̀rílàdí ìgbésẹ̀ méjì), tí òǹlò gbọdọ̀ lo ohun méjì (ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé àti ọ̀nà mìíràn) láti r'áàyè wọ ìṣàmúlò wọn.

English: The second factor could be a one-off secret code or a number generated by a program running on a mobile device.
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà kejì lè jẹ́ odù alálòlẹ́ẹ̀kan tàbí òǹkà tí ẹ̀rọ alágbèéká gbàjáde.

English: Two-factor authentication using a mobile phone can be done in one of two ways:
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà méjì ni a lè fi ṣe ìfẹ̀rílàdí ọlọ́nà méjì lórí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ alágbèéká:

English: your phone can run an authenticator application that generates security codes (such as Google Authenticator or Authy) or you can use a stand-alone hardware device (such as a YubiKey); or
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ rẹ lè ṣiṣẹ́ ìfẹ̀rílàdí láti ṣe àgbájáde odù ààbò (gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Afẹ̀rílàdí Google tàbí Authy) tàbí kí o lo ẹ̀rọ iṣẹ́ àìrídìmú àládàádúró (gẹ́gẹ́ bíi YubiKey); tàbí

English: the service can send you an SMS text message with an extra security code that you need to type in whenever you log in.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́ náà lè fi àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́ SMS pẹ̀lú àfilé odù ààbò tí ó ní láti tẹ̀ nígbàkúùgbà tí o bá fẹ́ wọlé.

English: If you have a choice, pick the authenticator application or stand-alone hardware device instead of receiving codes by text message.
Yoruba: Kàkà kí o gba àfilé odù ààbò, o lè yan iṣẹ́ ìfẹ̀rílàdí tàbí ẹ̀rọ iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àládàádúró.

English: It's easier for an attacker to redirect these codes to their own phone than it is to bypass the authenticator.
Yoruba: Ó rọrùn fún adojúkọni láti ṣ'àtúndarí odù wọ̀nyí sórí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ ti wọn ju ìdákọjá afẹ̀rílàdí lọ.

English: Some services, such as Google, also allow you to generate a list of one-time passwords, also called single-use passwords.
Yoruba: Àwọn iṣẹ́ kan, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Google, náà máa ń f'ààyè gbà ọ́ láti ṣ'àgbàjáde àkàsílẹ̀ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ẹ̀rìnkan ṣoṣo, tí a tún ń pè ní ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé alálòlẹ́ẹ̀kan.

English: These are meant to be printed or written down on paper and carried with you.
Yoruba: Ó yẹ kí a tẹ̀ ẹ́ sórí ìwé tàbí kọ ọ́ sílẹ̀ kí a máa gbé e kiri.

English: Each of these passwords works only once, so if one is stolen by spyware when you enter it, the thief won't be able to use it for anything in the future.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ẹ̀kan ṣoṣo ni ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé wọ̀nyí ń ṣiṣẹ́, torí náà bí iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú alamí bá jí ọkàn, olè náà kò ní le è lò ó fún ohunkóhun lọ́jọ́ iwájú.

English: If you or your organization run your own communications infrastructure, there's free software available that can be used to enable two-factor authentication for accessing your systems.
Yoruba: Bí ìwọ tàbí ilé-iṣẹ́ẹ̀ rẹ bá ní irinṣẹ́ ìtàkùrọ̀sọ tirẹ̀, iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú ọ̀fẹ́ wà lárọ̀ọ́wọ́tó tí ó ṣe é lò láti f'ààyègba ìfẹ̀rílàdí ọlọ́nà méjì láti r'áàyè wọ ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ.

English: Look for software offering implementations of the open standard "Time-Based One-Time Passwords" or RFC 6238.
Yoruba: Wá iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú tí ó jẹ́ ti ìṣísílẹ̀ "Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé Ẹ̀̀rìnkan ṣoṣo Adálórí Àkókò" tàbí RFC 6238.

English: Sometimes, You Will Need to Disclose Your Password
Yoruba: Nígbà mìíràn, O ní láti sọ Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ

English: Laws about revealing passwords differ from place to place.
Yoruba: Òfin nípa sísọ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé yàtọ̀ láti ibìkan dé òmíràn.

English: In some jurisdictions you may be able to legally challenge a demand for your password while in others, local laws allow the government to demand disclosure - and even imprison you on the suspicion that you may know a password or key
Yoruba: Nígbà mìíràn o lè kọ̀ jálẹ̀ kí o máà fún ẹnikẹ́ni ní ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ, níbo mìíràn ẹ̀wẹ̀wẹ̀ òfín ìbílẹ̀ f'ààyè gba ìjọba láti béèrè fún ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ẹnikẹ́ni - àti pàápàá fi ọ́ sí àtìmọ́lé bí o bá jẹ́ afurasí tí ó mọ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tàbí kọ́kọ́rọ́ kan.

English: Threats of physical harm can be used to force someone to give up their password.
Yoruba: A lè lo ìdẹ́rùbà ìpalára ojúkorojú láti fi gba ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé lọ́wọ́ èèyàn.

English: Or you may find yourself in a situation, such as travelling across a border, where the authorities can delay you or seize your devices if you refuse to give up a password or unlock your device.
Yoruba: Tàbí kí o bá araà rẹ nínú ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ kan, bíi rírin ìrìn àjò s'ódìkejì ìlú, níbi tí àwọn aláṣẹ lè ti dá ọ dúró tàbí gba ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ bí o bá kọ̀ láti fún wọn ní ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tàbí ṣí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ.

English: How to: Circumvent Online Censorship
Yoruba: Bí a ṣe ń: fo ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ Ayélujára dá

English: This is a short overview to circumventing online censorship, but is by no means comprehensive.
Yoruba: Èyí ni àkótán kúkúrú nípa ìfòdá ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ orí ayélujára, ṣùgbọ́n kì í ṣe ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́.

English: Governments, companies, schools, and Internet providers sometimes use software to prevent their users from accessing certain websites and services.
Yoruba: Ìjọba, ilé-iṣẹ́, ilé-ìwé, àti apèsèe ẹ̀rọ-àìrídìmú tí yóò dí òǹlò lọ́wọ́ kí wọ́n ba máà rí ààyè wọ àwọn ibùdó-ìtàkùn kan.

English: This is called Internet filtering or blocking, and it is a form of censorship.
Yoruba: Èyí ni a pè ní ìsẹ́ ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára tàbí ìdígàgá, tí í ṣe irúfẹ́ ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ kan.

English: Filtering comes in different forms. Censors can block individual web pages, or even entire websites.
Yoruba: Atẹríbọlẹ̀ẹ́ lè dígàgá ojú ìwé ìtàkùn-àgbáyé kan ṣoṣo tàbí gbogbo ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé pọ̀.

English: Sometimes, content is blocked based on the keywords it contains.
Yoruba: Nígbà mìíì, ohuninú ojú ìwé orí ayélujára ní í máa ń fa ìdígàgá

English: There are different ways of beating Internet censorship.
Yoruba: Onírúurú ọ̀nà ni a fi lè fo ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ orí ayélujára dá.

English: Some protect you from surveillance, but many do not.
Yoruba: Àwọn kan ń fi ààbò ìṣọ́ni bò ọ́, ṣùgbọ́n ọ̀pọ̀ ò ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: When someone who controls your net connection filters or blocks a site, you can almost always use a circumvention tool to get to the information you need.
Yoruba: Bí alákòóso ìṣàsopọ̀ ayélujáraà rẹ bá ṣẹ́ tàbí dígàgá ibùdó kan, o lè lo irinṣẹ́ ìfòdá tí yóò mú ọ rí ìwífún tí o nílò.

English: Note: Circumvention tools that promise privacy or security are not always private or secure.
Yoruba: Fiyèsíi: irinṣẹ́ ìfòdá aṣèlérí ààbò tàbí ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀ kì í sábà í ṣe ti ìkọ̀kọ̀ tàbí ní ààbò.

English: And tools that use terms like "anonymizer" do not always keeps your identity completely secret.
Yoruba: Irinṣẹ́ tó ń lo gbólóhùn bíi "anonymizer" kì í sábà pa ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ mọ́ fínnífínní.

English: The circumvention tool that is best for you depends on your threat model.
Yoruba: Irinṣẹ́ ìfòdá tó dára jù fún ọ dá lóríi àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà rẹ.

English: If you're not sure what your threat model is, start here.
Yoruba: Bí àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà rẹ ò bá dá ọ lójú ṣáká tó, bẹ̀rẹ̀ níhìn-ín.

English: In this article, we'll talk about four ways to circumvent censorship:
Yoruba: Nínú àpilẹ̀kọ yìí, a máa sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ọ̀nà mẹ́rin tí a lè gbà fo ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ orí ayélujára dá.

English: Visiting a web proxy to access a blocked website.
Yoruba: Bíbẹ aṣojú ìtàkùn wò láti wọ ibùdó-ìtàkùn tí a ti dígàgáa rẹ̀.

English: Visiting an encrypted web proxy to access a blocked website.
Yoruba: Bíbẹ aṣojú ìtàkùn tí a ti yí dátà rẹ̀ padà sí odù ààbò láti wọ ibùdó-ìtàkùn tí a ti dígàgáa rẹ̀.

English: Using a Virtual Private Network (VPN) to access blocked websites or services.
Yoruba: Lílo Ìṣàsopọ̀ Àìrí Ìkọ̀kọ̀ (VPN) láti wọ ibùdó-ìtàkùn tàbí iṣẹ́.

English: Using the Tor Browser to access a blocked website or protect your identity.
Yoruba: Lílo aṣàwákiri Tor láti wọ ibùdó-ìtàkùn tí a ti dígàgáa rẹ̀ tàbí dáàbò bo ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ.

English: Basic techniques
Yoruba: Àwọn ìpìlẹ̀ ìmọ̀

English: Circumvention tools usually work by diverting your web traffic so it avoids the machines that do the blocking or filtering.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́ tí irinṣẹ́ ìfòdá sábà máa ń ṣe ni dídaríi dátà tó ń gba orí ìtàkùn rẹ kí o ba yẹ ẹ̀rọ tó ń ṣe ìdígàgá tàbí ìsẹ́ kúrò.

English: A service that redirects your Internet connection past these blocks is sometimes called a proxy.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́ tí í ṣe àtúndaríi ìṣàsopọ̀ ayélujára fo ìdígàgá kọjá là ń pè ní aṣojú ń'gbà mìíì.

English: HTTPS is the secure version of the HTTP protocol you use to access websites.
Yoruba: HTTPS ni ẹ̀dà ààbò fún ìfẹ́nukò HTTP tí ò ń lò fi wọ ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé.

English: Sometimes a censor will only block the insecure (HTTP) version of a site.
Yoruba: Nígbà mìíràn Atẹríbọlẹ̀ẹ́ lè dígàgá ẹ̀dà ibùdó àìláàbò (HTTP)

English: That means you can access the blocked site simply by entering the version of the web address that starts with HTTPS.
Yoruba: Ìyẹn ni pé o lè wọ ibùdó tí a dígàgá náà bí o bá tẹ ẹ̀dà àdírẹ́ẹ̀sì ibùdóò rẹ tó bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú HTTPS.

English: HTTPS stops censors from reading your web traffic, so they cannot tell what keywords are being sent, or which individual web page you are visiting.
Yoruba: HTTPS máa ń dá atẹríbọlẹ̀ dúró láti máà le è ka dátà tó ń gba oríi ìtàkùn rẹ, torí náà wọn kò le è sọ ọ̀rọ̀-aṣínà tí a fi ránṣẹ́, tàbí orí ojú ìwé ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tí ò ń bẹ̀wò.

English: Censors can still see the domain names of all websites you visit.
Yoruba: Atẹríbọlẹ̀ ṣì lè rí orúkọ agbègbè ìkápáa gbogbo ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tí o bá lọ.

English: So, for example, if you visit "eff.org/https-everywhere" censors can see that you are on "eff.org" but not that you are on the "https-everywhere" page.
Yoruba: ún àpẹẹrẹ, bí o bẹ "eff.org/https-everywhere" wò atẹríbọlẹ̀ lè rí i wípé o wà lóríi "eff.org," ṣùgbọ́n kì í ṣe pé o wà lóríi ojú ìwée "https-everywhere."

English: If you suspect this type of simple blocking, try entering https:// before the domain in place of http:
Yoruba: Tí o bá ní ìfura irúfẹ́ ìdígàgá àìle báyìí, gbìyànjú kí o tẹ https:// síwájú agbègbè ìkápá dípò http:

English: Try installing EFF's HTTPS Everywhere extension to automatically turn on HTTPS where possible.
Yoruba: Gbìyànjú kí o gbé alátànkáa EFF ibi-gbogbo tí yóò fúnra rẹ̀ tan HTTPS níbi tó bá yẹ sórí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ.

English: Another way that you may be able to circumvent basic censorship techniques is by trying an alternate domain name or URL.
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà mìíràn tí o lè gbà fi fo ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ dá ni bí o bá lo orúkọ agbègbè-ìkápá mìíràn tàbí URL.

English: For example, instead of visiting http://twitter.com, you might try the mobile version of the site at http://m.twitter.com.
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, kàkà kí o bẹ http://twitter.com wò, o lè gbìdánwò láti ṣí ibùdó náà lóríi ẹ̀dà ti ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ alágbèéká ní http://m.twitter.com.

English: Censors that block websites or web pages work from a blacklist of banned websites, so anything that is not on that blacklist will get through.
Yoruba: Atẹríbọlẹ̀ tó dígàgá ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tàbí ojú ìwé ìtàkùn-àgbáyé ń fi àkàsílẹ̀ ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé àìdára tí a ti gbẹ́sẹ̀ òfin lé ṣiṣẹ́, torí náà ohunkóhun tí kò bá sí lórí àkàsílẹ̀ àìdára yẹn yóò la ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ kọjá.

English: They might not know of all different versions of a particular website's name - especially if the administrators of the site know it is blocked and register more than one domain.
Yoruba: Wọ́n lè máà mọ gbogbo onírúurú ẹ̀dà orúkọ ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé ní pàtó - ju gbogbo rẹ̀ lọ bí alákòóso ibùdó bá mọ̀ wípé a ti dígàgáa rẹ̀ àti pé a orúkọ agbègbè ìkápá tí a fi sílẹ̀ ju ọ̀kan lọ.

English: Web-based proxies
Yoruba: Aṣojú orí ìtàkùn-àgbáyé

English: A web-based proxy (such as http://proxy.org/) is a website that lets its users access other blocked or censored websites.
Yoruba: Aṣojú orí ìtàkùn-àgbáyé (gẹ́gẹ́ bíi http://proxy.org/) jẹ́ ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tí ń f'ààyè gba òǹlò láti wọ ibùdó tí a dígàgáa rẹ̀ tàbí tẹríi rẹ̀ bọlẹ̀.

English: It is therefore a good way to circumvent censorship.
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà tó dára láti fo ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ dá lèyí.

English: In order to use a web-based proxy, visit the proxy and enter the web address that you want to see; the proxy will then display the web page you asked for.
Yoruba: Láti lo aṣojú orí ìtàkùn-àgbáyé, bẹ aṣojú náà wò kí o tẹ àdírẹ́ẹ̀sì ibùdó-ìtàkùn tí o fẹ́ rí sí i; aṣojú yìí yóò fi ojúùwé ibùdó-ìtàkùn tí o béèrè fún hàn ọ́.

English: However, web-based proxies don't provide any security and will be a poor choice if your threat model includes someone monitoring your internet connection.
Yoruba: Bótiwùkíórí, aṣojú orí ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé kì í pèsèe ààbò kankan àti pé kò ní ṣ'ẹnuure bí àṣàyàn àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà rẹ bá ní aṣọ́ní tí ń ṣọ́ ìṣàsopọ̀ rẹ.

English: They will not help you to use blocked services such as your instant messaging apps.
Yoruba: Wọn kò ní ràn ọ́ lọ́wọ́ láti lo iṣẹ́ tí a ti dígàgá gẹ́gẹ́ bíi áàpù iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ oníwàràǹṣesà rẹ.

English: The web-based proxy will have a complete record of everything you do online, which can be a privacy risk for some users depending on their threat model
Yoruba: Aṣojú orí ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé máa ní àkọsílẹ̀ ohun gbogbo tí ò ń ṣe lórí ayélujára, tí ó lè jẹ́ ewu ìdáààbòbò fún òǹlò mìíràn lórí àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà wọn.

English: Encrypted proxies
Yoruba: Aṣojú tí dátà rẹ̀ ti yí padà sí odù ààbò

English: Numerous proxy tools utilize encryption to provide an additional layer of security on top of the ability to bypass filtering.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kẹ́ àìmọye irinṣẹ́ aṣojú tó ń lo ìyí-dátà-padà-sódù-ààbò láti pèsè ìpele ìròpọ̀ ààbò lórí agbára ìdákọjá ìsẹ́.

English: The connection is encrypted so others cannot see what you are visiting.
Yoruba: Ìṣàsopọ̀ náà ti yìí dátà padà sí odù ààbò kí ẹlòmíràn ó máà ba à lè rí ibi tí ò ń bẹ̀wò.

English: While encrypted proxies are generally more secure than plain web-based proxies, the tool provider may have information about you.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí aṣojú tí dátà rẹ̀ ti yí padà sí odù ààbò l'áàbò tó péye ju aṣojú orí ìtàkùn-àgbáyé lọ, apèsè irinṣẹ́ náà lè rí ìwífún nípaà rẹ.

English: They might have your name and email address in their records, for instance.
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, wọ́n lè ní orúkọ àti àdírẹ́ẹ̀sì ímeèlì rẹ lákọsílẹ̀.

English: That means that these tools do not provide full anonymity.
Yoruba: Ìyẹ́n túmọ̀ sí wípé irinṣẹ́ wọ̀nwọ̀nyí kì í pèsèe àìlórúkọ dójú àlà.

English: The simplest form of an encrypted web proxy is one that starts with "https" - this will use the encryption usually provided by secure websites.
Yoruba: Aṣojú ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tí dátà rẹ̀ ti yí padà sí odù ààbò tó rọrùn jù ni "https" - èyí yóò lo ìyí-dátà-padà-sódù-ààbò tí ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tó l'áàbò pèsè.

English: However, be cautious - the owners of these proxies can see the data you send to and from other secure websites.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀, ṣọ́ra - àwọn to ni aṣojú wọ̀nyí lè rí dátà tí o fi ránṣẹ́ sí àti bọ̀ wá láti ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé ààbò mìíràn.

English: Ultrasurf and Psiphon are examples of these tools.
Yoruba: UltraSurf àti Psiphon jẹ́ àpẹẹrẹ irinṣẹ́ báwọ̀nyí.

English: Virtual Private Networks
Yoruba: Ìṣàsopọ̀ Àìrí Ìkọ̀kọ̀

English: A Virtual Private Network (VPN) encrypts and sends all Internet data from your computer through another computer.
Yoruba: Ìṣàsopọ̀ Àìrí Ìkọ̀kọ̀ (VPN) máa ń yí dátà padà sí odù ààbò, yóò sì fi gbogbo dátà ránṣẹ́ láti orí ẹ̀rọ-ayélujáraà rẹ sóríi ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá mìíràn.

English: This computer could belong to a commercial or nonprofit VPN service, your company, or a trusted contact.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá yìí lè jẹ́ ti iléeṣẹ́ ìṣòwò kan tàbí ilé-iṣẹ́ àìjèèrè apèsèe VPN, ilé iṣẹ́ẹ̀ rẹ, tàbí ẹni mímọ̀.

English: Once a VPN service is correctly configured, you can use it to access webpages, e-mail, instant messaging, VoIP, and any other Internet service.
Yoruba: Ní kété tí iṣẹ́ẹ VPN bá ti wà, o lè lò ó fi wọ ojú ìwé ìtàkùn-àgbáyé, ímeelì, iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ oníwàràǹṣesà VoIP, àti iṣẹ́ orí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára tó kù.

English: A VPN protects your traffic from being spied on locally, but your VPN provider can still keep logs of the websites you access, or even let a third party snoop directly on your web browsing.
Yoruba: VPN máa ń dáàbò bo ìwífún tó ń kọjá lórí ayélujára kí àwọn alamí má ba à rí i lágbègbè kan, ṣùgbọ́n apèsèe VPN rẹ ṣì lè ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tí o wọ, tàbí jẹ́ kí ẹnìkẹ́ta yọ́ kẹ́lẹ́ wọ inúu aṣàwáríkiri ayélujáraà rẹ.

English: Depending on your threat model, the possibility of a government listening in on your VPN connection or getting hold of VPN logs may be a significant risk.
Yoruba: Ó dá lóríi àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà rẹ, o ṣe é ṣe kí ìjọba ó máa fẹtíkọ́ ìṣàsopọ̀ VPN rẹ tàbí gbígbá àkọsílẹ̀ VPN rẹ mú lè di ewu ńlá.

English: For some users, this could outweigh the short-term benefits of using a VPN.
Yoruba: Fún òǹlò mìíràn, èyí lè lágbára jù f'áǹfààní tó wà nínú lílo VPN fún ìgbà díẹ̀.

English: For information about specific VPN services, click here.
Yoruba: Fún àlàyé nípa àwọn iṣẹ́ VPN ní pàtó, ṣíra tẹ ibí.

English: We at EFF cannot vouch for this rating of VPNs.
Yoruba: Ní EFF a kò le è jẹ́rìí sí VPN wọ̀nyí.

English: Some VPNs with exemplary privacy policies could be run by devious people.
Yoruba: VPN mìíràn tí ó ní ìlànà ààbò tó yàrá ọ̀tọ̀ lè jẹ́ ti ọ̀daràn.

English: Do not use a VPN that you do not trust.
Yoruba: O kò gbọdọ̀ lo VPN tí o kò fi ọkàn tàn.

English: Tor is open-source software designed to give you anonymity on the web.
Yoruba: Tor jẹ́ iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú orísun-ìṣísílẹ̀ tí a ṣe kí ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ ó ba wà nípamọ́ lórí ìtàkùn àgbáyé.

English: Tor Browser is a web browser built on top of the Tor anonymity network.
Yoruba: Aṣàwáríkiri ìtàkùn-àgbáyé ni aṣàwáríkiri Tor tí a kọ́ sóríi ìṣàsopọ̀ àìlórúkọ òǹlò Tor.

English: Because of how Tor routes your web browsing traffic, it also allows you to circumvent censorship.
Yoruba: Nítorí bí Tor ṣe ń gbé dátà ká lórí aṣàwáríkiri ibùdó-ìtàkùn rẹ, ó gbà ọ́ láàyè láti fo ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ dá.

English: (See our How to: Use Tor guides for Linux, macOS and Windows).
Yoruba: (Wo bí a ṣe ń: lo ìtọ́nà Tor fún Linux, macOS àti Windows)

English: When you first start the Tor Browser, you can choose an option specifying that you are on a network that is censored:
Yoruba: Bí o bá ṣí Aṣàwáríkiri Tor, o lè ṣe àṣàyàn àfihàn wípé oríi ìṣàsopọ̀ tí a tẹríi rẹ̀ bọlẹ̀ lo wà:

English: Tor will not only bypass almost all national censorship, but, if properly configured, can also protect your identity from an adversary listening in on your country's networks. It can, however, be slow and difficult to use.
Yoruba: Tor kò ní fo ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ ọ̀pọ̀ ìlú kọjá nìkan, ṣùgbọ́n, bí o bá fàṣẹ fún un bí ó ṣe yẹ, ó lè dáàbò bo ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ kí ó máà bọ́ s'ọ́wọ́ ọ̀tá tó ń tẹ́tí sí ìṣàsopọ̀ ìlúù rẹ. Síbẹ̀, ó lè máa fà tìkọ̀, kò sì rọrùn ní lílò.

English: To learn how to use Tor on a desktop machine, click here for Linux, here for macOS, or herefor Windows, but please be sure to tap "Configure" instead of "Connect" in the window displayed above.
Yoruba: Láti ka bí o ṣe lè lo Tor lórí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá àgbélétábìlì, ṣíra tẹ ibí fún Linux, ibí fún MacOS, tàbí ibí fún Windows, àmọ́ jọ̀wọ́ rí i dájú wípé o f'ọwọ́tọ́ "configure" dípò "connect" nínú àwòrán fèrèsé òkè.

English: Workers" Day Celebration: House Speaker tasks Nigerian workers on productivity
Yoruba: ---Àjọ̀dún òṣìṣẹ́: Abẹnugan ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ as̩ojú rọ òṣìṣẹ́ láti tẹramọ́ iṣẹ́ fún àbájáde rere.

English: The Speaker of the Nigerian House of Representatives Mr Femi Gbajabiamila has congratulated the Nigerian workers for marking this year's International Workers" Day.
Yoruba: Abẹnugan ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣ̣ojú ti Nàìjíríà, Fẹ́mi Gbàjàbíàmílà, ti kí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ orílẹ̀-èdè yìí kú orííre fún ti àjọ̀dún àyájọ́ àwọn òsìsẹ́ lágbàáyé.

English: Mr Gbajabiamila said although the day is being marked quietly across the globe as a result of the lockdown necessitated by the COVID-19 pandemic, there is much to remember about the sacrifices made by Nigerian workers.
Yoruba: Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Gbàjàbíàmílà ní bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ayẹyẹ yìí wáyé láìsí ariwo ní gbogbo àgbáyé nítorí àṣe̩ kónílé-gbélé látàrí ìtànkálẹ̀ aàrun COVID-19, ohun tí a lè rántí pọ̀ nípa àwọn ìrúbọ ti àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Nàìjíríà̀ ṣe.

English: In a statement marking the Workers" Day signed by his Special Adviser on Media and Publicity, Lanre Lasisi, the Speaker commended the Nigerian workers for their commitment and dedication to work over the years, which he said has shaped the country tremendously.
Yoruba: Nínú àtẹ̀jáde tó ń sàmì ọjọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ èyí tí Olùdámọ́ràn rẹ̀ Pàtàkì lórí ìròyìn àti ìkéde fo̩wó̩sí, Láńre Làsísì, Abẹnugan gbóṣùbà fún àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Nàìjíríà nítorí ìfarajìn àti ipa ribiribi tí wọ́n kó fún ọ̀pọ̀ ọdún sẹ́yìn, èyí tó mú ìyípadà rere bá Nàìjíríà.

English: He, however, called on Nigerian workers to be more productive now and always, saying no matter what was achieved before now must be sustained and improved upon for the country to achieve more.
Yoruba: Síbè̩, ó ro̩ àwọn òṣìṣé Nàìjíríà kí wọ́n túnbọ̀ máa so èso rere nísisìnyí àti gbogbo ìgbà, nítorí àṣeyorí àná nílò ìtẹ̀síwájú kí a ṣiṣẹ́ síi kí ọrílẹ̀-èdè yìí leè ní àṣeyọrí síi.

English: "I want to salute the courage of Nigerian workers, who have over the years given their best to their work.
Yoruba: "Mo fẹ́ kí àwọn òṣìṣé Nàìjíríà fún ọkàn-akin, àwọn tí wọ́n ti fi gbogbo ipá wọn ṣiṣé.

English: Indeed Nigeria and Nigerians are proud of you.
Yoruba: Nítòótọ́, Nàìjíríà àti àwọn ọmọ Nàìjíríà fi yín yangàn.

English: I urge the Nigerian workers to redouble their efforts at this time of our national development.
Yoruba: Mo rọ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Nàìjíríà láti fikún okun wọn ní irú àkókò ìdàgbàsókè orílẹ̀ èdè wa yìí.

English: They must continue to put in their best in the work that they do for the betterment of the country."
Yoruba: Wọ́n gbọ́dọ̀ tẹ̀síwájú láti fi gbogbo agbára wọn ṣe iṣé tí wọ́n ń ṣe fún àǹfààní orílẹ̀ èdè"

English: --- May Day: Senate President felicitates with Nigerian workers
Yoruba: --- Àyájọ́ àwọn Òṣìṣẹ́: Olóri ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin àgbà kí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Nàìjíríà

English: President of the Nigerian Senate, Ahmad Lawan, has felicitated with Nigerian workers as they join their counterparts the world over to mark the Workers" Day.
Yoruba: Ààrẹ ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin àgbà ti Nàìjíríà, Ahmad Lawan, kí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ orílẹ̀-èdè yìí bí wọ́n ṣe sowó̩pò̩ pè̩lú àwọn akẹgbẹ́ wọn lágbàáyé láti s̩e àjọ̀dún o̩jó̩ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́.

English: Senator Lawan also congratulated Nigerian workers for sustaining their heroic struggle for the liberation of the country from poverty and underdevelopment even in the face of the daunting challenges at various workplaces.
Yoruba: Aṣòfin Lawan tún gbóṣùbà fún àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ fún gudugudu méje, yàyà mẹfà tí wọ́n ń ṣe láti mú orílẹ̀-èdè kúrò nínú òṣì àti àìní idàgbàsókè àti kíkojú àwo̩n ìpèníjà amúnibè̩rù lẹ́nu iṣẹ́ onírúurú.

English: He acknowledged the role of workers as the creator of wealth in society and stressed that it is for this reason that they should be appreciated at all times.
Yoruba: Ó mọ rírì ipa àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ẹni tó ń mú ọrọ̀ wá sí àwùjọ, ó tẹnumọ wípé èyí ni a ṣe gbọ́dọ̀ mo rírì wọn ní gbogbo ìgbà.

English: The best way to appreciate the enormous contributions of the Nigerian workers is to always consider their welfare as of utmost importance.
Yoruba: Ó tẹ̣̀síwájú pé "ọ̀nà tó dára jùlọ̣ láti mọ̣ rírì ipa ribiribi tí àwọ̣̣n òṣìṣẹ́ kó ní láti mójútó ètò ìgbáyé-gbádùn wọ̣̣n.

English: "As a legislature, we are ever ready to work in collaboration with the organised labour Unions to rid our statute books of any anti-labour laws," Lawan said.
Yoruba: Lawan sọ wípé, "Gẹ̣́gẹ́ bí ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣ̣òfin, a ti ṣ̣etán láti fọwọ̣́sowọ̣́pọ̀ pẹ̣̀lú ẹ̣̣gbẹ̣́ àwọ̣̣n òṣ̣ìṣ̣ẹ́ láti ṣòfin tó lòdì sí ìwà ìbàjẹ́ sí òṣìṣẹ lẹ́nu iṣẹ́."

English: The Senate President said as part of the effort of the 9th National Assembly to strengthen the economy and improve the standard of living of the people, it is determined to make the country's financial year predictable through the timely passage of the 2020 budget.
Yoruba: Ààrẹ ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin àgbà sọ wípé, gégẹ́ bíi ara akitiyan ilé-ìgbìmọ aṣòfin kẹsàn-án láti fi okun fún ètò ọrọ̀ ajé àti láti mú ìgbé-ayé àwọn ènìyàn dára síi, ti pinu láti mú kí ètò ìsúúná ọdún yìí ṣee dáadáa nípa títètè bu ọwọ́ lu ìwé ètò ìsúná ọdún 2020.

English: According to Senator Lawan, the National Assembly has in the same respect made critical amendments to some laws to ensure smooth implementation of the budget.
Yoruba: Nínu ọ̀rọ̀ Aṣòfin Lawan, ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin àgbà bakan náà ti ṣe àtúnṣe sí àwọn òfin kò̩ò̩kan láti ri wípé ìmúlò ètò ìsúná náà lo̩o̩ bí ó ti yẹ.

English: He said the Legislature would continue to move relentlessly in that direction, despite the unforeseen challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.
Yoruba: Ó sọ wípé àwọn Aṣòfin yóò máa lọ ní ìlànà yìí láìwo àwọn ìpèníjà àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn COVID-19.

English: The Senate President noted that this year's celebration of Workers" Day comes at a time the entire world is facing the health emergency brought about by the Coronavirus pandemic.
Yoruba: Ààrẹ ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin ṣe àkíyèsí wípé ayẹyẹ ọjọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ti ọdún yìí wáyé lásìkò tí gbogbo orílẹ̀ èdè àgbáyé ń kojú àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn òjiijì COVID-19.

English: "It is the resilience and never-die spirit of the Nigerian people that will boost the efforts of the government to overcome the pandemic," he stated.
Yoruba: Ó wípé "Ọkàn akínkanjú àti ẹ̀mí tí kìí kú tí àwọn ènìyàn Nàìjíríà níí ni yóò ran iṣẹ́ ìjọba lọ́wọ́ láti leè borí àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn náà"

English: The Senate President urged the Nigerian workers, as they mark their day, to adhere strictly to all the prescribed public health protocols of social distancing, wearing of face mask, use of hand sanitizer, observance of personal hygiene, and to endeavour to stay at home and stay safe.
Yoruba: "Ààrẹ ilé ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin wá rọ àwọn òṣìsẹ́ lórílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà bí wọ́n ṣe ń sàmì ọjọ́ wọn, láti máa tẹ́lé ìlànà ètò ìlera láwùjọ, fífi ààyè sáàrín ara wa, kí a máa wọ ìbòjú, kí a máa lo oun èlò ìfọwọ́ apakòkòrò, kí a máa ṣe ìmọ́tótó ara wa àti láti máa dúrọ sílé kí a sì dáàbò bo ara wa.

English: --- COVID 19: another twenty four (24) people were tested positive in Nigeria.
Yoruba: --- COVID-19: Àwọn ènìyàn mẹ́rìnlélógún (24) mìíràn tún jẹyọ lórílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà

English: Another twenty-four (24) people were tested positive for corona virus (COVID 19) in Nigeria this made the total of infected people to be one thousand, nine hundred and thirty-two (1932) when three hundred and nineteen (319) have been discharged, and fifty-eight (58) are dead. The Nigeria centre for disease control (NCDC) announced this on their twitter handle @NCDC.gov.
Yoruba: Àwọn ènìyàn mẹ́rìlélógún (24) mìíràn tún ti jẹyọ tí wọ́n ní ààrùn Corona (COVID 19) lórílé̩èdè Nàìjíríà, èyí tó jẹ́ kí iye àwọn tó ní ààrùn Corona jẹ́ o̩gbò̩nlélé̩è̩dé̩gbàá lé méjì (1932), nígbà tí àwọn ènìyàn bí mọ́kàndínlógúnlélọ́ọ̀dúnrún (319) ti gba ìwòsàn, tí àwọn ènìyàn méjìdínlọ́gọ́ta (58) sì ti jẹ́ Ọlọ́run nípè. Àjọ tó ń gbógun ti àjàkálẹ̀ aàrùn ti Nàìjíríà (NCDC) ló kéde yìí lórí ẹ̀rọ Twitter wọn, @NCDC. gov.

English: --- COVID 19: We have received some news about the happening in Kano - Dr. Osagie
Yoruba: --- COVID-19: A ti gba ìròyìn díẹ̀ lórí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ní Kánò- Dókítà Osagie

English: The Minister for health in Nigeria Dr. Osagie Ehanire has said they have received some news on the happening in Kano state.
Yoruba: Mínísítà fún ètò ìlera ti Nàìjíríà, Dókítà Osagie Ehanire ti ní àwọn ri ìròyìn díẹ̀ gbà nípa ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ onírúurú ní ìpínlẹ̀ Kánò.

English: The minister said this in a daily interview of the federal Government in charge of fighting against COVID 19 with journalist in Abuja.
Yoruba: Mínísítà sọ̀rọ̀ yìí lásìkò ètò ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò ojoojúmó tí ìgbìmọ̀ ìjọba àpapọ̀ tó ń mójútó gbígbógun ti aàrùn COVID-19 ń ṣe pẹ̀lú àwọn akọ̣̣̣̣̣̀ròyìn nílùú Àbújá.

English: He continued that they are expecting the news about the sudden death in Kano state, and this help them to take step of providing the instrument, the professionals and the training to help stop COVID- 19 in Kano state.
Yoruba: Ó tún tẹ̀síwájú pé àwọ̣n ṣí ń retí gbogbo ìròyìn nípa ìṣẹ̣̀lẹ̀ ikú òjijì tó wáyé ní ìpínlẹ̣̀ Kánò, eléyìí yóò ràn ìgbéṣẹ̀ pípèsè ètò ìrànwọ́ ìrìnsẹ̀ , àwọn onímọ̀ àti ètò ẹ̣̀kọ́ tí wọn yóò fún ìpínlẹ̀ Kánò láti dẹ́kun aàrùn COVID-19.

English: Dr Ehanire, now appealed health workers to follow the line of programmes to protect themselves always so that they will not be infected by COVID -19 or endanger themselves.
Yoruba: Dókítà Ehanire , wá rọ̣ àwọ̣n òṣìṣẹ̣́ ètò ìlera làti maa tẹ̀ḷé ètò ìlànà láti dáàbò bò ara wọn nígbà gbogbo kí wọ̣n máa bàa lùgbàdì aàrùn COVID-19 tàbí fi ara wọ̣n sínú ewu.

English: --- Nigeria confirms 204 cases of COVID-19
Yoruba: --- Nàìjíríà ṣàwárí àwọn alárùn COVID-19 mé̩rìnlélúgba

English: Nigeria has recorded 204 cases of the novel Coronavirus known as COVID-19, bringing the total number of the confirmed cases to 1932.
Yoruba: Nàìjíríà ti ní àkosílẹ̀ ènìyàn mẹ́rìnlélúgba tí wọ́n ní ààrun kòrónà tí a mọ̀ sí COVID - 19, èyí tó mú gbogbo akárùn náà jé̩ o̩gbò̩nlélé̩è̩dé̩gbàá lé méjì (1932).

English: There are 319 Discharged and 58 Deaths.
Yoruba: Okòóléló̩ò̩dúnrún dín ò̩kan (319) gba ìwòsàn, méjìdínlọ́gọ́ta sì kú.

English: On its official Twitter handle @NCDCgov, the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control, NCDC, showed the breakdown of the new cases;
Yoruba: Àjo̩ a-gbógun-ti-àjàkálẹ̀-ààrun ti Nàìjíríà (NCDC) ló so̩ èyí lórí ẹ̀rọ abẹ́yẹfò @NCCDCgov;

English: 204 new cases of #COVID19 reported;
Yoruba: Alárùn COVID-19 mé̩rìnlélúgba ti farahàn;

English: 80-Kano 45-Lagos 12-Gombe 9-Bauchi 9-Sokoto 7-Borno 7-Edo 6-Rivers 6-Ogun 4-FCT 4-Akwa Ibom 4-Bayelsa 3-Kaduna 2-Oyo 2-Delta 2-Nasarawa 1-Ondo 1-Kebbi 11:50pm 30th April- 1932 confirmed cases of #COVID19 in Nigeria Discharged.
Yoruba: Ọgọ́rin-Kano, márùndínláàdọ́ta-Èkó, méjìlá-Gombe, mẹ̩́sàn-án-Bauchi, mé̩sàn-án-Sokoto, méje-Borno, méje-Edo, méfà-Rivers, méfà-Ògùn, mẹ́rin-Àbújá, mẹ́rin-Akwa Ibom, mẹ́rin-Bayelsa, mẹ́ta-Kaduna, méjì-Òyó, méjì-Delta, méjì-Nasarawa, Ò̩kan-Òǹdó, Ò̩kan-Kebbi. Ní agogo méjìlá ku ìṣéjú mẹ́wàá, ọgbọ̀n ọjo oṣú igbe - 1932 alárùn Covid-19 farahàn ní Nàìjíríà.

English: --- COVID-19: Ministerial Task Team on Kano submits interim report
Yoruba: --- COVID-19: Ikò̩ òṣìṣé mínísítà ti Kano s̩àgbékalè̩ ìròyìn gbà-á-gbè̩

English: The Ministerial Task Team on fact-finding mission to Kano has submitted an interim report to the Federal Ministry of Health, on the needs, strengths and weaknesses of the Kano response system.
Yoruba: Ikò̩ ọ̀ṣìṣẹ́ mínísítà lóri is̩é̩ ìwádìí sí Kano, ti s̩e àgbékalè̩ ìròyìn gbà-á-gbè̩ fun ilé-iṣẹ́ ìjọba àpapọ̀ ti ìlera, lórí ìdí, okun àti àìlera ọ̀nà tí ìpínlẹ̀ Kano ṣe ń dáhùn.

English: The Minister of Health, Dr Osagie Ehanire said this at the daily joint press briefing by the Presidential Task Force on Covid-19, in Abuja, Nigeria.
Yoruba: Mínísítà fún ìlera, Dókítà Osagie Ehanire sò̩yí nínú ìpàdé àpapọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn oníròyìn èyí tí ìgbìmọ̀ ìjọba àpapọ tó ń mójútó COVID-19 ní Àbújá ṣe.

English: He said while the Ministry awaits a full report, the interim report will be a guide in supporting Kano State COVID-19 Task force with necessary material, training and human resources.
Yoruba: Ó ní bí ilé-iṣé ìjọba àpapọ s̩e ń retí ìròyìn kíkún, ìròyìn gbà-á-bè̩ yìí yóò jẹ́ ató̩nà nínú ìrànwọ́ fún ikò̩ agbógunti Covid-19 ti Kano pèlú èròja to ye̩, ìdánilé̩kò̩ó̩ àti àwo̩n ènìyàn araniló̩wó̩.

English: "They will include assembling and dispatching a technical team from FMOH and virus Infectious disease specialists from Irrua Specialist hospital to join a technical team from Lagos Ministry of Health that is already on ground in Kano at the request of the Governor of Kano State" he said.
Yoruba: " Lára àwọn ohun ìrànwọ́ ni kíkó àti rírán àwọn ẹgbẹ́ onímọ̀ láti FMOH àti àwọn onímọ̀ nípa kòkòrò ààrùn láti ilé-ìwòsàn Irrua Specialist Hospital láti darapọ̀ mọ́ ẹgbẹ́ onímọ̀ ilé-iṣẹ́ ètò ìlera ní ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó tí ó ti ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní ìpínlẹ̀ Kano nítorí Gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀ Kano"

English: He said there will also be a good pool of experienced hands-on experts to support the leading role of Kano State in the response.
Yoruba: Gé̩gé̩ bi ìdáhùn, ó tún so̩ pé àwọn onímọ̀ onírìírí yóò pò̩ jaburata ní ìkàlè̩ láti kin àwo̩n òs̩ìs̩é̩ ìs̩áájú lé̩yìn ní ìpínlẹ̀ Kano.

English: "An emergency medical team from FHOH has left Abuja with ambulances, five of which were kindly donated by FRSC, on their way to Kano to provide emergency response in view of movement restrictions arising from the lockdown."
Yoruba: "E̩gbẹ́ oníṣègùn tó ń dáhùn ìpè pàjáwìrì lati FMOH ti kúrò ní Àbújá pẹ̀lú àwo̩n áḿbúlàǹsì, márùn-ún ni àjọ ẹ̀ṣọ́ ojú pópó (FRSC) fi to̩re̩, lọ́nà láti lọ sí ìpínlẹ̀ Kano fún ìdáhùn pàjáwìrì látàríi àṣẹ kónílégbélé.

English: Dr Ehanire restated the need for health workers to stringently follow laid down standard infection prevention and control measures at all times and not to take risks.
Yoruba: Dókítà Ehanire tún sọ̀dí tí àwọn òṣìṣé ìlera ṣe gbọ́dọ̀ tẹ̀lé àwọn ìlànà ìpara-ẹni-mọ́ fún ààrùn ní gbogbo ìgbà, kí wọ́n máa sì fi ẹ̀mí wọn wéwu.

English: "We cannot afford to lose the service of essential manpower at this time; every client should be treated with a high index of suspicion for COVID-19, but treat every client with fairness so that persons suffering from other ailments do not suffer neglect or treatment refusal."
Yoruba: "A kò leè gbà láti pàdánù àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ pàtàkì nírú àkókò báyìí; gbogbo ènìyàn ni wọ́n gbọ́dọ̀ tó̩jú pẹ̀lú ìfura tó ga fún COVID-19 sùgbọ́n kí wọ́n tójú gbogbo ènìyàn láì s̩ojús̩àájú kí àwọn elòmíràn pẹ̀lú àìsàn má baà jìyà àìdásí tàbí kí wọ́n má tó̩jú wọn."

English: "It is not ethical to turn clients away without, at least a medical advice, neither should a person in distress be refused care in emergency situation" he said.
Yoruba: Ó wípé, "Ó jẹ́ ohun àìdára láti lé àwọn ènìyàn lọ láìsí ìmọ̀ràn nípa ètò ìlera tàbí kí á fi ìtọ́jú du ẹni tí ó nílò ìtọ́jú ní pàjáwìrì."

English: --- Re-opening of schools not yet in view - Minister
Yoruba: --- S̩ís̩í àwo̩n ilé-è̩kó̩ kò tíì farahàn - Mínísítà

English: The Minister of State for Education, Emeka Nwajiuba says he cannot for-see or immediately tell when schools will be reopened.
Yoruba: Mínísítà ìpínlẹ̣̀ fún ètò ẹ̣̀kọ̣́, Emeka Nwajiuba ní òun kò leè sọjọ́ tàbí ìgbà tí wọn yóò padà ṣí ilé-è̩kó̩.

English: The Minister also said re-opening of schools will be in tandem with President Muhammadu Buhari's gradual ease of the lockdown put in place to curb the spread of COVID-19.
Yoruba: Mínísítà tẹ̣̀síwájú pé ṣíṣí àwọn ilé-è̩kó̩ yóò jẹ́ ní sísẹ̀-n-tẹ̀lé pẹ̀lú bí Ààrẹ Muhammadu Buhari ṣe ń gbẹ́sẹ̀ kúrò lórí àṣẹ kónílé-gbélé tí ó wà láti kápá ààrùn kòrónà.

English: Nwajiuba who had earlier during the daily briefing said that the government is not ready to put the lives of children at risk, warned that no school should engage students except when a formal date of resumption is announced by the government.
Yoruba: Nwajiuba, nínú ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀ lójojúmọ́ ti sọ s̩áájú wípé ìjọ̣̣ba kò ṣetán láti fi ẹ̣̀mí àwọ̣̣̣̣n o̩mo̩ wéwu, ó wá kìlọ̀ wípé ilé-è̩kó̩ kọkan kò gbọdọ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ ètò ẹ̀kọ́ nílé-è̩kó̩ wọ̣̣n àyàfi ọjọ́ tí ìjọ̣̣ba bá kéde rẹ̀ pé kí ilé-è̩kó̩ wọlé.

English: " In anyway none of these schools can function outside the society."
Yoruba: "Ní kúkurú, kò sí èyíkèyí nínú àwo̩n ilé-è̩kó̩ yìí tó le s̩í lé̩yìn odi.

English: The Minister also said that all entrance examinations that had been postponed will hold when the government is satisfied that the students have understood the syllabus as planned.
Yoruba: Mínísítà tún so̩ pé gbogbo àwọ̣̣n ìdánwò ìgbaniwọlé tí wọ́n ti sún síwájú ni yóò di ṣíṣe nígbà tí ìjọba bá ri dájú pé gbogbo ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ tí wó̩n gbékalè̩ ló yé àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ó̩.

English: The Minister clarified that both the West African Examination Council for Senior School Students and other National Examinations including NABTEB are not cancelled but only postponed.
Yoruba: Mínísítà ṣe àlàyé pé ìdánwò àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ oníwèémẹwàá (WAEC) àti àwọn ìdánwò àpapọ̀ (NECO) pẹ̀lu NABTEB ni kò ì di fífagilé sùgbọ́n tí wó̩n sún síwájú.

English: He acknowledged challenges in the deployment of the e-learning policy hence the engagement of the State Universal Basic Education Boards.
Yoruba: Ó sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ìpèníjà tí ẹ̀kọ́ orí ayélujára tí a ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ mú wọlé àti bí a ṣe mú ètò ẹ̀kọ́ gbogboogbò ní ìpínlẹ̀ lò.

English: According to him," we know some are limited by access and the access is limited by device, some can only get on the continuation of their academic program via radio, some at the television level, some are using computer online system, so we are doing this in partnership with states meaning that every gap we intend to bridge as regards the education of these children nationwide, we had to pass through every state Governor through their SUBEBS"
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ó ṣe sọ, "A mọ̀ wípé àwọn kan kò ni àǹfààní àti àìkò ní àǹfààní yìí nítorí àìkò ní ẹ̀rọ tó kún ojú òsùwọ̀n, àwọn kan le tẹsíwájú nínú ẹ̀kọ́ wọn lórí rédíò, àwọn kan lórí te̩lifís̩àn, àwọn kan sì ń lo ẹ̀rọ ayára-bí-àsá pẹ̀lú ayélujára, nítorí náà à ń ṣe èyí pẹ̀lú àjọṣiṣẹ́pọ̀ ìjọba ìpínlẹ, èyí túmọ̀ sí pé gbogbo àlàfo tí a fe̩ dí tó nííṣe pẹ̀lú ẹ̀kọ́ àwọn ọmọ jákèjádò orílẹ̀-èdè yìí, a nílò láti gba ọ̀dọ̀ Gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀ kọ̀ọ̀kan nípaṣè àjọ ẹ̀kọ́ alákọ̀ọ́bẹ̀rẹ̀ káríayé SUBEBS"

English: "Presently we have time table for 31 states out of 36 states, which means via Radio or T.v, teaching and learning are ongoing, these are time tables that suit each state but the federal government has only provided guideline via online content"
Yoruba: "Ní báyìí a ti ní ètò ìlànà ẹ̣̀kọ̣́ fún àwọ̣̣n ìpínlẹ̀ mọ̣́kànlélọ̣́gbọ̀n nínú ìpínlẹ̀ mẹ̣̣́rìndínlógóji, èyí túmọ̀ sí wípé láti orí rédíò tàbí te̩lifís̩àn, ìkọ́ni àti ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ n lọ, èyí jẹ́ àwo̩n ìlànà ìkẹ́kò̩ọ́ tó dára fún ìpínlẹ kọ̀ọ̀kan sùgbọ́n ìjọba àpapọ̀ ti ṣe ìlànà láti orí ayélujára."

English: "Using these SUBEBs ,the same way we share their interventions with them is the same way this teaching and learning online content is been shared and the FG informed that they could use state media that is appropriate in their areas." Nwajiuba said.
Yoruba: Nwajiuba sọ wípé "Lílo àwo̩n SUBEB, ọ̀nà tí à ń gbà momi o̩gbó̩n wo̩n ni a ṣe fi pín kíkọ́ àti mímọ̀ yìí lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára. Ìjọba àpapọ̀ sì sọ wípé wọ́n leè lo àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ìgbóhùn sáfẹ́fẹ́ ti ìpínlẹ̀ wo̩n tó dára fún un."

English: The Minister added that the COVID 19 pandemic has helped all stakeholders to retool and has also helped everybody to get on board.
Yoruba: Mínísítà s̩àfikún pé àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn COVID-19 ti ran àwọn olókoòwò gbogbo lọ́wọ́ láti túnramú, ó sì ti ran ẹnìkọ̀ọ̀kan láti bọ́ sójú iṣẹ́.

English: Speaking on the Sustainability of the e-learning policy, the Minister said the government will further engage master teachers that will perfect the system that will transcend its use after the Coronavirus health challenge facing the world.
Yoruba: Nígbà tó ń sọ̀rọ̀ lórí ìmúdúró ẹ̀kọ́ lórí ayélujára, mínísítà sọ wípé ìjọba yóò túnbọ̀ ṣàmúlò àwọn olùkọ́ akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ tí yóò ṣàṣepé ètò náà tí yóò leè mú u wúlò lẹ́yìn ìpèníjà ààrun kòrónà tó kojú àgbááyé.

English: Meanwhile the Education Secretariat of the Federal Capital Territory Administration FCTA, has issued a warning to some private Schools disseminating information to parents and students indicating the resumption of the 2019/2020 3rd term calendar online.
Yoruba: Bákan náà, ilé-iṣẹ́ ẹ̀kọ́ tó ń ṣàmójútó àwọn ilé-è̩kó̩ ní olú-ìlú FCTA, ṣe ìkìlọ̀ fún àwọn ilé-è̩kó̩ aládàáni tí wọ́n ń dájọ́ ìwọlé táàmù kẹta fún 2019/2020 lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára fún àwọn òbí àti akẹ́kọ̀ọ́.

English: The FCTA Education Secretary, Umaru Marafa said in a statement released on Tuesday that no academic activities in all Schools in any form should commence until a notice to reopen is approved and conveyed by the Secretariat"
Yoruba: Akọ̀wé ilé-iṣẹ́ àjọ tó ń mójútó ilé-è̩kó̩, Umaru Marafa sọ nínú àtẹ̀jáde ọjọ́ ìṣẹ́gun wípé kò sí iṣẹ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ kọ̀kan ní ilé-è̩kó̩ kọ̀ọ̀kan lọ́nàkọnà tó gbọ́dọ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ títí di ìgbà tí àṣẹ s̩ís̩í ilé ìwé bá jáde.

English: "The Implication of this is that when the Schools will be reopened, adequate notice of the fact that 2nd term was inconclusive will be factored into the academic calendar which will dovetail into the 3rd term accordingly. Any action taken otherwise is likely to negatively distort the academic calendar of the schools involved" Marafa said.
Yoruba: Marafa so̩ pé, "Ìtumò̩ èyí ni pé nígbà tí àwọn ilé-è̩kó̩ yóò bá di s̩ís̩í padà, ìfilọ̀ tí ó yé̩ ni yóò ti wà lórí táàmù kejì tí kò parí, àti ò̩nà àti runmó̩ táàmù kẹta bí ó ti yẹ. Ìgbésè̩ tó bá lòdì sí èyí ṣeéṣe kó kóbá ètò ẹ̀kọ́ àwọn ilé-è̩kó̩ tó kàn.

English: School proprietors are therefore, advised to maintain the status quo and keep their schools closed and not re-open in any form while they await further directives from the FCTA.
Yoruba: Wó̩n ro̩ àwọn ọ̀gá ilé-è̩kó̩ aláàdáni láti sowé-agbéjé̩-mó̩wó̩ kí ilé-è̩kó̩ wò̩n sì wà látìpa, kí wọ́n má s̩e si ní ọ̀nàkọnà títí ìjò̩ba yóò fi sohun mìíràn.

English: Violators of this directive will face the full wrath of the law.
Yoruba: Àwọn tí wọ́n bá ṣe lòdì sí àṣẹ yìí yóò dojúkọ ìdájọ́ òfin pó̩nńbélé;

English: Marafa further disclosed that the FCTA Education Secretariat has concluded plans to introduce e-learning platforms to include lessons on radio and television channels to keep the students constructively engaged while the lockdown lasts.
Yoruba: Marafa tún sọ wípé ilé-iṣẹ́ ẹ̀kọ́ ìjọba àpapọ̀ ti parí gbogbo ètò láti leè mú ètò ẹ̀kọ́ lórí ayélujára w̩onú èto ẹ̀kọ́ yálà lóri rédíò tàbí te̩lifís̩àn kí àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ leè máa ṣiṣẹ́ nígbogbo ìgbà tí kónílé gbélé bá fiwà.

English: --- No private school must start work - Minister FCT
Yoruba: --- Kò gbọ̣̣̣̣̣dọ̣̀ ṣí ilé-ìwé aládàáni kankan tó gbọ̣́dọ̣̀ bẹ̣̀rẹ̣̀ isẹ̣́ - Mínísítà FCT

English: The Minister for the Federal capital territory (FCT), Alhaji Muhammad Musa Bello has warned the proprietors of private schools in Abuja that have started informing parents and students that very soon they will start work for the third term for the present 2019/2020 academic session, to be careful so that they will not face the wrath of government law.
Yoruba: Mínísítà fún olú-ìlú Nàìjíríà, Alhaji Muhammad Músá Bello ti ṣ̣èkìlọ̀ fún gbogbo àwọ̣̣n olùdarí ilé-ìwé aládàáni tó wà nílùú Àbújá tí wọ́n ti ń sọ̣̣ fún gbogbo àwọ̣̣n òbí àti akẹ̣̣́kọ̣̀ọ́ pé wọ̣̣n kò ní pẹ́ bẹ̣̀rẹ̣̀ iṣ̣ẹ́ láìpẹ̣́ fún sáà kẹ̣̣ta fún ti ọ̣dún 2019/2020 tí a wàyìí láti ṣ̣ọ̣̣́ra, kí wọ̣̣́n máa ba fojụ winá òfin ìjọ̣̣ba.

English: Senior secretary for education in the federal capital territory, Umaru Marafa said this in a statement released on Tuesday that no academic activities in all Schools in any form should commence until a notice to reopen is approved and conveyed by the Secretariat"
Yoruba: Akọ̣̣̀wé àgbà fún ètò ẹ̣̣̀kọ́ nílùú Àbújá, Umaru Máráfá ló sọ̣̣̀rọ̣̣̀ yíì nínú àtẹ̀jáde kan tí ó gbé jáde lọ̣̣́jọ́ ìṣ̣ẹ̣̣́gun pé ètò ẹ̣̣̀kọ́ kò ní tíì bẹ̣̣̀rẹ̀ nílé ìwé kankan tó wà nílùú Àbújá báyìí àyàfi ọjọ́ tí ilé-iṣ̣ẹ́ akọ̀wé àgbà fún ètò ẹ̣̣̀kọ́ bá fọ̣̣wọ̣̣́si.

English: "We are appealing to private school proprietors to allow all their schools to remain closed, they must not try to open the school except there is a notice or guideline from ministry of FCTA"
Yoruba: "À ń rọ̣̣ gbogbo àwọ̣̣n olùdarí ilé-è̩kó̩ aládàáni láti jẹ́ kí ilé-è̩kó̩ wà ní títìpa, wọn kò gbọ̣̣̣dọ̣̣̀ gbìyànjú láti ṣí ilé-è̩kó̩ náà àfi tí àṣ̣ẹ̣̣ tàbí ìlànà bá wá láti ọ̀dọ̀ ilé-iṣ̣ẹ́ FCTA."

English: All those that go against this rule shall face the wrath of law.
Yoruba: Gbogbo àwọ̣̣n tó bá tàpá ṣófin yìí ni yóò fojú winá òfin ìjọ̣̣ba.

English: Marafa continued that Ministry of FCTA in charge of education has planned to start teaching by using the knowledge of internet, the use of television to teach the students in the period of lockdown.
Yoruba: Máràfá tẹ̀síwájú pé ilé-iṣ̣ẹ́ FCTA tí ó ń mójútó ètò ẹ̣̀kọ́ ti s̩e ètò láti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ètò ẹ̀kọ́ nípa lílo ìmọ̀ ayélujára, àti s̩ís̩e àmúlò te̩lifís̩àn láti fi kọ̣́ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ní àkókò kónílé-gbélé.

English: --- FULL TEXT OF PRESIDENT MUHAMMADU BUHARI'S NATIONWIDE BROADCAST
Yoruba: --- Ọ̀RỌ̀ ÀÀRẸ MUHAMMADU BUHARI LÓRI TE̩LIFÍS̩ÀN SỌ́MỌ NÀÌJÍRÍÀ

English: ADDRESS BY H.E. MUHAMMADU BUHARI, PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF NIGERIA ON THE CUMULATIVE LOCKDOWN ORDER OF LAGOS AND OGUN STATES AS WELL AS THE FEDERAL CAPITAL TERRITORY ON COVID- 19 PANDEMIC AT THE STATE HOUSE, ABUJA, MONDAY, 27th APRIL, 2020
Yoruba: Ọ̀RỌ̀ ÀÀRẸ ORÍLẸ̀-ÈDÈ NÀ̀ÌJÍRÍÀ, MUHAMMADU BUHARI, NÍPA ÒFIN KÓNÍLÉ-GBÉLÉ NÍ ÌPÍNLẸ̀ ÈKÓ, ÒGÙN ÀTI ÌLÚ ÀBÚJÁ, FCT, LÓRI ÌTÀNKÁLẸ̀ ÀÀRÙN COVID- 19, NÍ ÈYÍ TÍ Ó WÁYÉ NÍ ÌLÚ ÀBÚJÁ LỌ́JỌ́ AJÉ, ỌJÓ̩ KẸTÀDÍNLỌ́GBỌ́N, OSÙ KẸRIN ,ỌDÚN 2020 (MONDAY, 27th APRIL, 2020).

English: 1. Fellow Nigerians
Yoruba: 1.O̩mọ Nàìjíríà

English: 2. I will start by commending you all for the resilience and patriotism that you have shown in our collective fight against the biggest health challenge of our generation.
Yoruba: 2.Màá bẹ̀rẹ̀ pè̩lú gbígbós̩ùbà fun yín nítorí ìwà akínkanjú àti ìjólóòótọ́ yín èyí tẹ s̩àfihàn nínú ìjà àjùmò̩jà sí ìpèníjà ìlera tó gajù, tó ń kojú ìran wa.

English: 3. As at yesterday, 26th April 2020, some 3 million confirmed cases of COVID-19 have been recorded globally with about 900,000 recoveries. Unfortunately, some 200,000 people have passed away as a result of this pandemic.
Yoruba: 3.Níwòyí àná, 26th April 2020, àgbáyé s̩àwárí àwo̩n alárùn Covid-19 míĺiọ̣́nù mẹ́ta, tí ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbààrún ló̩nà e̩gbè̩rún ènìyàn sì ti gbàwòsàn. Ó ṣeni láàánú pé igba ló̩nà e̩gbè̩rún ènìyàn ló tipasè̩ ààrùn náà papò̩dà.

English: 4. The health systems and economies of many nations continue to struggle as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.
Yoruba: 4.Ètò ìlera àti ọrọ̀ ajé ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ orílẹ̀ èdè ni ó sì ń tiraka látàrí àjàkálẹ́ ààrùn kòkòrò kòrónà.

English: 5. Nigeria continues to adapt to these new global realities on a daily basis. Today, I will present the facts as they are and explain our plans for the coming months fully aware that some key variables and assumptions may change in the coming days or weeks.
Yoruba: 5.Nàìjíríà ń tẹ̀síwájú láti máa mọ àwọn òótọ́ titun tó ń súyo̩ lágbàáyé lójoojúmó̩. Lónìí, n ó sọ àwọn òtítọ́ bó ṣe jẹ́, n ó sì ṣàl̀àyé àwọn ètò wa fún àwọn oṣu tó ń bọ̀ nígb̀atí a tí mọ̀ wípé àwọn ohun kan lè yípadà láwọn ọjọ́ àtọ̀sẹ̀ tó ń bọ̀.

English: 6. Exactly two weeks ago, there were 323 confirmed cases in 20 States and the Federal Capital Territory.
Yoruba: 6.Ní déédé ọ̀sẹ̀ méjì sẹ́yìn, oníkòrónà okòóléló̩ò̩dúnrún lé mé̩ta ni wó̩n s̩àwárí nípìnínlè̩ ogún àti olú-ìlú.

English: 7. As at this morning, Nigeria had recorded 1,273 cases across 32 States and the FCT. Unfortunately, this includes 40 deaths.
Yoruba: 7.'Lówùúrọ̀ yìí, Nàìjíríà ti lákọsílẹ̀ àádó̩rinlélè̩é̩gbé̩fà-lé-mé̩ta alárùn nípìnínlè̩ méjìlélọ́gbọ̀n àti olú-ìlú. Ó ṣeni láànú pé ogójì ló ti papòdà.

English: 8. I am using this opportunity to express our deepest condolences to the families of all Nigerians that have lost their loved ones as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. This is our collective loss and we share your grief.
Yoruba: 8.Mò ń lo àǹfààní yìí láti fi ìbánikẹ́dùn wa hàn pẹ̀lú àwọn ẹbí ọmọ orílè̩-èdè Nàìjíríà gbogbo tí wọ́n pàdánù àwọn olólùfẹ́ wọn látàrí àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn COVID-19. Èyí jẹ́ àdánù wa papọ̀, a sì pín nínú ìbànújẹ́ yín.

English: 9. Initial models predicted that Nigeria will record an estimated 2,000 confirmed cases in the first month after the index case.
Yoruba: 9.Àwòye ìbè̩rè̩ ni pé Nàìjíríà máa ní e̩gbàá àko̩sílè̩ alárùn ní oṣù àkọ́kọ́ lé̩yìn tí wọ́n rí alárùn àkó̩kó̩.

English: 10. This means that despite the increase in the number of confirmed cases recorded in the past two weeks, the measures we have put in place thus far have yielded positive outcomes against the projections.
Yoruba: 10.Èyí ni pé bí iye àwọn tí àyẹ̀wò so̩ pé wọ́n ní ààrùn kòrónà ní ọ̀sẹ̀ méjì sẹ́yìn ti pọ̀ tó, àwọn ohun ta ti ṣàgbékalè̩ ti mú èso rere jáde lòdì síwòye àná.

English: 11. The proportion of cases imported from other countries has reduced to only 19% of new cases, showing that our border closures yielded positive results. These are mostly fellow Nigerians returning through our land borders. We will continue to enforce land border arrival protocols as part of the containment strategy.
Yoruba: 11.Iye alárùn kòrónà tó tòkè òkun wá ti dínkù sìdá mó̩kàndínlógún nínú o̩gó̩rùn-ún àwo̩n alárùn titun, èyí fihàn pé títi e̩nubodè sèso rere. Ò̩pò̩lo̩pò̩ ni àwo̩n o̩mo̩ Nàìjíríà tó ń padabò̩ wálé. A ó tẹ̀síwájú nínú títe̩pe̩le̩ mó̩ ìlànà gbígba àwo̩n as̩è̩s̩è̩dé gé̩gé̩ bi ọ̀nà láti gbógun tààrùn yìí.

English: 12. Today, the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) has accredited 15 laboratories across the country with an aggregate capacity to undertake 2,500 tests per day across the country.
Yoruba: 12.Lónìí, àjọ amójútó àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn lórílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà ti fi ọwọ́ sí àwọn ilé ìyẹ̀wò mẹ́ẹ̀dógún tó lè ṣe àyẹ̀wò fún ènìyàn tó tó è̩é̩dé̩gbè̩tàlá lójúmọ́ jákèjádò orílẹ̀ èdè.

English: 13. Based on your feedback, Lagos State Government and the FCT with support from NCDC have established several sample collection centers. They are also reviewing their laboratory testing strategy to further increase the number of tests they can perform including the accreditation of selected private laboratories that meet the accreditation criteria.
Yoruba: 13.Látàrí èsì yín, ìjọba ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó àti ìlú Àbújá pẹ̀lú àtìlẹ́yìn àjọ agbógun ti àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn ti ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ibùdó ìgbàyèwò onírúúurú. Wọ́n tún ṣàgbéyẹ̀wò ète ìs̩àyè̩wò ní àwo̩n yàrá àyè̩wò láti lè mú kí àyè̩wò s̩ís̩e pò̩ sí pè̩lú ibùdó àyè̩wò aládàáni tí ó kojú òs̩ùnwò̩n tí wó̩n fo̩wó̩sí.

English: 14. Several new fully equipped treatment and isolation centres have been operationalised across the country thereby increasing bed capacity to about three thousand.
Yoruba: 14.Ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ilé-ìtójú gidi àti ìbùdó ìyàsọ́tọ̀ titun tìbè̩rè̩ iṣẹ́ jákèjádò orílẹ̀-èdè yìí, èyí sì mú kí iye ìbùsùn fé̩ tó ẹgbẹ̀é̩dógún.

English: 15. I commend the State Governors for the activation of State-level Emergency Operation Centres, establishment of new treatment centres and the delivery of aggressive risk communication strategies.
Yoruba: 15.Mo yin àwo̩n Gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀ fúndàásílẹ̀ ibùdó ìdásí ní pàjáwìrì nípìnínlẹ̀, ìdásílẹ̀ àwọn ibùdó ìtójú tuntun àti ète bíba àwo̩n ènìyàn sò̩rò̩ gidigidi lórí ewu tó wà.

English: 16. Over 10,000 healthcare workers have been trained. For their protection, additional personal protective equipment have been distributed to all the states.
Yoruba: 16.E̩gbẹ̀rún mẹ́wàá òṣìṣẹ́ ìlera lé, la ti kọ́. Fún ààbò won, àwọn èlò ìdáàbòbò mìíràn la ti fi s̩o̩wó̩ sáwo̩n ìpínlẹ̀.

English: 17. Although we have experienced logistical challenges, we remain committed to establishing a solid supply chain process to ensure these heroic professionals can work safely and are properly equipped.
Yoruba: 17.Nítòótọ́ a ti ní ìrírí àwọn ìpèníjà kan, a dúró digbi lóri s̩ís̩àgbékalè̩ ìpèsè tí ó múnádoko kí àwo̩n òs̩ìs̩é̩ yìí s̩is̩é̩ láìsí ewu pè̩lú ìs̩o̩ra pípé.

English: 18. In keeping with our Government's promise to improve the welfare of healthcare workers, we have signed a memorandum of understanding on the provision of hazard allowances and other incentives with key health sector professional associations.
Yoruba: 18.́Ni mímú ìlérí ìjọba wa ṣe láti mú kí ìgbé ayé àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìlera wa dára si, a ti fi ọwọ́ sí ìwé àdéhùn olóye fún ìpèsè owó ìfẹ̀míwewu àti àwọn owó mìíràn pẹ̀lú àwọn ẹgbẹ́ akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ ẹ̀ka ètò ìlera tí ó ṣe kókọ.

English: 19. We have also procured insurance cover for 5,000 frontline health workers. At this point, I must commend the insurance sector for their support in achieving this within a short period of time.
Yoruba: 19.A ti s̩ètò ìdójútòfò fún àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìlera tó ń léwájú bíi ẹgbẹ̀rún márùn-ún. Níkòóríta yìí mo gbọ́dọ̀ kí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ adójútòfò fún àtìlẹyìn wọn ní ṣíṣe èyí láàrín àkókò díè.

English: 20. Nigeria has also continued to receive support from the international community, multilateral agencies, the private sector and public-spirited individuals. This support has ensured that critical lifesaving equipment and materials, which have become scarce globally, are available for Nigeria through original equipment manufacturers and government-to-government processes.
Yoruba: 20.Nàìj́iríà sì ń gbàrànlọ́wọ́ láti àwọn orílẹ̀ àgbáyé láti àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ káàkiri, ẹgbẹ́ aládàáni àti ẹnìkọ̀ọ̀kan. Àtìlẹyìn yìí ti jẹ́ káwọn irinṣẹ́ àtohun èlò ta fi ń dóòlà ẹ̀mí, èyí tó sò̩wọ́n ní àgbáyé ti wà fún Nàìjírị́à látipaṣẹ̀ àwọn àjọ tó ń ṣe irinṣẹ́ gidi àtètò ìjọba-sí-ìjọba.

English: 21. The distribution and expansion of palliatives which I directed in my earlier broadcast is still on-going in a transparent manner. I am mindful of the seeming frustration being faced by expectant citizens. I urge all potential beneficiaries to exercise patience as we continue to fine tune our logistical and distribution processes working with the State Governments.
Yoruba: 21.Pínpín àti ìgbòòrò àwọn ohun ìtura lásìkò kónílé -gbélé tí mo sọ nínú ìkéde ìs̩áájú sì ń tẹ̀síwájú láìléèérú nínú. Mo mọ ìsúni tí àwọn ọmọ orílẹ-èdè yìí tó ń retí rẹ̀ ń kojú. Mo ṛo̩ gbogbo ẹ̀yin anípìn-ín nínú rẹ̀ láti ni ́sùúrù bí a ti ń wá ọ̀nà tó dára láti pín pẹ̀lu àwọn ìjọba ìpínlẹ̀.

English: 22. Our Security Agencies continue to rise to the challenge posed by this unusual situation. While we feel deeply concerned about isolated security incidents, I want to assure all Nigerians that your safety and security remain our primary concern especially in these difficult and uncertain times.
Yoruba: 22.Àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ alábòò wa tẹ́síwájú láti dìde sípèníjà àsìkò ajo̩nilójú yìí. Bó tilè̩ jé̩ pé ìs̩è̩lè̩ ààbò ibùdó ìyàsó̩tò̩ dùn wá gan-an, mo fẹ́ fiyé ọmọ Nàìjíríà pé ààbò àti è̩s̩ó̩ yín jé̩ àkó̩kó̩ sí wa, pàápàá jùlọ ní àkókò líle òun àìmò̩ yìí.

English: 23. As we focus on protecting lives and properties, we will not tolerate any human rights abuse by our security agencies. The few reported incidences are regrettable, and I want to assure you that the culprits will be brought to justice.
Yoruba: 23.Bá ṣe ń bójútó ààbò è̩mí àti dúkìá a kò ní fààyè gba ì-tẹ-ẹ̀tọ́-ọmọnìyàn mólẹ̀ láti ọ̀dọ̀ òṣìṣẹ́ aláàbò. Àwọn ìròyìn ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ díẹ̀ tá a gbọ́ jẹ́ èyí tó ṣeni láàánú, mo sì fẹ́ fi dáa yín lójú pé a ó mú àwọn ọ̀daràn náà láti kojú ìdájọ òfin.

English: 24. I urge all Nigerians to continue to cooperate and show understanding whenever they encounter security agents. Furthermore, for their protection, I have instructed that the personnel of all the security agencies be provided with the necessary personal protective equipment against infection.
Yoruba: 24.Mo rọ gbogbo ọmọ Nàìjíríà láti tẹ̀síwájú nínú ìfọwọ́sowọ́pọ̀ àti ìfòyehàn nínú ìpàdé wo̩n àti òṣìṣẹ́ aláàbò. Síwájú si, fún ààbò wọn, mo ti pàṣẹ pé kí wó̩n fún àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ aláàbò wọ̀nyí ní irinṣẹ́ ìdáàbòbò ara wo̩n lọ́wọ́ àkóràn ààrùn yìí.

English: 25. As we continue to streamline our response in the centres of Lagos and the FCT, I am gravely concerned about the unfortunate developments in Kano in recent days. Although an in-depth investigation is still on-going, we have decided to deploy additional Federal Government manpower, material and technical resources to strengthen and support the State Government's efforts, with immediate effect.
Yoruba: 25.Bá ti ń tẹ̀síwájú láti mú àdínkùn bá ìdáhùn wa láwọn ibùdó tÈkó àtÀbújá, ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ní Kánò láìpẹ́ yìí tún bàmí-nínú-jẹ́. Bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ìwá̀díi kíkún ń tẹ̀síwájú, a ti pinnu láti s̩àfikún òṣìṣẹ́ ìjọba àpapọ̀, ohun èlò àti ìrànwó̩ peléke láti kín àti s̩àtìlẹ́yìn akitiyan ìjọba ìpínlẹ̀, ní ló̩gán.

English: 26. In Kano, and indeed many other States that are recording new cases, preliminary findings show that such cases are mostly from interstate travel and emerging community transmission.
Yoruba: 26.Ní Kánò, àti ìpínlẹ̀ yòókù tó ń s̩àkọsílẹ̀ alárùn tuntun, ìwádìí àkọ́kọ́ so pé àwọn èsì àyẹ̀wò yìí níí s̩e pè̩lú ìrìnàjò ìpínlẹ̀sípìnínlẹ̀ àti ìtànkálè̩ ààrùn nílùú kan.

English: 27. Drawing from these, I implore all Nigerians to continue to adhere strictly to the advisories published by the Presidential Task Force and the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control.
Yoruba: 27.Lati inú èyí, mo rọ gbogbo ọmọ Nàìjíríà kí wọ́n ó tẹ̀síwájú láti máa tẹ̀lé ìmọ̀ràn àwọn ikọ̀ amúṣẹ́ṣe ààrẹ àti àwọn àjo tí ó ń mójútó ààrùn

English: 28. These include regular hand washing, physical distancing, wearing of face masks/coverings in public, avoidance of non-essential movement and travels and avoidance of large gatherings.
Yoruba: 28.Àwọn èyí ni, fífọwọ́ lóòrèkóòrè, jíjìnà síra e̩ni, lílo ìbomú nígbangba, yíyàgò fún òde ìwò̩fún pè̩lú ìrìnàjò àti yíyàgò fún ìpéjọpọ̀ elérò púpọ̀.

English: 29. Fellow Nigerians, for the past four weeks, most parts of our country have been under either Federal Government or State Government lockdown. As I mentioned earlier, these steps were necessary and overall, have contributed to slowing down the spread of COVID-19 in our country.
Yoruba: 29.Ẹ̣̣̀yin ọmo Nàìjíríà, fún bí ọ̀sẹ̀ mẹ́rin sẹ́yìn lọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ibì lórílẹ̀èdè wa lábẹ àṣẹ kónílégbélé ti ìjọba àpapọ̀ tàbí ti ìjọba ìpínlẹ̀. Bí mo s̩e sọ ṣáájú, àwọn ìgbésẹ̀ yìí ṣe pàtàkì àti pé ó tún kópa nínu mímú àdínkù bá ìtànkálè̩ Kòrónà lórílẹ̀èdè wa.

English: 30. However, such lockdowns have also come at a very heavy economic cost. Many of our citizens have lost their means of livelihood. Many businesses have shut down. No country can afford the full impact of a sustained lockdown while awaiting the development of vaccines.
Yoruba: 30.Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, irú àṣẹ kónílé gbélé náà ti wà pẹ̀lú ètò ìsúnná tó pọ̀. Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ọmọ orílẹ̀èdè wa ti pàdánù ọ̀nà ìjẹun. Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ iṣẹ́ ló ti dúró. Kò sí orílẹ̀èdè tó lè gba gbogbo àkóbá kónílé-gbélé se nígbà à ń retí èsì ayò̩ lórí abẹ́rẹ́ àjẹsára.

English: 31. In my last address, I mentioned that Federal Government will develop strategies and policies that will protect lives while preserving livelihoods.
Yoruba: 31.Nínú ọ̀rọ̀ àsọkẹ́yìn, mo ní ìjọba àpapọ yóò ṣàgbékalẹ̀ ète àti òfin tí yóò dáàbòbò è̩mí á sì ló̩ràá ìgbé-ayé.

English: 32. In these two weeks, the Federal and State Governments have jointly and collaboratively worked hard on how to balance the need to protect health while also preserving livelihoods, leveraging global best practices while keeping in mind our peculiar circumstances.
Yoruba: 32.Láàrín ọ̀sẹ̀ méjì yìí, ìjọba àpapọ àti ìpínlẹ̀ ti ṣiṣẹ́ takuntakun papọ̀ lóríi ọ̀nà láti ṣe ìdó̩ó̩gba dídábòòbò ìlera àti tító̩jú ìgbé ayé, ní ìdó̩gba pẹ̀lu bí wọ́n ti ń ṣe ní gbàáyé pẹ̀lu ìrántí awon ohun ìyàtọ̀ wa.

English: 33. We assessed how our factories, markets, traders and transporters can continue to function while at the same time adhering to NCDC guidelines on hygiene and social distancing.
Yoruba: 33.A ṣàgbéyẹ̀wò bí àwọn ilé-iṣẹ, ọjà, oníṣòwò àti àwọn awakọ̀ wa ṣe leè tèsíwájú nínú ṣiṣẹ́ bákan náà kí wọ́n tèlé ìlànà àjo̩ amójútó ààrùn lórílèèdè yìí làkalè̩ lórí ìmó̩tótó àti jíjìnnà síra e̩ni.

English: 34. We assessed how our children can continue to learn without compromising their health.
Yoruba: 34.A ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò ìtẹ̀síwájú ìké̩kò̩ó̩ àwo̩n o̩mo̩ wa láì s̩e àkóbá ìlera wo̩n.

English: 35. We reviewed how our farmers can safely plant and harvest in this rainy season to ensure our food security is not compromised. Furthermore, we also discussed how to safely transport food items from rural production areas to industrial processing zones and ultimately, to the key consumption centres.
Yoruba: 35. A yiiri ò̩nà tí àwo̩n àgbè̩ wa s̩e lè gbìn kí wó̩n sì kórè ní àkókò òjò kí á lè rip é ìpèsè oúnje̩ kò ní àkóbá. Síwájú sí, a tún sò̩rò̩ lóri ìgbóúnje̩ aláìléwu láti ìgbèríko lo̩ sí àwo̩n ilé-iṣẹ́ ìs̩ááyan rẹ̀ àti ibùdó ìje̩un gbòógì.

English: 36. Our goal was to develop implementable policies that will ensure our economy continues to function while still maintaining our aggressive response to the COVID-19 pandemic. These same difficult decisions are being faced by leaders around the world.
Yoruba: 36.Àfojúsùn wa ni ká wá ò̩nà tá á lò ti yóò jé̩ kí o̩rò̩ ajé wa máa tè̩síwájú nígbà tí à ń wá ìdáhùn atè̩wò̩n sájàákálè̩ ààrùn kòrónà. Ìpinnu líle yìí làwo̩n olórí gbogbo lágbàááyé ń dojúko̩.

English: 37. Based on the above and in line with the recommendations of the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19, the various Federal Government committees that have reviewed socio-economic matters and the Nigeria Governors Forum, I have approved a phased and gradual easing of lockdown measures in FCT, Lagos and Ogun States effective from Monday, 4th May, 2020.
Yoruba: 37.Nítorí èyí àti ìyànjú àwọn ikọ̀ ààrẹ lórí COVID-19, orísirísi ìgbìmọ̀ ìjọba àpapọ tó ti gbé ọ̀rọ̀ ìsúnná yẹ̀wò àti ìgbìmọ̀ àwọn gómìnà Nàìjíríà, mo ti fọwọ́ sí kí òfin kónílé-gbélé nílùú Àbújá, Èkó, àti ìpínlẹ̀ Ògùn kí ó máa lọlẹ̀ díẹ̀díẹ̀ kí ó sì bè̩rè̩ láti ọjọ́ ajé, ọjọ́ kẹrin, oṣù karùn-ún, 2020.

English: 38. However, this will be followed strictly with aggressive reinforcement of testing and contact tracing measures while allowing the restoration of some economic and business activities in certain sectors.
Yoruba: 38.Síbè̩, àyè̩wò s̩is̩é àti s̩ís̩àwárí àwo̩n alábàápàdé alárùn kòrónà yóò máa lo̩ ní kánkán, a ó sì mú ìpadàbòsípò bá ètò ọrọ̀ ajé àtokòòwò láwo̩n ibì kan.

English: 39. Furthermore, new nationwide measures are to be introduced as follows;
Yoruba: 39.Síwájú síi, òfin tuntun táa s̩àgbékalè̩ káàkiri orílèèdè nìwọ̀nyí;

English: a. There will be an overnight curfew from 8pm to 6am. This means all movements will be prohibited during this period except for essential services;
Yoruba: a.Àkókò àìjáde wà láti 8am si 6am. Èyí túmọ̀ sí wípé rírìn káàkiri yóò di èèwọ̀ láàrin àkókò yìí àfi àwọn òs̩ìs̩é̩ pàtàkì.

English: b. There will be a ban on non-essential inter-state passenger travel until further notice;
Yoruba: b.Kò ní sááyè fún ìrìnàjò aláìs̩epàtàkì láarin ìpínlẹ̀síìpínlẹ̀ títí di àkókò àìmò̩.

English: c. Partial and controlled interstate movement of goods and services will be allowed for the movement of goods and services from producers to consumers; and
Yoruba: c.Gbígbé ẹrù alámòójútó láàrin ìpínlẹ̣̀síìpínlẹ̀ yóò wà díẹ̀ láti leè máa gbé àwọn ẹrù láti ilé-iṣé lọ sọ́dọ̀ àwọn tí yóò lò wọn.

English: d. We will strictly ensure the mandatory use of face masks or coverings in public in addition to maintaining physical distancing and personal hygiene. Furthermore, the restrictions on social and religious gatherings shall remain in place. State Governments, corporate organisations and philanthropists are encouraged to support the production of cloth masks for citizens.
Yoruba: d.A ó ri dájú wípé a fi dandan sí lílo ìbòjú ní ìta pẹ̀lú bí a ṣe ń fi ààyè sáàrín ara wa àti ìmọ́tótó. Ìjọba ìpínlẹ̀, àwọn onílé iṣẹ́ ńlá àti àwọn ẹlẹ́yinjú àánú la rọ̀ láti ṣe ìrànwọ ní pípèsè àwọn aso ìbòmú fún àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdè yí.

English: 40. For the avoidance of doubt, the lockdown in the FCT, Lagos and Ogun States shall remain in place until these new ones come into effect on Monday, 4th May 2020.
Yoruba: 40.Nítorí iyèméjì, òfin kónílé-gbélé nílùú Àbújá, ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó àti Ògùn yóò wà títí di ìgbà tí àwọn òfin mìíràn yóó fi bẹ̀ẹ̀rẹ̀ lỌ́jọ́ ajé, ọjọ́ kẹrin oṣù karùn-ún, 2020.

English: 41. The Presidential Task Force shall provide sector specific details to allow for preparations by Governments, businesses and institutions.
Yoruba: 41.Àwọn ikọ̀ ààrẹ yóò pèsè àwọn àlàyé kan fún ìmúra sílẹ̀ ìjọba, àwọn olókoòwò àti ilé iṣẹ́.

English: 42. In respect to the above guidelines, State Governors may choose to adapt and expand based on their unique circumstances provided they maintain alignment with the guidelines issued above.
Yoruba: 42.Níbàámu àwọn ìlànà òkè wò̩nyí, ìjọba ìpínlẹ̀ leè yàn láti faramọ́ àti láti fẹ̀ẹ́ lójú sii lórí onírúurú ìs̩è̩lè̩ àrò̩ò̩tò̩ tó bá súyo̩ kí wọ́n sáà ti wà níbàámu pẹ̀lú ìlànà àgbékalè̩ yìí.

English: 43. To support our businesses and traders, the monetary and fiscal authorities shall deploy all the necessary provisions needed for production to continue and thus, jobs restored.
Yoruba: 43.Láti s̩èrànwó fún olókoòwò àtàwọn ọlọ́jà wa, àwọn tó wà nídìí owó yóò darí ìpèsè tó yẹ kíṣẹ́ leè tẹ̀síwájú, ká sì múṣẹ́ padàbò̩ sípò.

English: 44. These revised guidelines will not apply to Kano State.
Yoruba: 44.Àwọn ìlànà wọ̀nyí kò ní kan ìpínlẹ̀ Kano.

English: 45. With regards to Kano, I have directed the enforcement of a total lockdown for a period of two weeks effective immediately. The Federal Government shall deploy all the necessary human, material and technical resources to support the State in controlling and containing the pandemic and preventing the risk of further spread to neighboring States.
Yoruba: 45.Níti ìpínlẹ̀ Kano, mo ti pàṣẹ kónílé-gbélé pátápátá fún òṣẹ̀ méjì ní kíákíá. Ìjọba àpapọ̀ yóò kó àwọn ènìyàn, ohun èlò àti àwọn irinṣẹ́ tí wọ́n nílò láti ran ìpínlẹ̀ náà lọ́wọ́ ní kíkápá àti bíborí àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn kòrónà yìí pè̩lú dídènà rè̩ láti máa ràn lọ sí àwọn ìpínlẹ̀ tó múlé tìí.

English: 46. I wish to once again, commend the frontline workers across the country who, on a daily basis, risk everything to ensure we win this fight. For those who got infected in the line of duty, rest assured that Government will do all it takes to support you and your families during this exceedingly difficult period. I will also take this opportunity to assure you all that your safety, wellbeing and welfare remain paramount to our Government.
Yoruba: 46.Léèkan si, mo fẹ́ káwọn òṣìṣẹ́ tó ń léwájú jákèjádò orílèèdè yìí, àwọn tí wọ́n ń fi ohun gbogbo wéwu lójojúmọ́ láti borí ìjà yìí. Sáwọn tó kó ààrùn lójú iṣẹ́ wọn, ẹ fọkànbalẹ̀ wípé ìjọba yóò ṣohun gbogbo tó gbà láti ràn ẹ̀yin àti ẹbí yín lọ́wọ́ lákòókò tó le rékọjá yìí. Mo tún fẹ́ lo àǹfàní yìí láti fi dáa yín lójú wípé ààbò àti ìgbé-ayé àlàáfíà yín ló jẹ ìjọba yìí lógún.

English: 47. I will also recognize the support we have received from our traditional rulers, the Christian Association of Nigeria, the Nigerian Supreme Council for Islamic Affairs and other prominent religious and community leaders. Your cooperation and support have significantly contributed to the successes we have recorded to date.
Yoruba: 47.Mo tún mo rírì àtìlẹyìn ta ti rígbà láti ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn Ọba wa, àwọn ẹgbẹ́ ọmọlẹ́yìn Krístì ní Nàìjíríà, àjọ tó gajù tó ń rí sí Islam àti àwọn àjọ ẹlẹ́sìn pẹ̀lú àwọn olórí agbègbè. Ìfọwọ́sowọ́pọ̀ àti àtìlẹyìn yín ti ran àseyọrí tí a ní lọ́wó

English: 48. I will urge you all to please continue to create awareness on the seriousness of the coronavirus among your worshippers and communities while appealing that they strictly comply with public health advisories.
Yoruba: 48.Màá rọ gbogbo yín láti jọ̀wọ́ tẹ̀síwájú láti máa sọ̀rọ̀ lórí ààrùn Kòrónà ní àárín àwọn olùjọ́sìn àti àwọn olùgbé agbègbè yín wípé kí wọ́n kíyèsí gbogbo ìmọ̀ràn àti ìmọ́tótó láwùjọ.

English: 49. I also thank the Nigeria Governors" Forum and the Presidential Task Force for all their hard work to date. Through this collaboration, I remain confident that success is achievable.
Yoruba: 49.Mo dúpẹ̣́ lọ̣́wọ́ ẹ̣̣gbẹ̣́ àwọ̣n gómìnà, ikò̩ ìgbìmọ̀ ìjọba àpapọ̀ amójútó ààrùn COVID-19 fún iṣ̣ẹ́ ribiribi títí dòní. Pẹ̣̀lú ìfọwọ́sowọ́pọ̀ yìí, mo ní ìdánilójú pé, àseyọrí yóò wà.

English: 50. I also wish to thank corporate organizations, philanthropists, the UN system, the European Union, friendly nations, the media and other partners that have taken up the responsibility of supporting our response.
Yoruba: 50.Mo tún fẹ́ dúpẹ́ lọ́wọ́ àwọ̣̣n ilé-iṣ̣ẹ́ ńlá, aláàánú, àjọ̣ ìṣ̣ọ̣̣kan àgbáyé, àjọ̣ aláwọ̀ funfun, ọ̣̀rẹ́ orílèèdè yìí, akọ̣̣ròyìn àtàwọ̣̣n olùrànlọ̣́wọ́ wa fún àtìlẹ́yìn tí wọ̣̣n ń ṣ̣̣e fún wa.
