Yoruba: Ní àfikùn sí panchayat tí ìbó yàn, àwọn kan ńbẹ tí wọ́n pe ara wọn ní panchayat ipò-ìsàlẹ̀ láì ní àṣẹ kankan tí ó fún wọn lágbara níbikíbi ní orílẹ̀-èdè.

English: These bodies pass verdicts and mete out punishments and remain largely unchallenged.
Yoruba: Àwọn ẹgbẹ́ yìí máa ń dájọ́ àti fi ìyà jẹ ènìyàn tí kò sì sí ẹni tí ó ká wọn lápá kò.

English: An incident in Ajmer district of Rajasthan in 2017 reported involvement of caste panchayat leading to the death of a 40-year-old woman.
Yoruba: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ kan ní agbègbèe Ajmer ní Rajasthan lọ́dún-un 2017 jábọ̀ ìlọ́wọ́sí panchayat ipò-ìsàlẹ̀ tí ó ṣ"okùnfa ikú obìnrin ogójì ọdún kan.

English: Legally, the courts can take action against such verdicts in case of both elected panchayats and caste panchayats.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí òfin, ilé ẹjọ́ lé gbé ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó tako irúu ìdájọ́ báwọ̀nyí yálà láti ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn panchayat tí ìbó yàn àti panchayat ipò-ìsàlẹ̀.

English: However, the victims seldom get the opportunity to reach a court of law before they become targets of mobs.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, àwọn tí ó fara kááṣá ò tilẹ̀ ní àǹfààní sí ilé-ẹjọ́ òfin kí àgbájọ-àwọn-ènìyànkéènìà ó tó kojúu wọn.

English: Witch-hunting across India
Yoruba: Ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ jákèjádò India

English: Jharkhand has recorded the highest number of crimes committed in the name of witch-hunting but it is not the only state.
Yoruba: Jharkhand ti ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ iye ẹṣẹ̀ àwọn ènìyán ṣẹ̀ tí ó pọ̀ jù lọ tí ó tan mọ́ ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ àmọ́ kì í ṣe ìpínlẹ̀ náà nìkan.

English: Cases of witch-hunting have been reported from Chattisgarh, Odisha, Gujarat, West Bengal Assam, Bihar, Maharashtra and Rajasthan too.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ràn-an ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ ti wà l"ákọsílẹ̀ ní Chattisgarh, Odisha, Gujarat, West Bengal Assam, Bihar, Maharashtra àti Rajasthan pẹ̀lú.

English: In a chilling incident in 2014, Debjani Bora, an Indian athlete had become a target in Assam.
Yoruba: Nígbà ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ kan ní 2014, Debjani Bora, ẹlẹ́sẹ̀ ehoro ọmọ bíbíi orílẹ̀-èdèe India ti fi ara kááṣá rí.

English: According to Debjani's statements, she was accused of being the cause of several deaths in Cherekali village located 180 km from Guwahati, the capital of the eastern state in India.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀rọ̀ọ Debjani, a f"ẹ̀sùn-un ìgbẹ̀mí ènìyàn púpọ̀ kàn án ní abúlée Cherekali tí ó wà ní kìlómità 180 láti Guwahati, olú-ìlúu India ti apáa ìlà-oòrùn.

English: She was allegedly named by a headman of a village prayer hall and brutally assaulted by the villagers.
Yoruba: Olóríi gbọ̀gán àdúrà abúlé l"ó dárúkọ rẹ̀ tí àwọn ará abúlé sí fi ìyà jẹ́ ẹ.

English: 2017 witnessed several cases in the state of Rajasthan.
Yoruba: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ 2017 ní ipínlẹ̀ Rajasthan.

English: Among these, a 40-year-old woman Kanya Devi was attacked and beaten to death after being accused by her family members in Ajmer district of the state.
Yoruba: Lára èyí ni, ọmọbìnrin ogójì ọdún kan Kanya Devi rí ìkọlù tí a sì lù ú pa lẹ́yìn tí mọ̀lẹ́bíi rẹ̀ fi ẹ̀sùn kàn án ní agbègbèe Ajmer.

English: Victims and Survivors
Yoruba: Àwọn Ẹni-tó-fara-kááṣá àti Ẹni-tórí-kó-yọ

English: People blame accused witches for causing a slew of misfortunes: the death of a person or animal, droughts, crop failures, etc.
Yoruba: Àwọn ènìyàn ń f"ẹ̀sùn kan àwọn ẹlẹyẹ fún iṣẹ́-ibi ọwọ́ọ wọn: ikú ènìyàn tàbí ẹranko, ọ̀dá òjò, àìso jìngbìnnì irúgbìn, àti bẹ́èbẹ́è lọ.

English: The attacks on these women (and some men) are vicious and inhuman.
Yoruba: Ìkọlù tí ó kọ lu àwọn obìnrin wọ̀nyí (àti àwọn ọkùnrin kan) rorò bí ẹranko ẹhànnà.

English: At times, the accusations and punishment are meted out by their families.
Yoruba: Nígbà mìíràn, àwọn èsùn náà àti ìjìyà ẹṣé máa wá láti ọ̀dọ̀ mọ̀lébíi wọn.

English: Some have lived to tell the tale and fight. Chutni Mahato of Saraikela in Jharkhand is one of them.
Yoruba: Àwọn kan ń gbé tí wọ́n sì ń sọ ìtàn-an wọn tí wọ́n sì ń jà fún ẹ̀tọ́ọ wọn.

English: People from the region call her a "tigress."
Yoruba: Chutni Mahato ti Saraikela ní Jharkhand jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára wọn.

English: She was accused of practicing witchcraft in 1995.
Yoruba: Àwọn ènìyàn láti agbègbè náà máa ń pè é ní "tigress."

English: Since then, she has transformed into an activist crusading against the victimization of women in the name of witch-hunting with the help of NGOs working to end the practice.
Yoruba: Wọ́n fi ẹ̀sùn-un àjẹ́ kàn-án ní ọdún-un 1995. Láti ìgbà náà, ó ti yírapadà di ajìjàǹgbara olùtako ìfìyàjẹ àwọn obìnrin pẹ̀lú àtìléyìn Ilé-iṣẹ́-tí-kìí-ṣe-tìjọba.

English: Chutni expresses how the lack of resources often makes it a struggle to fight against the practice.
Yoruba: Chutni sọ bí àìsí àtìlẹ́yìn tó késejárí ṣe mú u nira láti jà tako ìwà pálapàla yìí.

English: I wish there was more support from the authorities and government for the work that we are doing here.
Yoruba: Ìbájẹ́pé àtìlẹ́yìn tó tó wá láti ọwọ́ àwọn oníṣẹọba àti ìjọba fún iṣẹ́ tí à ń ṣe níbí.

English: However, I have suffered because of this practice.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, mo ti jìyà nítorí ìwà pálapàla yìí.

English: When someone comes to me for help, I am always going to stand by them, she said in a telephonic interview.
Yoruba: Bí ènìyàn bá tọ̀ mí wá fún ìrànlọ́wọ́, mo máa dúró tì wọ́n gbágbágbá, ó sọ nínúu ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò orí ẹ̀ro-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ kan.

English: Formulating Public Opinion
Yoruba: Dídá Ohùn Gbogboògbò Sí i

English: Both the survivors and activists feel that there is a lack of public opinion in support of ending witch-hunting.
Yoruba: Àwọn ẹni-tórí-kó-yọ àti ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́-ènìyàn rò wípé àwọn ènìyàn gbogbo kò ti ìfòpin sí ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ lẹ́yìn.

English: The activists who were interviewed for this story expressed a paucity of political will and intellectual engagement to provide the momentum required for the campaign against the heinous practice to succeed.
Yoruba: Àwọn ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́-ènìyàn tí a fọ̀rọ̀ wá lẹ́nu wò lórí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí jẹ́ kí á mọ̀ wípé àbùkù ìrànwọ́ ìjọba àti àwọn onímọ̀ ni kò mú ìwà àìbójúmu náà ṣíra kásẹ̀ ńlẹ̀.

English: A silver lining in this dark cloud is that people working against the practice believe that the situation can be turned around.
Yoruba: Ohun tí ó dára jù lọ ni wípé àwọn tí ó ń tako ìwà burúkú yìí gbàgbọ́ wípé àyípadà lè dé.

English: According to Prem Chand:
Yoruba: Ní ọ̀rọ̀ọ Prem Chand:

English: The efforts for ending witch hunting can be modeled on the same principles that the government has used for promoting other social problems such as the literacy mission.
Yoruba: Akitiyan láti f"òpin sí ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ lè tẹ̀lé ìlànà tí ìjọba fi polongo ètò mímọ̀ọ-kọ-àti-mímọ̀ọ-kà.

English: Also, the intellectuals would have to lend their support to the cause to mold the public opinion.
Yoruba: Bákan náà, àwọn onímọ̀ ní láti f"ọwọ́ sí i k"áwọn ènìyàn ó ba f'ohùn sí i.

English: The sources for the story were interviewed with the assistance of B. Vijay Murty, a journalist and resident editor based out of Jharkhand.
Yoruba: B. Vijay Murty, akọ̀ròyìn àti olùgbé Jharkhand ni ó gbọ̀rọ̀ sílẹ̀ lẹ́nu àwọn tí ọ̀rọ́ kàn.

English: Caring for Myanmar's orphaned elephants
Yoruba: Ìtọ́jú àwọn erin aláìlóbìíi Myanmar

English: A camp staff member bottle-feeds Ayeyar Maung. / Aung Kyaw Htet / The Irrawaddy
Yoruba: Òṣìṣẹ́ àgọ̀ kan ń rọ Ayeyar Maung ní oúnjẹ. / Aung Kyaw Htet / The Irrawaddy

English: This article by Aung Kyaw Htet is from The Irrawaddy, an independent news website in Myanmar, and is republished on Global Voices as part of a content-sharing agreement.
Yoruba: Àpilẹ̀kọ jẹ́ ti Aung Kyaw Htet tí ó kọ́ fún The Irrawaddy, iléeṣẹ́ oníròyìnin orí ayélujára ní Myanmar, tí Ohùn Àgbáyé ṣe àtúntẹ̀jádée rẹ̀ ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú àdéhùn ìbáṣepọ̀ tí ó wà láàárín wọn.

English: When forestry staff found her deep in the jungle of the Irrawaddy Delta, Ayeyar Sein was three months old.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ alábòójútó igbó rí i nínú ijù tí ó sún mọ́ Etí-omi Irrawaddy, oṣù mẹ́ta ni Ayeyar Sein nígbà náà.

English: One of her legs was caught in a steel trap laid by poachers.
Yoruba: Ẹsẹ̀ẹ rẹ̀ kan ti lu páḿpẹ́ àwọn ajérangbépa.

English: Workers from the government's timber extraction enterprise saved her and sent her to an elephant camp in Bago Region for treatment.
Yoruba: Àwọn onígẹdú ìjọba ló dóòlà ẹ̀míi rẹ̀, wọ́n sì gbé e lọ sí àgọ́ erin kan ní Agbègbèe Bago fún ìtọ́jú.

English: Now she is one of eight calves being sheltered at Wingabaw, Myanmar's only elephant orphanage.
Yoruba: Òhun ni ọ̀dọ̀ erin kẹjọ tí yóò rí ààbò ní Wingabaw, ibi ààbò fún àwọn erin Myanmar tí kò lóbìí.

English: Another calf, Ayeyar Maung, endured a similar ordeal.
Yoruba: Ọ̀dọ́ erin mìíràn, Ayeyar Maung náà rí nǹkan.

English: Before his arrival at the camp, the six-month-old was snared in a wire trap.
Yoruba: Kí ó tó di èròo àgọ́ náà, erin oṣù mẹ́fà náà ti lu okùn.

English: As he was stuck among a group of boulders in the same forest where Ayeyar Sein was found, his herd was forced to leave him behind.
Yoruba: Ó sì há sí àárín àwọn òkúta nínú ijù kan náà tí a ti rí Ayeyar Sein, àwọn ọ̀wọ́ọ rẹ̀ tó kù fi í sílẹ̀ lọ.

English: However, forest workers were able to free him and he arrived at the camp last year.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀, àwọn alábòójútó ijù tú u sílẹ̀, ó sì di aráa àgọ́ náà ní ọdún tó kọjá.

English: They are the youngest of the orphans at the camp; the oldest is nearly four years their senior.
Yoruba: Àwọn méjèèjì ni erin aláìlóbìíi tí ó kéré jù lọ nínú àgọ́ náà; ọdún mẹ́rin ni erin tí ó dàgbà jù gbà lọ́wọ́ọ wọn.

English: All have tragic backgrounds.
Yoruba: Gbogbo wọn ni ó ní ìtàn kan tàbí òmíràn tí ó jẹ mọ́ ìjìyà láti ọwọ́ ẹ̀dá ọmọ ènìyàn adáríhununrun.

English: Some were left by their herds, while others were orphaned when their parents were killed by poachers.
Yoruba: Àwọn kan kò rí ọ̀wọ́ọ wọn tí wọ́n jọ ń jẹ̀ mọ́, àwọn mìíì di aláìlóbìíi lẹ́yìn tí àwọn tí ó ń pa ẹran nínú ìgbẹ́ nípakúpa pa òbíi wọn.

English: At Wingabaw Camp, the motherless calves rely on baby formula provided daily by staff.
Yoruba: Ní àgọ́ tí ó wà ní Wingabaw, àwọn ọ̀dọ́ erin tí kò ní òbí náà gbẹ́kẹ̀lé oúnjẹ ọmọ ìkókó tí àwọn alábòójútó ijù ń pèsè fún wọn lójoojúmọ́.

English: They are allowed to roam in the forest in the morning and wash in a nearby stream before returning to the camp.
Yoruba: Ààyé gbà wọ́n láti jẹ̀ nínú ijù ní òwúrò, wọn yóò sì wẹ̀ nínú odò kékeré kan nítòsí kí wọn ó tó padà sí àgọ́.

English: Currently, it is believed that Myanmar has nearly 1,500 wild elephants.
Yoruba: Lọ́wọ́ lọ́wọ́ báyìí, Myanmar yóò fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ ní tó erin ẹgàn 1,500.

English: But they are under serious threat from poaching, with elephants being killed at the alarming rate of one a week.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ ó jẹ́ ohun tí ó bani lọ́kàn jẹ́ nítorí pé àwọn tí ó ń dá ẹ̀míi wọn légbodò kò jẹ́ kí wọn ó gbé ayé, erin kan lọ́sẹ̀ kan ni wọ́n ń pa.

English: Tobago's coral bleaching alert makes it clear there is "no alternative" to fighting the climate crisis
Yoruba: Iyùn Tobago tí ó ti ń pàwọ̀dà fi hàn gbàgàdàgbagada pé kò sí ọ̀nà mìíràn ju kíkojú àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́

English: The island's reefs are on "Bleaching Alert Level One"
Yoruba: The island's reefs are on "Bleaching Alert Level One"

English: Bleached stag horn coral. Photo by Matt Kieffer, CC BY-SA 2.0.
Yoruba: Iyùn bí ìwo àgbọ̀nrín tí ó ti pàwọ̀dà. Àworán láti ọwọ́ọ Matt Kieffer, CC BY-SA 2.0.

English: Tobago's coral reefs are an integral part of both the island's marine ecosystem and its economy.
Yoruba: Iyùn-un abẹ́ òkúta òkun jẹ́ ohun tí a ò leè fọwọ́ rọ́ sẹ́yìn nínú àwọn àmúṣọrọ̀ tí ó ń mú ọrọ̀ Ajé Tobago àti àwọn àyíká erékùṣù náà gbòòrò.

English: Home to numerous species of marine life (and a main source of fish for local fishermen), they also protect the coastline from wave erosion and the effects of tropical storms.
Yoruba: Ibùgbé ọ̀kan-òjọ̀kan ẹ̀yà ẹ̀dá inú omi (àti ibi ẹja pípa fún àwọn apẹja ìbílẹ̀), tí ó sì tún ń dá ààbò bo èbúté, èyí tí kò mú kí àwọn ìjì líle etí omi ó pọ̀ kọjá àlà ni à ń sọ.

English: Popular spots like Buccoo Reef are also popular tourist attractions.
Yoruba: Òkúta inú òkun Buccoo Reef tí o gbajúmọ̀ bí ìṣáná ẹlẹ́ta tí àwọn arìnrìn-àjò afẹ́ máa ń wọ́ tùùrùtù níbẹ̀ náà kò gbẹ́yìn.

English: But after a press release issued by the country's Institute of Marine Affairs (IMA) on August 22, 2019, in which it warned that - based on findings from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) Coral Reef Watch - Tobago's coral reefs have been placed on a watch for "Bleaching Alert Level One," all eyes are on the island.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ lẹ́yìn àtẹ̀jáde kan sí ilé ìròyìn tí Àjọ tí ó ń ṣàkóso Omi orílẹ̀ èdè náà (IMA) tẹ̀ jáde ní ọjọ́ 22, oṣù Ògún ọdún-un 2019, èyí tí ó kìlọ̀ wípé - ìwádìíi National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Coral Reef Watch sọ wípé - iyùn abẹ́ òkúta òkun Tobago ti bọ́ sì abẹ́ ìṣọ́ láti ṣe òfíntótó "Ìkéde Ìpàwọ̀dàa Ìpele Ìkíni," gbogbo ojú ló ń wo erékùṣù náà.

English: There is a distinct possibility that the bleaching could advance to Level Two within a matter of weeks, which would threatens not only the existence of the reefs themselves, but also the island's marine life and people.
Yoruba: A ì í ṣe é mọ̀, ìpàwọ̀dà náà lè fò fẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ìpele kejì láàárín ọ̀sẹ̀ díẹ̀, tí yóò sì fa àkóbá fún ìwàláàyè àwọn iyùn wọ̀nyí, àwọn ẹ̀dá inú omi mìíràn àti àwọn olùgbé erékùṣù náà.

English: What exactly is bleaching?
Yoruba: Kí ni ohun tí ń pàwọ̀dà ní pàtó?

English: Corals coexist with and become home to symbiotic algae, helping it store nutrients and remove waste.
Yoruba: Alábàágbé àti alájọṣe iyùn ni àwọn ewé inú omi tí ó máa ń bá a kó ohun aṣaralóore pamọ́ àti da èérí ara nù.

English: In return, the algae gives the coral the energy it needs to grow, but drastic changes in water temperature can threaten this cooperative relationship.
Yoruba: Ewé wọ̀nyí yóò sì fún iyùn ní okun tí ó nílò fún ìdàgbàsókè, àmọ́ àyípadà ìgbóná inú omi ń dí àjọṣepọ̀ yìí lọ́wọ́.

English: When water becomes too hot (or too cold) the corals expel the algae - and with it, its main source of food.
Yoruba: Bí omi bá gbóná ju bí ó ṣe yẹ lọ (tàbí bí ó bá tutù jù) àwọn iyùn yóò lé ewé omi - tí yóò sì pàdánù ọwọ́ tí ó ń fi oúnjẹ nù ún.

English: Eventually, the coral starves to death; the most noticeable outward sign of this phenomenon is that the coral loses its colour, going from shades of brown and green to a crisp, brittle, bone white.
Yoruba: Àṣèyìnwá àṣẹ̀yìnbọ̀, ebi yóò pa iyùn kú; àwọ̀ ara tí yóò yí padà ni àmì tí a ó fi mọ̀, ìpàwọ̀dà láti àwọ̀ olómi-ọkà àti ewéko sí funfun egungun.

English: Bleaching Level Alert One means that the corals are extremely likely to start the bleaching process.
Yoruba: Ìkéde Ìpàwọ̀dà Ìpele Kìíní ń kéde wípé bí a kò bá wá nǹkan ṣe sí i, àwọn iyùn náà yóò bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í pàwọ̀dà.

English: The IMA therefore suggests that both biologists and citizens should keep an eye out for signs of bleaching over the next 9-12 weeks.
Yoruba: IMA dábàá wípé kí àwọn onímọ̀ ìṣẹ̀dá àti ọmọ ìlú ó máa ṣọ́ àwọn ẹ̀dá inú omi náà fún àwọn àmì ìpàwọ̀dà ní àárín-in ọ̀sẹ̀ mẹ́sàn-án sí méjìlá tí ó ń bọ̀.

English: Level Two bleaching would be an indication of widespread coral bleaching and coral mortality.
Yoruba: Ìpele ìpàwọ̀dà kejì yóò jẹ́ ìtọ́ka sí ìpàwọ̀dà iyùn kárí ayé àti ikú iyùn.

English: What causes it?
Yoruba: Kí ló fa sábàbí?

English: According to local coral reef ecologist Anjani Ganase, the main contributors to coral bleaching in Tobago are the warmer water temperatures - a result of climate change.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí onímọ̀ àyíká ìbílẹ̀ Anjani Ganase ti ṣe ṣàlàyé, ọ̀dádá tí ó dá ìpàwọ̀dà iyùn-un Tobago ni ìwọ̀n ìgbóná omi tí ó re òkè - tí í ṣe arapa àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́.

English: Via email, Ganase explained that the ocean absorbs much of the heat in the atmosphere, which in turn causes the water - especially shallower bodies of water, like the Caribbean Sea - to heat up.
Yoruba: Nínú ímeèlì, Ganase ṣàlàyé wípé òkun máa ń fa èyí tí ó pọ̀ nínú ooru inú afẹ́fẹ́ mu, tí ó sì ń fa kí omi - pàápàá jù lọ àwọn ibú omi jínjìn gbungbunrungbun bíi Ọ̀sàa Caribbean - ó gbóná janjan.

English: In fact, NOAA's 12-week outlook extends well past Tobago to the reefs of the Lesser Antilles.
Yoruba: Kódà, ìṣọ́ ọlọ́sẹ̀ méjìláa NOAA Tobago tan pinpin àyípadà yìí dé iyùn Lesser Antilles.

English: Other reefs around the region, most notably in parts of the Greater Antilles and Cuba, have already been placed on a Level Two Bleaching Alert:
Yoruba: Àwọn òkúta tí ó wà ní agbègbè náà, bíi Greater Antilles àti Cuba, ti wà ní Ìpele Kejì Ìkéde Ìpàwọ̀dà:

English: What are its effects?
Yoruba: Kí ni arapa rẹ̀?

English: Coral bleaching is a huge threat.
Yoruba: Ohun tí ó léwu ni ìpàwọ̀dàa iyùn.

English: Because reefs provide fishes with a habitat that allows them to have access to shelter, food and most importantly, shelter for their young until they are ready to survive in the wider ocean, the proposition of losing them will impact the ability of fish species to survive.
Yoruba: Nítorí wípé iyùn máa fún ẹja ní oúnjẹ, òun náà ni ó dúró gẹ́gẹ́ bí ilé fún àwọn ẹja àti fún àwọn ọmọ ẹja tí kòì tíì lè wẹ̀ nínú alagbalúgbú omi, nítorí ìdí èyí, bí a bá pàdánùu wọn, ẹja náà yóò bá wọn lọ.

English: It will also negatively affect the livelihoods of local fishermen.
Yoruba: Bí ẹjá bá sì tán lómi, iṣẹ́ bọ́ lọ́wọ́ àwọn apẹja nìyẹn.

English: Tobago relies very heavily on its local tourism industry; its reefs reportedly attract around 40 per cent of the island's tourists.
Yoruba: Tobago gbẹ́kẹ̀lé iléeṣẹ́ ìrìnàjò afẹ́ ìbílẹ̀; ìdá 40 àwọn arìnrìn-àjò afẹ́ erékùṣù yìí ni ó máa ń wá láti wo àwọn iyùn omi wọ̀nyí.

English: Should coral bleaching continue, there will be fewer thriving reefs for people to explore and quite likely, a reduction in tourism dollars, which affects a range of hospitality-related industries: hotels, restaurants, transport services and tour companies.
Yoruba: Bí ìpàwọ̀dà bá tẹ̀síwájú, àwọn ènìyàn kò ní rí òkúta iyùn, owó dollar ìrìnàjò afẹ́ yóò fìdí jálẹ̀, tí yóò sì kó bá àwọn iléeṣẹ́ agbàlejò bíi: ilé ìtura, ilé ìjẹun, iṣẹ́ ìgbòkègbodò ọkọ̀ àti ilé iṣẹ́ aṣàkóso ìrìnàjò.

English: The great irony is that, as tropical storms intensify as a result of the climate crisis, reefs are needed more than ever to absorb the force of waves and create a buffer between the ocean and the shore - but the reefs are compromised by global heating.
Yoruba: Bí ìjì líle bá ń pọ̀ sí i látàrí ségesège ojú-ọjọ́, òkúta iyùn-ún níṣẹ́ pàtàkì ní ṣíṣe láti fa agbára àwọn ìgbé omi àti ìdúró gẹ́gẹ́ bí alárinà láàárín òkun àti etí òkun - àmọ́ ìgbóná àgbáńlá ayé ń dí i lọ́wọ́ láti ṣiṣẹ́ẹ rẹ̀.

English: Studies show that coral reefs protect around 90 per cent of Tobago's shoreline from wave-induced erosion.
Yoruba: Ìwádìí ti fi ìdíi rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ wípé òkúta iyùn ní ń gba ìdá 90 etídò Tobago sílẹ̀-lọ́wọ́ ọ̀gbàrá tí ìgbé omi ń fà.

English: In a feature address at the International Year of the Reef at the University of the West Indies in 2018, Professor John Agard said that this function will only become more important as storm intensities increase and sea levels rise.
Yoruba: Ní ibi ètò Àyájọ́ Ọdún Òkúta iyùn ní Ifásitì West Indies ní ọdún-un 2018, Ọ̀jọ̀gbọ́n John Agard sọ wípé iṣẹ́ yìí yóò pọ̀ sí i bí ìjì ṣe ń pọ̀ sí i àti bí ọ̀sà ṣe ń kún sókè.

English: What can we do to stop it?
Yoruba: Kí ni a lè ṣe láti dẹ́kun rẹ̀?

English: Ganase says the lack of proper management that has allowed overfishing and pollution to go unchecked has made Tobago's coral bleaching worse.
Yoruba: Ganase ní pé àìmójútò omi wọ̀nyí bí ó ti tọ́ ló fa ẹja pípa kọjá àlà àti ìbàjẹ́ àyíká ni eku ẹdá tí ó fa ìpàwọ̀dà iyùn-un Tobago.

English: If this continues, she explains, active management and protection will be critical for full recovery and growth:
Yoruba: Bí ó bá ń bá a lọ bẹ́ẹ̀, títẹmpẹlẹ mọ́ ìṣàkóso àti ààbò òkúta iyùn nìkan ló lè mú kí wọn ó padà bọ̀ sípò àti dàgbà:

English: Ideally, coral reefs should be closed to the public and placed into an intensive recovery programme to ensure healthy fish communities and water quality that will support coral growth and recruitment.
Yoruba: Ó yẹ kí òkúta iyùn ó di ohun tí yóò pamọ́ fún àwọn èrò, kí iṣẹ́ ìràpadà ó fẹsẹ̀ múlẹ̀ kí ọ̀wọ́ ẹja onílera àti omi tí ó dára tí yóò mú kí iyùn ó dàgbà ó padà.

English: She added:
Yoruba: Ó sọ síwájú sí i:

English: Individual actions to reduce our carbon footprintare are always warranted but we also need citizens to demand more action from our governments to provide the infrastructure, resources and education for climate conservation and adaptation.
Yoruba: Ojúṣe oníkálukú ni láti dín èéfín inú àyíká kù, bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni ọmọ aráyé ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti béèrè fún iṣẹ́ ìlọsíwájú láti ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn ìjọba kí wọn ó pèsè ohun tí yóò mú nǹkan sún pẹ́lí, ohun èlò àti ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ nípa ìpamọ́ àti ìfikọ́ra.

English: Communities need the support to manage and conserve our natural resources not just from governments but from businesses and corporations that also utilise these resources.
Yoruba: Ó pọn dandan kí a ṣàkóso àti ìpamọ́ ohun àlùmọ́ọ́nì wa, bóyá ìjọba ni o tàbí iléeṣẹ́ ńláńlá tí ó ń lo àwọn àlùmọ́ọ́nì wọ̀nyí.

English: There is a pressing need for regional island governments to demand an international effort in tackling the climate crisis.
Yoruba: Ó ti di ṣíṣe fún ìjọba ti erékùṣù agbègbè kan náà láti kéde nípa ojúṣe àgbáyé ní ti ìgbógunti ìṣòro àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́.

English: On September 11, 2019, Barbadian Prime Minister Mia Mottley addressed this issue at the United Nations" Geneva headquarters, urging larger nations to do better in fighting climate change.
Yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 11, oṣù Ọ̀wẹwẹ̀, ọdún-un 2019, Olùdarí Barbadia Mia Mottley mẹ́nu lé ìṣòro yìí ní olú iléeṣẹ́ Àjọ Àgbáyé ní Geneva, ó ń rọ àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè ńlá kí wọn ó gbé ìgbésẹ̀ akin láti kọjúu àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́.

English: The islands of the Caribbean, she said, "do not have the luxury of time because [we] are busy trying to survive."
Yoruba: Ó sọ wípé, erékùṣù Caribbean, "kò ní àsìkò tí ó pọ̀ nítorí [à] ń ṣiṣẹ́ ìyè lọ́wọ́ ."

English: Ganase agrees about the urgency of the matter.
Yoruba: Ganase gbà wípé ọ̀ràn náà gba àtúnṣe ní kíákíá.

English: Any and all forms of aid in tackling climate change and coral bleaching, she said, especially on political levels, "requires effort":
Yoruba: Ohun gbogbo tí ó bá gbà láti gba òròmọdìẹ ojú-ọjọ́ lọ́wọ́ àyípadà àti ìdẹ́kun ìpàwọ̀dà iyùn ni kí á fi fún un, ó sọ wípé, pàápàá jù lọ "iṣẹ́ ń bẹ" fún àwọn tí ó ń ṣe òṣèlú:

English: It's not going to be easy as seen internationally, but there is really no alternative.
Yoruba: Bí a ṣe ń wò ó, kò ní jẹ́ ohun tí ó rọrùn, àmọ́ ọ̀nà àbáyọ mìíràn ń bẹ.

English: Travel: An extreme sport for Africans
Yoruba: Ìrìn-àjò: Ìpẹ̀kun eré-ìdárayá fún Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀

English: Visa applications can feel like a sacrifice to the gods
Yoruba: Ìṣèbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà dà bíi ẹbọ fún àwọn òòsà

English: Africa silhouette image by Natasha Sinegina (CC BY-SA 4.0).
Yoruba: Àwòràn olójìjì láti ọwọ́ọ Natasha Sinegina (CC BY-SA 4.0).

English: Visa page images by Jon Evans (CC BY 2.0).
Yoruba: Àwòrán ojú-ewé ìwé ìrìnnà látọwọ́ọ Jon Evans (CC BY 2.0).

English: Image remix by Georgia Popplewell.
Yoruba: Àtúntò àwòrán-an látọwọ́ọ Georgia Popplewell.

English: In 2019, Temitayo Olofinlua, a Nigerian writer and academic, was denied a visa to attend the European Conference on African Studies in Edinburgh, UK.
Yoruba: Ní ọdún-un 2019, a kò fún Tèmítáyọ̀ Ọlọ́finlúà, òǹkọ̀wé àti ọ̀mọ̀wé ọmọbíbí orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, ní ìwé ìrìnnà láti lọ sí Àpérò Lórí Ẹ̀kọ́ Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní Éróòpù tí ó wáyé ní Edinburgh, UK.

English: The British High Commission in Nigeria said they were "not satisfied" that Olofinlua would leave the UK at the end of her trip.
Yoruba: Ìgbìmọ̀ Àgbà Sórílẹ̀-èdè Britain ní Nàìjíríà sọ wípé àwọn kò "sí àrídájú" tí ó tẹ̀ àwọn lọ́rùn wípé Ọlọ́finlúà yóò fi UK sílẹ̀ lẹ́yìn tí ètó bá parí.

English: The visa refusal was later rescinded by the UK Home Office. Olofinlua went to the conference and has since returned to Nigeria.
Yoruba: Ilé-iṣẹ́ UK Nílé pe àìfúni ní ìwé ìrìnnà náà padà. Ọlọ́finlúà lọ, ó bọ̀ padà sí Nàìjíríà, kò b'ọmọ jẹ́.

English: Others have not been as lucky. In April 2019, the UK visa authorities prevented 24 out of 25 African scientists working on infectious diseases from joining their colleagues at various events taking place as part of the London School of Economics Africa Summit.
Yoruba: Àwọn mìíràn kò rí àǹfààní báyìí. Nínúu oṣùu Igbe ọdún-un 2019, àwọn aláṣẹ ìwé ìrìnnà UK kò jẹ́ kí ọmọ adúláwọ̀ 24 nínúu àwọn onímọ̀ ìjìnlẹ̀ 25 tí ó ń ṣiṣẹ́ lóríi àrùn àkóràn ó darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn akẹgbẹ́ẹ wọn níbi àpérò London School of Economics Africa Summit.

English: The people most invested in and best-positioned to tackle the problem of diseases on their continent, were barred from participating in an event about "the challenge of pandemic preparedness."
Yoruba: Àwọn onímọ̀ tí wọ́n lakakì tí wọ́n sì ní ìmọ̀ pípé láti kojúu àrùn tí ó ń bá ilẹ̀ adúláwọ̀ fínra, kò rí ìwé ìrìnnà tí yóò mú wọn kópa nínúu àpérò nípa "ìpèníjà ìpọnmisílẹ̀-de-oǹgbẹ àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn" gbà.

English: "You won't come back!"
Yoruba: "O kò ní padà!"

English: Barring Africans from entry into certain countries is not only humiliating - it also highlights the institutional racism that underpins the notion that African professionals and creatives cannot be trusted to obey the law.
Yoruba: Kékeré nìkan kọ́ ni ìdójútì tí àìfàyègba Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ láti wọ àwọn illú kan ń mú dání - bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni ó ń tọ́ka sí ìgbékalẹ̀ ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà tí ó ń ṣe àtillẹ́yìn fún ìgbàgbọ́ wípé àwọn akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ àti alátinúdá ò ṣe é fi ọkàn tàn lọ títí ni ti ìbọ̀wọ̀ fún òfín dé.

English: Article 13 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights declares that "Everyone has the right to leave any country, including his own, and to return to his country."
Yoruba: Abala 13 ti Ìkéde Káríayé Fún È̩Tó̩ O̩mo̩nìyàn wípé "E̩nì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti kúrò lórìlẹ̀‐èdè yòówù kó jẹ́, tó fi mọ́ orílẹ̀‐èdè tirẹ̀, kí ó sì tún padà sí orílẹ̀‐èdè tirẹ̀ nígbà tó bá wù ú."

English: The reality, however, is that without a passport and valid visa, this right cannot easily be exercised.
Yoruba: Òtítọ́ ibẹ̀, síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, bí kò bá sí ìwé-àṣẹ-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà àti ìwé ìrìnnà tí ó wúlò, kò rọrùn láti lò.

English: And the ease of getting a visa varies according to nationality.
Yoruba: Ìrọ̀rùn ni ìbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè kan, kò sì rí bẹ́ẹ̀ ní orílẹ̀-èdè mìíràn.

English: On the 2019 Henley Passport Index, Japan and Singapore hold the top spot for access to most countries, while Angola, Egypt and Haiti are at the bottom.
Yoruba: Ní oríi 2019 Henley Passport Index, Japan àti Singapore ni orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó rọrùn fún jù lọ láti ríwèé gbà wọ̀lú oríṣìíríṣi, nígbàtí Angola, Egypt àti Haiti wà ní ìsàlẹ̀.

English: Read more: "No Visa Mix': Tanzanian singeli stars denied visas to US music festival
Yoruba: Kà síwájú sí i: "Kò Sí Àpòpọ̀ Ìwé Ìrìnnà': Àwọn ìràwọ̀ olórin orílẹ̀-èdè Tanzania ò rí ìwé ìrìnnà wọ àjọ̀dún orin ní US

English: Kenyan author Ciku Kimeria describes the indignity of living without "passport privilege."
Yoruba: Òǹkọ̀wée ọmọbíbíi Kenya Ciku Kimeria ṣe àlàyé gbígbé láìsí iyì "ẹ̀tọ́ sí ìwé-ẹ̀rí-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà."

English: She notes that even a visa does not guarantee entry because "you still have to deal with the surly immigration official who will suspiciously ask, "And what are you here to do?""
Yoruba: Obìnrin náà sọ wípé ìwé ìrìnnà nìkan kò gbé ènìyàn wọ orílẹ̀-èdè mìíràn nítorí pé "o ní láti dáhùn àwọn ìbéèrè bíi, "Kí ló wa síbí wá ṣe?"

English: If the answer to this question isn't to the official's satisfaction, visitors could find themselves being marched back to the departure gate.
Yoruba: tí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ibodè yóò béèrè, bí èsì ìbéèrè kò bá tẹ́ wọn lọ́rùn, arìnrìn-àjó lè bá ara rẹ̀ ní ẹnu ìloro àlọ.

English: For Africans traveling outside the continent, applying for a visa can feel like offering sacrifices to a ravenous god.
Yoruba: Fún àwọn Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó fẹ́ ṣe ìrìnàjò jáde lọ sí orílẹ̀-èdè tí kìí ṣe ti adúláwọ̀, ìbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lú máa ń dà bíi ṣíṣe ẹbọ fún òòṣà tí ebi ń pa.

English: Adéṣínà Ayẹni (Ọmọ Yoòbá), Global Voices Yoruba translation manager, recounts his recent experience trying to procure a visa to Lisbon, Portugal, for the 2019 Creative Commons Summit:
Yoruba: Adéṣínà Ayẹni (Ọmọ Yoòbá), alákòóso Ohùn Àgbáyé ní èdèe Yorùbá, sọ ìríríi rẹ̀ nígbà tí ó ṣe ìbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lúu Lisbon, Portugal, fún àpéròo àwọn alátinúdá 2019 Creative Commons Summit:

English: It was the greatest news of my life when I received a mail to deliver a keynote address at the 2019 CC Summit in Lisbon...
Yoruba: Ìdùnnù ǹlá gba ọkàn-an mi nígbà tí mo gba ìròyìn tẹl mí lọ́wọ́ wípé n ó máa sọ̀rọ̀ àkórí ètò níbi Àpérò CC ọdún-un 2019 ní Lisbon. . . .

English: On April 18, 2019, some days to my birthday, I submitted my visa application to attend the Lisbon summit at the VFS Global office in Lekki, Lagos.
Yoruba: Lọ́jọ́ 18 oṣù Igbe, 2019, ọjọ́ díẹ̀ sí àyájọ́ ọjọ́ ìbíì mi, mo kó àwọn ohun tí wọn béèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà láti wọ̀lúu Lisbon ki n ba kópa nínúu àpérò náà sílẹ̀ ní ilé-iṣẹ́ẹ VFS Global ní ìdádò Lekki, ní Èkó.

English: The summit was slated for May 9-11, 2019, but visa processing takes a minimum 15 days.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ 9 sí 11 ọdún-un 2019 ni àpérò náà ṣùgbọ́n ọjọ́ márùnúndínlógún ni yó gbà fún ìwé ìrìnnà láti jáde fún gbígbà.

English: On the day I was to depart for Portugal, I still [hadn't] received my passport...
Yoruba: Lọ́jọ́ tí ó yẹ kí n kúrò nílé fún Portugal, n kòì tí ì rí ìwé-ẹ̀rí-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà mi gbà padà...

English: 11 days after the summit elapsed, I received a text from the VFS for collection of my passport.
Yoruba: ọjọ́ mọ́kànlá lẹ́yìn tí àpérò ti di àfìsẹ́yìn ti eégún aláré ń fiṣọ, mo gba iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ kí n wá gba ìwé-ẹ̀rí-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà mi ní VFS.

English: The elders say, you cannot be at your best when sad.
Yoruba: Awọn àgbá bọ̀, inú dídùn l"ó ń mú orí yá.

English: It is one thing that I was not given a visa to attend the summit, another is that the huge scholarship grant to attend the summit went down the drain, wasted.
Yoruba: Ìṣòro kan ni ti àìrí ìwé ìrìnnà gbà, òmíràn ni ti owó ìrìnàjò ọ̀fẹ́ gọbọi tí ó wọlẹ̀ nítori n kò le è lọ si àpérò.

English: I am miserable because I have not been able to refund the scholarship due to the Central Bank of Nigeria's policy on wire transfers.
Yoruba: Ìbànújẹ́ gba ọkàn mi poo látàríi àlàálẹ̀ Ilé-Ìfowópamọ́ Àgbà orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà tí kò mú ìfowó ránṣẹ́ sí òkè òkun rọrùn; n kò le è dá owó ìrìnàjò ọ̀fẹ́ tí ó pọn dandan láti dá padà padà fún àwọn tí ó ni owó.

English: It is excruciatingly painful that my right to associate as a free citizen of the global village was violated.
Yoruba: Ó dùn mí wọ akínyẹmí ara wípé wọ́n gbẹ́sẹ̀ lé ẹ̀tọ́ọ mi gẹ́gẹ́ bí olómìnira láti darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn akẹgbẹ́ẹ̀ mi.

English: I was stripped of my voice!
Yoruba: Wọ́n pa ohùn mọ́ mi lẹ́nu!

English: For Africans traveling within Africa: A painful irony
Yoruba: Ìṣòro: Fún àwọn Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò nínúu Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀

English: It's difficult for Africans to travel outside Africa - but it can be equally grim to travel within the continent.
Yoruba: Ó ṣòro fún ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ láti ṣe ìrìnàjò jáde kúrò ní Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ - ṣùgbọ́n bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni ó nira láti ṣe ìrìnàjò nílẹ̀ náà.

English: Citizens of many countries in the global North can travel to most Africa countries visa-free, or with few restrictions, but the majority of Africans need visas to travel to over half of the other African countries.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ onílùú àìmọye orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó wà ní Àríwá àgbáńlá ayé lè ṣe ìrìnàjò lọ sí ọ̀pọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè ní ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ láì ní ìwé ìrìnnà, tàbí pẹ̀lú hìhámọ́ tí ò tó nǹkan, àmọ́ ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ni ó nílòo ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lú láti ṣe ìrìnàjò sí ìdajì àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó kù.

English: Nigerian Global Voices contributor Rosemary Ajayi captures the "struggle of Africans traveling within Africa":
Yoruba: Aládàásí Ohùn Àgbáyé ọmọbíbí orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà Rosemary Àjàyí ṣe àpèjúwe "ìlàkàkà àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò ní àárín ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ ":

English: I am happy that we, and many others, are highlighting the challenges Africans face getting Western visas.
Yoruba: Inúu mi dùn nítorí wípé à ń gbé ọ̀ràn ohun tí ojú àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ máa ń rí ní wọ́n bá béèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà wọ Orílẹ̀-èdè òyìnbó àti ohun ti ó tan mọ́ ọn yè wò.

English: This doesn't annoy me as much as the struggles of Africans travelling within Africa.
Yoruba: Èyí kò gbé mi lọ́kàn bíi ti ìlàkàkà àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò nínúu ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.

English: At RightsCon in Tunis, and GlobalFact in Cape Town, I took the time to ask Africans if they had needed visas.
Yoruba: Ní RightsCon tí ó wáyé ní Tunis, àti GlobalFact tí ó wáyé ní Cape Town, mo bi àwọn Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ bóyá wọ́n ti nílòo ìwé ìrìnnà.

English: Just this weekend, I learnt of a Nigerian journalist who was unable to attend GlobalFact because he didn't have a visa.
Yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ ìsinmi tí a wà yìí, mo gbọ́ wípé oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn ọmọ Nàìjíríà kan kò le è wà níbí GlobalFact nítorí wípé kò ní ìwé ìrìnnà.

English: Let's not talk about how most of the African delegates at RightsCon had to fly out of Africa first, in order to get to Tunis.
Yoruba: Kí a máà sọ ti àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó fò kúrò nílẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kí wọn ó tó lè wọ Tunis.

English: Last month, I met an East African journalist applying for a visa to Nigeria. He was asked to supply the driver's license of the professional driver picking him up from the airport!
Yoruba: Ní oṣù ti ó kojá, mo ṣe alábàápàdé oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn tí ó wá láti Ìlà-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà wọ Nàìjíríà. Wọ́n ní kí ó pèsèe ìwé-ẹ̀rí ìwákọ̀ọ ti akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ awakọ̀ tí yóò wá gbé e bí ó bá balẹ̀ ní pápá-ọkọ̀-òfuurufú!

English: As Rosemary points out, intra-continental travel is often further complicated by having to travel out of the continent in order to reach a destination within Africa.
Yoruba: Bí Rosemary ti sọ, ìrìnàjò nínúu ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ máa ń gba ṣíṣèrìnàjò kúrò ní ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kí aṣèrìnàjò ó tó le è dé ibi tí ó ń lọ ní àárín Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.

English: At the International Air Transport Association (IATA) regional aviation forum in Accra in June, Ghana's Vice President, Dr. Mahamudu Bawumia lamented the fact that "a business person from Freetown [Sierra Leone], for example, should travel for nearly two days to go to Banjul (often through a third country) for a journey which a straight-line flight would have taken only one hour."
Yoruba: Ní ibi àpérò òṣìṣẹ́ ọkọ̀-òfuurufú agbègbè tí Àjọ Ìgbókègbódò Ọkọ̀-òfuurufú Àgbáyé (IATA) gbé kalẹ̀ tí ó wáyé ní Accra nínúu oṣù Òkúdù, Igbákejì Ààrẹ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Ghana, Oníṣègùn Mahamudu Bawumia pohùnréré-ẹkún látàríi wípé "ó yẹ oníṣòwò láti Freetown [Sierra Leone], fún àpẹẹrẹ, láti ṣe ìrìnàjò fún ọjọ́ méjì gbáko láti lọ sí Banjul (nípasẹ̀ẹ orílẹ̀-èdè kẹ́ta) fún ìrìnàjò tí kò ju wákàtí kan lọ."

English: The convoluted flight routes are then compounded by the extraordinarily high cost of air travel within the continent.
Yoruba: Ìpòyì lórí òfuurufú náà gbọ́mọ pọn pẹ̀lú owó kanangú fífò lókè láàárín Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.

English: Is it true that Africans are unlikely to return home?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ òtítọ́ ni wípé ó ṣeéṣe kí Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ó máà padà wálé?

English: A rescue operation off the Canary Islands in 2006.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́ ìdóòlà-ẹ̀mí ní oríi omi Erékùsù Canary ní 2006.

English: Photo by Noborder Network. (CC BY 2.0)
Yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Noborder Network. (CC BY 2.0)

English: Between 2010-2017, migrants from sub-Saharan African countries accounted for the largest migrant population in the world after Syria.
Yoruba: Ni àárín-n ọdún-un 2010-2017, àwọn aṣípòkiri láti àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó wà lábẹ́ Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara ni ó ṣepò tí ó tẹ̀lé Syria gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìlú tí ó ní ènìyàn tó pọ̀ jù nínú àwọn aṣípòkiri lágbàáyé.

English: Many Africans leave the countries fleeing poverty or violent conflict, to seek asylum, refugee status or permanent residence in North America or Europe.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ń sá kúrò nílùú nítorí ebi àti rògbòdìyàn, láti wábi forípamọ́síeek, didi ogúnlémidébí tàbí didi agbélùú ní Àréwá Amẹ́ríkà tàbí ní Éróòpù.

English: A 2018 Pew Research study reports that the number of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa "grew by 50% or more between 2010 and 2017, significantly more than the 17% worldwide average increase for the same period."
Yoruba: Àbájáde Ìwádìí Pew ọdún-un 2018 sọ wípé iye àwọn aṣípòkiri láti Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara "ti fi ìdá 50 lọ sókè tàbí jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ ní àárín-in ọdún-un 2010 àti 2017, ju gbogbo rẹ̀ lọ wọn ju ìdá 17 lọ káríayé ní àsìkò kan náà."

English: Sub-Saharan Africans are also emigrating to countries far and wide.
Yoruba: Awọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó wá láti Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara náà ń ṣí kiri orílẹ̀-èdè jákèjádò àgbáyé.

English: In 2014, over 170,000 migrants without legal documents ferried across the Mediterranean Sea to Italy.
Yoruba: Ní ọdún-un 2014, ó tó aṣíkiri 170,000 tí ò ní ìwé-àṣẹ lábẹ́ òfin ni ó ń wọ ọkọ̀ gba orí òkun Mediterranean lọ sí orílẹ̀-èdè Italy.

English: Many hailed from sub-Saharan Africa.
Yoruba: Ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ ló wá láti àwọn Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara.

English: In December 2018, Brazilian police rescued 25 sub-Saharan African nationals who had "been at sea for over a month" in the Atlantic Ocean.
Yoruba: Ní oṣù Ọ̀pẹ ọdún-un 2018, Ọlọ́pàá Brazil dóòlà ẹ̀mí èèyàn 25 ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó wá láti Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara "tí ó ti wà lọ́rí omi òkun Atlantic fún oṣù kan gbáko."

English: The travelers had paid "hundreds of dollars apiece" for the trip from Cape Verde. In June 2019, US Customs and Border Protection in Del Rio, Texas, USA, arrested more than 500 Africans from Republic of the Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, and Angola, for trying to cross into the USA via the Rio Grande River.
Yoruba: Àwọn arìnrìnàjòó san "ẹgbẹlẹmùkù owó lọ́wọ́ ẹnìkọ̀ọ̀kan" fún ìrìnàjò láti Cape Verde. Ní oṣù Òkúdù ọdún-un 2019, US Customs Àjọ Aṣọ́bodè àti Ààbò Ibodè US ní Del Rio, Texas, USA, fi ọwọ́ọ ṣìkún òfin mú àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ 500 tí ó wà láti Ilẹ̀-olómìnira Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, àti Angola, tí wọn ń fẹ́ gba omi Odò Rio Grande wọ USA.

English: While dominant narratives in the media perpetuate Africa as a continent of mass migration driven by poverty or violent conflict, however, Marie-Laurence Flahaux and Hein De Haas, scholars from University of Oxford and University of Amsterdam, respectively, take issue with this stereotype.
Yoruba: Onírúurú ìròyìn ni ó ti rò ó wípé Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ ni àárín-ín gbùngùn òtòṣì àti ogun, síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, Marie-Laurence Flahaux àti Hein De Haas, àwọn onímọ̀ láti Ifásitì ti Oxford àti Ifásitì ti Amsterdam, ní ṣísẹ̀ntèlé, kò gbà pé bẹ́ẹ̀ ní ó rí.

English: Flahaux and De Haas argue that these narratives are propagated not only by "media and politicians" but also by scholars.
Yoruba: Flahaux àti De Haas jiyàn wípé kò rí bí ìròyín ti ṣe rò ó sí etígbọ̀ọ́ ọmọ aráyé pàápàá "àwọn ilé iṣẹ́ àti olóṣòlú" àti àwọn ọlọ́gbọ́n náà.

English: Their research shows that migration from the continent is multi-layered and driven by global "processes of development and social transformation" that have increased the "capabilities and aspirations" of Africans" to migrate - similar to migrants from other parts of the world.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́ ìwádìí fi yé wípé àwọn ìṣípòkiri láti Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kò déédéé wáyé, ohun tí ó fà á ni "ìlànà ìdàgbàsókè àti ìyípadà àwùjọ" èyí tí ó ń mú ṣíṣíkiri lọ sí àwọn agbègbè àgbáyé wu Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ - tí kò yàtọ̀ sí aṣípòkiri láti ibòmìíràn lágbàáyé.

English: These stereotypical narratives, however, often inform visa policy:
Yoruba: Àwọn ìròyìn abanilórúkọjẹ́ wọ̀nyí, ni ó ń fa sábàbí ìlànà-iṣẹ́ ìwé ìrìnnà:

English: Most countries" authorities assume that all Africans who travel will not return to their home countries, leaving African visa applicants to bear the burden of proof.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè ni ó nígbàgbọ́ wípé gbogbo arìnrìnàjò tí ó bá jẹ́ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ni kò ní padà sí orílẹ̀-èdèe rẹ̀, àfi bí arìnrìnàjó bá ní ẹ̀rí tí ó yanrantí tó ni ó lè rí ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lú gbà.

English: Getting non-African nations to take a more nuanced approach to visa approvals for African nationals is a long battle.
Yoruba: Kò rọrùn láti ṣí ojú àwọn tí kì í ṣe ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ lójú nípa orúkọ búburú tí wọn ti sọ orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó wá láti Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.

English: Meanwhile, African nations can take action to improve mobility across the continent.
Yoruba: Níbàyìí, àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ níṣẹ́ láti ṣe sí ètò lílọ-àti-bíbọ̀ àwọn ọmọadúláwọ̀. Ìwé-ẹ̀rí-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà kan ṣoṣo fún gbogbo orílẹ̀-èdè ní Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ jẹ́ ọ̀nà àbáyọ - àmọ́ kò tó.

English: A common African passport is one step - but it's not enough. The Single African Air Transport market (SAATM), and the Continental Free Trade Agreement, both launched last year, have laid the foundation for some of these shifts, but widespread implementation is still a long way off.
Yoruba: Single African Air Transport market náà (SAATM), àti Continental Free Trade Agreement náà, tí a fi lọ́lẹ̀ lọ́dún tí ó kọjá, ti se àlàálẹ̀ ìgbésẹ̀ wọ̀nyí, ṣùgbọ́n ìmúṣẹ ṣì kù díẹ̀ káàtó.

English: Meanwhile, as an African, to dare to travel is to be subjected to cruel humiliations when travelling outside Africa - or to be jolted out of the fantasy of African unity by the harshness of travelling within the continent.
Yoruba: Lásìkò yìí, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀, ìyànjú láti rìnrìnàjò ni láti ní ìrírí ìrẹnisílẹ̀ tí àwọn tí ó ń se ìrìnàjò lọ sí òkè-òkun ń rí - tàbí jẹ́ títají nínú àlà ìsọ̀kan Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ tí kò sí.

English: Either way the visa gods demand more sacrifices, while remaining adamantly intransigent.
Yoruba: Èyí kéyìí tí ò báà jẹ́, òòsà ìwé ìrìnnà ń béèrè ẹbọ sí i, tí kọ̀ sì yé é gbẹbọ.

English: Social media propelled ethnocentric disinformation and propaganda during the Nigerian elections
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ Alátagbà ni a fi gbé àwọn ìròyìn irọ́ àti ọ̀rọ̀ ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà jáde lásìkò ìdìbò orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà

English: Ethnic driven falsehoods spiked on social media during the elections
Yoruba: Irọ́ tí ó ti ara ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà sú yọ lórí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà lásìkò ìbò

English: Voting in progress at presidential election March 28, 2015, in Abuja, Nigeria. Photo by US Embassy / Idika Onyukwu [Image Attribution: Non-Commercial 2.0 Generic (CC BY-NC 2.0) ]
Yoruba: Ìbò ààrẹ ti ọjọ́ 28, oṣù kẹta ọdún-un 2015 bí ó ṣe ń lọ lọ́wọ́ ní Abuja, Nàìjíríà. Àwòrán láti Iléeṣẹ́ Aṣojúu Ètò Ìrìnàjò sí orílẹ̀-èdèe US ní Nàìjíríà/ Idika Onyukwu [Ìgbóríyín fún òǹlàwòrán: Àìsí-fọ̀rọ̀-ajé 2.0 Àìlámì (CC BY-NC 2.0) ]

English: This story is the first in a two-part series on online ethnic hate speech, disinformation and propaganda during the 2019 Nigeria elections.
Yoruba: Èyí ni àkọ́kọ́ nínú ìròyìn oníṣísẹ̀ntẹ̀lé ẹlẹ́ka-méjì tí ó dá fìrìgbagbòó lóríi ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹni, ìròyìn ẹlẹ́jẹ̀ àti irọ́ lórí ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà lásìkò ìbò ọdún-un 2019.

English: You can read the second part here.
Yoruba: O leè ká apá kejì ìròyìn náà níbí.

English: Nigeria went to the polls to elect a new president and a national parliament on February 23, 2019.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ 23, oṣù kejì ọdún-un 2019 ni àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà gba ẹ̀ka ìdìbò lọ láti dìbò yan ààrẹ àti ọmọ ìgbìmọ̀ tuntun sípò.

English: With two main contenders vying for the presidency, incumbent President Muhammadu Buhari obtained 15 million votes and triumphed over his closest rival, Atiku Abubakar, by a "margin of 56 percent to 41 percent."
Yoruba: Àwọn méjì gbòógì òǹdíjedupò sí ipò ààrẹ, Ààrẹ tí ó wà lórí àléfà kó ìbò ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 15 tí ó mú u borí olórogún-un rẹ̀ pẹ́kípẹ́kí, Atiku Abubakar, pẹ̀lú "àlàfo idà 56 sí ìdá 41."

English: Buhari was sworn-in for a second term of four years on May 29, 2019.
Yoruba: A ṣe ìbúra fún Buhari fún sáà kejì ọlọ́dún mẹ́rin lọ́jọ́ 29, oṣù karùn-ún, 2019.

English: Read more: #NigeriaDecides2019: Everything you need to know for this year's general elections
Yoruba: Kà sí i: #NigeriaDecides2019: Ohun gbogbo tí ó yẹ kí o mọ̀ nípa ìdìbò gbogboògbò ti ọdún nìí

English: However, the election campaign was fought on different fronts, including social media.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀, ohun gbogbo tí ó gbà ni wọ́n fi ṣe ìpolongo ìbò náà, láì yọ bíbẹ ẹ̀rọ alátagbà lọ́wẹ̀ sílẹ̀.

English: There was widespread dissemination of ethnic hate speech at the service of disinformation and propaganda online, particularly on Twitter.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin tòun ìwà ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà àti ìròyìn irọ́ ràn bíi pápá inú ọyẹ́ ní orí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára, pabambarì lóríi gbàgede Twitter.

English: Ethnic hate in Nigeria
Yoruba: Ìkórìíra Ẹ̀yà ní Nàìjíríà

English: Nigeria's multi-ethnicity - over 250 ethnic groups and 500 languages - has at times been a source of conflict instead of strength.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀yà onírúurú - tí ó tó bíi 250 àti èdè 500 - ti fi ìgbà kan jẹ́ orísun àìbalẹ̀ọkàn dípòo ìfọ̀kànbalẹ̀.

English: This becomes particularly obvious during elections when politicians use these divisions to campaign for votes.
Yoruba: Èyí fi ojú hàn lásìkò ìbò nígbàtí àwọn olóṣèlú lo ẹlẹ́yàmẹ́lẹ́yá fi polongo ìbò.

English: Naturally, online conversations in Nigeria have not been devoid of ethnic-induced hate.
Yoruba: Láti ilẹ̀, ìtàkùrọ̀sọ lórí ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà kò lọ láì sí ìkórìíra.

English: Read more: Nigeria: Curbing the tide of ethnic hate - online and off
Yoruba: Kà sí i: Nàìjíríà: Gbígbógun ti àpọ̀jù ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin - lójúkorojú àti lórí ayélujára

English: During the 2015 elections, for instance, Twitter Nigeria descended into a bitter and binary sparring match between supporters of the then-two major contestants, Goodluck Jonathan (PDP, an Ijaw Christian) and Muhammadu Buhari (APC, a Hausa, Fulani Muslim).
Yoruba: Lásìkò ìbò ọdún-un 2015, fún àpẹẹrẹ, gbàgede Twitter ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà di ibi ìkorò àti ibi ìdíje ìjuwọ́ láàárín àwọn alátìlẹ́yìn àwọn òǹdíje méjì ìgbà náà, Goodluck Jonathan (PDP, ọmọ lẹ́yìn Krístì tó jẹ́ ọmọ Ijaw) àti Muhammadu Buhari (APC, Ìmàle, Hausa, Fulani).

English: Twitter became a tool for propagating ethnic hate and party politics.
Yoruba: Twitter di irinṣẹ́ fún ìgbéròyìn ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin jáde àti ohun èlò fún ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú.

English: Some thought 2019 would be different because Buhari from the All Progressive Congress (APC) and Abubakar from the People's Democratic Party (PDP) are both Hausa, Fulani Muslims, but that was not the case.
Yoruba: Àwọn kan lérò wípé ọdún-un 2019 yóò yàtọ̀ nítorí pé Buhari ti ẹgbẹ́ẹ Àjọ Ìtẹ̀síwájú Gbogboògbò (APC) àti Abubakar láti Ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú Ìjọba-tiwantiwa Àwọn Ènìyàn (PDP) tí àwọn méjèèjì sì jẹ́ Hausa, Fulani Ìmàle, àmọ́ bẹ́ẹ̀ kọ́ ló rí.

English: Their vice-presidential candidates - Yemi Osibanjo (APC), a Yoruba, and Peter Obi (PDP), an Igbo, are both Christians - but from different ethnic groups.
Yoruba: Àwọn amúgbálẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́ wọn - Yẹmí Ọṣìńbàjò (APC), ọmọ Yoruba, àti Peter Obi (PDP), ọmọ Igbo, jẹ́ Ọmọ-lẹ́yìn-in-krístì - àmọ́ láti ẹ̀yà ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀.

English: It seemed like a repeat of 2015 but now with different protagonists.
Yoruba: Ó fẹ́ jọ àtúnwáyé ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ 2015 ṣùgbọ́n pẹ̀lú atakànàngbọ̀n mìíràn.

English: The political atmosphere became ethnically-charged in 2017, two years before the elections, creating the conditions for an atmosphere of distrust.
Yoruba: Ohun gbogbo nípa ìṣèlú Nàìjíríà wọṣọ ẹlẹ́yàmẹ́lẹ́yá ní 2017, ọdún méjì kí ìbò ó tó bẹ̀rẹ̀, tí ó sì fa àìgbàgbọ́ nínú ètò ìṣèlú.

English: The Indigenous People of Biafra (IPOB), a secessionist organization in the southeastern part of the country led by Nnamdi Kanu, also added to the heightened ethnic tensions brewing.
Yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ ajìjàngbara ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ Biafra Indigenous People of Biafra (IPOB), tí ó jẹ́ àgbáríjọpọ̀ àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ ìlà-oòrùn orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà tí Nnamdi Kanu jẹ́ olórí, dá kún rògbòdìyàn tí ó ń rọ́ tìtì.

English: Read more: As ethnic hate speech rises, Nigerian writers push back
Yoruba: Kà sí i: Bí ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin ṣe ń peléke sí i, àwọn òǹkọ̀wée Nàìjíríà náà múṣẹ́ ṣe

English: Desertification in predominantly-Muslim northern Nigeria led to a southward migration of Nigeria's cattle herders that ignited violent conflicts with farmers.
Yoruba: Ìdi-aṣálẹ̀-ilẹ̀ ní àríwá Nàìjíríà ló mú kí àwọn ọlọ́sìn-ẹran tí ó jẹ́ darandaran tí ó ń bá àwọn àgbẹ̀ jà ó wà sí apá gúúsù.

English: The southern Christian communities" resentment of the influx of Muslim Fulani herders was portrayed in some narratives as an 'Islamisation' force.
Yoruba: Àwọn Ọmọ-lẹ́yìn-in-krístì kan "rí gbígba àwọn Fulani darandaran tí ó jẹ́ Ìmàle tọwọ́tẹsẹ̀ wọlé sí apáa gúúsù gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ìgbésẹ̀ láti 'Sọnidìmàlè' ní tipátipá.

English: The failure of the Nigerian government to investigate these clashes and "bring perpetrators to justice" resulted in the death of about 4,000 people from 2015 to late 2018, according to Amnesty International.
Yoruba: Ìkọ̀jálẹ́ ìjọba Nàìjíríà láti ṣe ìwádìí sí àwọn ìkọlù tí ó ń wáyé àti "fífimú àwọn tí ó ṣẹ̀ sófin dánrin," tí ìkọlù náà sì fa ikú àwọn ènìyàn tí ó tó bíi ẹgbẹ̀rún 4 láti ọdún-un 2015 sí 2018, gẹ́gẹ́ bí iléeṣẹ́ Amnesty International ti ṣe ní i lákọsílẹ̀.

English: Hence, ethnocentrism was already at an all-time high before the presidential elections in 2019.
Yoruba: Láti ìhín lọ, ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà ti ń peléke sí i kí ó tó di àsìkò ìbò ààrẹ ọdún-un 2019.

English: The prevailing distrust was a fertile ground for false information - online and offline - during the elections.
Yoruba: Àìnígbàgbọ́ tí ó wà nílẹ̀ ló fi àyè gba ìgbéjáde ìròyìn irọ́ - lójúkorojú àti lórí ayélujára - lásìkò ìbò.

English: Elections and the credibility of online information in Nigeria
Yoruba: Ìbò àti ìgbàgbọ́ ọ̀rọ̀ orí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà

English: The number of internet users in Nigeria grew from 98.3 million in 2017 to 100.5 million in 2018.
Yoruba: Iye àwọn òǹlò ẹ̀rọ ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà fò fẹ̀rẹ̀ sókè láti ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 98.3 ní ọdún-un 2017 sí ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 100.5 ní 2018.

English: Facebook maintains the lead as the social media platform of choice with 22 million users, followed by YouTube (7 million+), Twitter (6 million) and Instagram (5.7 million).
Yoruba: Facebook ló léwájú gẹ́gẹ́ bí i gbàgede ààyò ọ̀pọ̀ ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà pẹ̀lú òǹlò ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 22, tí gbàgede àwòrán-àtohùn YouTube (ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 7 àti jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ) tẹ̀lé e, Twitter (ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 6) àti Instagram (ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 5.7).

English: The majority of Nigerian voters are young. Out of the 84 million registered voters for the 2019 General Elections, over half - 51 percent - are young voters aged between 18 and 35, whereas nearly 30 percent are between 36 and 50 years old.
Yoruba: Ọ̀dọ́ ni ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn olùdìbò orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà. Lára ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 84 àwọn olùdìbò tí ó forúkọsílẹ̀ fún Ìbò Àpapọ̀ ọdún-un 2019, tí ìdajì - ìdá 51 - jẹ́ ọ̀dọ́ òǹdìbò tí ọjọ́ oríi wọ́n tó ọdún 18 àti 35, tí ìdá 30 sì jẹ́ ẹni ọdún 36 àti 50.

English: These two groups of voters, which include both digital natives and digital immigrants, form the majority of Nigerian voters who are digitally savvy.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọjọ́-orí méjèèjì yìí, tí ó ní onímọ̀ nípa ìlò ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá àti àwọn aṣípò sórí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá, ni ó pọ̀ jù lọ nínú àwọn olùdìbòo Nàìjíríà.

English: Therefore, it was not surprising that digital media was one of the prominent battlegrounds for election campaigns in 2019.
Yoruba: Torí ìdí èyí, kò yanilẹ́nu wípé ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá jẹ́ gbàgede kan gbòógì fún fífi ìpolongo ìbò ọdún-un 2019 sọta ìjà lura ẹni.

English: As a result, the credibility of online information during the 2019 elections suffered great attrition.
Yoruba: Látàrí èyí, ó mú u ṣòro láti gbọ́kàn tẹ àwọn ìròyìn orí ayélukára-bí-ajere lásìkò ètò ìdìbò tó wáyé lọ́dún-un 2019.

English: False and misleading information, promoted as gospel truth, was amplified by supporters of the two major parties in Nigeria: the All Progressive Congress (APC) and the People's Democratic Party (PDP).
Yoruba: Ìròyìn irọ́ tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n nínú ni wọ́n polongo gẹ́gẹ́ ìhìn rere tòótọ́, tí àwọn alátìlẹ́yìn ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú méjèèjì tí ó gbajúmọ̀ jù lọ ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà sì lukoro rẹ̀: Àjọ Ìtẹ̀síwájú Gbogboògbò All Progressive Congress (APC) àti Ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú Ìjọba-tiwantiwa Àwọn Ènìyàn People's Democratic Party (PDP).

English: Based on ethnographic participant observation conducted between October 28, 2018, and May 29, 2019, ethnic hate was employed as a tool for disinformation and propaganda by both sides of the political divide on Twitter Nigeria during the 2019 presidential elections.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìkíyèsí ẹ̀yà tí ó wáyé láàárín ọjọ́ 28 oṣù kẹwàá, 2018, àti ọjọ́ 29, oṣù karùn-ún 2019, ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin jẹ́ irinṣẹ́ fún ìròyìn tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n ń'nú tí ó kún fún irọ́ láti sàkání ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú méjèèjì ní oríi Twitter ti Nàìjíríà lásìkò ìbò ààrẹ 2019.

English: These observations were captured as screengrabs of tweets or saved URLs collected over this period.
Yoruba: A ká àwọn ìkíyèsí yìí sílẹ̀ láti orí ayélujára ní àsìkò yìí.

English: In terms of ethnically-charged disinformation, some APC supporters accused Obi of being a bigot for purportedly deporting northerners while he was governor of Anambra State, in southeast Nigeria.
Yoruba: Tí a bá sọ nípa ìròyìn irọ́ nípa ti ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà, àwọn agbárùkù ti ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlúu APC yọ ẹnu ìwọ̀sí sí Obi lára nítorí pé ó dá àwọn ará òkè Ọya padà nígbà tí ó wà lórí ipò gẹ́gẹ́ bí aláṣẹ Ìpínlẹ̀ Anambra, ní ìlà-oòrùn gúúsù orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà.

English: Tweets went viral that claimed that Yoruba people were burning shops of Igbo traders in Lagos. Both stories were false and will be explored further in Part II of this essay.
Yoruba: Túwíìtì tàn kárí ilé kárí oko tí ó sọ pé àwọn ọmọ Yorùbá ń tiná bọ ìsọ̀ àwọn oníṣòwò tí ó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Igbo ní Èkó. Irọ́ funfun báláwú ni àwọn ìròyìn wọ̀nyí, a ó gbé e yẹ̀ wò síwájú sí i nínú Apá kejì àròkọ yìí.

English: Figure 1: Misinformed propaganda tweet by Festus Keyamo
Yoruba: Àwòrán 1: Túwíìtì irọ́ ti Festus Keyamo

English: Figure 2: The true location of the image that Keyamo shared.
Yoruba: Àwòrán 2: Àṣírí bi tí àwòrán tí Keyamo tari síta wà ní ti òtítọ́.

English: In another example, a photograph was used to misconstrue facts. On October 28, 2018, Festus Keyamo, then-media director of the Buhari Campaign Organisation, tweeted an image (Figure 1) of a tree growing between an apparently abandoned Nigerian rail track:
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ òmíràn, a lo àwòrán kan báyìí lọ́nà tí kò yẹ. Lọ́jọ́ 28, oṣù kẹwàá, ọdún-un, 2018, Festus Keyamo, olùdarí ètò ìkéde àná fún Iléeṣẹ́ Ìpolongo fún Buhari, túwíìtì àwòrán kan (Aworan 1) ti igi kan tí ó ń wù láàárín ojú irin kan tí ó ti di àpatì:

English: This is how trees grew in-between rail tracks between 1999 and 2015...
Yoruba: Bí igí ṣe ń wù sí àárín ojú irin ní 1999 sí 2015...

English: Now, this is the 'Completion Era' as the tracks are beginning to roar back to life." The PDP government was in power between 1999 and 2015.
Yoruba: Báyìí, "Sáà Ìparí iṣẹ́" rè é, àwọn ojú irin náà ti ń jí padà sáyé." Ìjọba PDP ló ń tukọ̀ ètò ní 1999 sí 2015.

English: However, a Nigerian Twitter user later traced back the image to an original Arabic-language tweet (Figure 2) posted earlier that same month.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn-ò-rẹyìn, òǹlò Twitter kan tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà tọ ipasẹ̀ẹ àwòrán náà sí túwíìtì kan lédèe Lárúbáwá (Àwòrán 2) tí ẹnìkan tari síta nínú oṣù yẹn.

English: According to the tweet, the photo is from Lebanon.
Yoruba: Túwíìtì náà jẹ́rìí wípé Lebanon ni àwòrán ọ̀hún ti ṣẹ̀ wá.

English: Keyamo's intention may have been to show that the Buhari government had surpassed previous administrations on the revamping of the morbid rail lines in the country.
Yoruba: Ohun tí Keyamo fẹ́ ṣe ni láti fi hàn wípé ìṣàkóso ìjọba Buhari ti gbé ìgbésẹ̀ àtúnṣe sí àwọn ọ̀nà ọkọ̀ọ ojú irin tí ìjọba àná pa tì.

English: However, the use of an image from a different country made the so-called "gains" questionable.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ ṣá, àwòrán orílẹ̀-èdè mìíràn tí ó lò láti fi sọ "ìtẹ̀síwájú" náà, fọ́ gbogbo rẹ̀ lójú.

English: Figure 3: Ethnic hate speech
Yoruba: Àwòrán 3: Ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin

English: Figure 4: El-Rufai later apologized for the "insensitive" tweet shown in Figure 3.
Yoruba: Àwòrán 4: El-Rufai tọrọ àforíjì fún túwíìtì "tí ó lè dá wàhálà sílẹ̀" náà tí ó wà ń'nú Àwòrán 3.

English: Online ethnic hate speech was also pronounced before, during and after the elections.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin ṣẹ́ yọ kí ọjọ́ ìbò ó tó kò, lásìkò ìbò àti lẹ́yìn ìbò.

English: In an ethnic slurred tweet (Figure 3) Bashir El-Rufai, son of the Kaduna State Governor, inferred that the Nigerian Civil War was ignited by the Igbo vengeance.
Yoruba: Túwíìtì ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà kan (Àwòrán 3) Bashir El-Rufai, ọmọ Aláṣẹ Ìpínlẹ̀ Kaduna, wí pé ẹ̀yà Igbo ló fi ìbínú tan iná ọ̀tẹ̀ tí ó fa Ogun Abẹ́lée Nàìjíríà.

English: Between 1967 and 1970, Nigeria fought a bitter civil war with the secessionist state of Biafra inhabited mostly by the Igbo in the southeastern part of the country.
Yoruba: Láàárín 1967 sí 1970, orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ja ogun kíkorò kan pẹ̀lú ìlúu Biafra tí í ṣe àwọn ẹ̀yà Igbo tí ó wà ní apá ìlà-oòrùn gúúsù, tí ó ń gbèrò láti pín yà kúrò lábẹ́ ìṣàkóso ìjọba Nàìjíríà.

English: Hence, according to Bashir El-Rufai, the result of the 2019 elections which was won by his party, the APC, should also be taken as a sweet "revenge" from the Hausa, Fulani.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀, gẹ́gẹ́ bí Bashir El-Rufai ti ṣe sọ, àbájáde ìbò ọdún-un 2019 tí ẹgbẹ́ẹ rẹ̀, APC, gbégbà-orókè. Ó yẹ kí a rí i bíi "ẹ̀san" láti apá ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn ẹ̀yà Hausa, Fulani.

English: He later apologized, after a backlash, for his previous "insensitive" tweet as shown in Figure 4.
Yoruba: Ó padà wá á tọrọ àforíjì, lẹ́yìn tí a ti bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lù ú, fún túwíìtì "tí ó lè dá wàhálà sílẹ̀ " bí a ti rí i nínú Àwòrán.

English: He also deleted the earlier tweet (Figure 3).
Yoruba: Bákan náà ni ó mú túwíìtì ìsọkúsọ náà wálẹ̀ (Àwòrán 3).

English: Ethnic-motivated false information on social media during the elections falls into two categories: disinformation and propaganda.
Yoruba: Ìròyìn irọ́ tí ó ti ara ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà wá lórí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà lásìkò ìbò ṣe é pín sábẹ́ ẹ̀ka méjì: ìròyìn tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n nínú àti ìròyìn irọ́.

English: Miroslav Tudjman and Nives Mikelic, communication scholars at the University of Zagreb, Croatia, define disinformation as "intentionally deputed mistaken information with the purpose to mislead the user."
Yoruba: Miroslav Tudjman àti Nives Mikelic, ọ̀mọ̀wé nípa ìtàkùrọ̀sọ ní Ifáfitì ti Zagreb, Croatia, túmọ̀ ìròyìn tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n nínú sí "ìròyìn àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ tari síta láti ṣi àwọn ènìyàn lọ́kàn."

English: Hence, the intention to pass across inaccurate, distorted and false evidence as true, distinguishes dis-information from misinformation.
Yoruba: Ète títari ìròyìn irọ́ síta bí òtítọ́, ló ya ìròyìn tí ó ń ṣini lọ́kàn àti ìròyìn irọ́ sọ́tọ́.

English: Tudjman and Mikelic assert that propaganda is much more than disinformation or misinformation.
Yoruba: Tudjman àti Mikelic sọ wípé ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn fẹ̀jú ju ìròyìn àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ tari síta láti ṣini lọ́kàn tàbí ìròyìn irọ́ lọ.

English: This is because propaganda "aims to manipulate the attitudes of the user" through an "accidental or intentional handling with information in [the] communication process."
Yoruba: Ìdí ni pé ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn "máa ń yí ìhùwàsí ẹni padà" nípasẹ̀ "ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àìròtẹ́lẹ̀ kan tàbí ìgbésẹ̀ àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ dá lásìkò ìtari ìtàkùrọ̀sọ [náà] síta."

English: Thus, propaganda weaponizes biased or inaccurate information for political interests and consequently manipulates perception.
Yoruba: Bí irú èyí, ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn máa ń tẹ̀sí apá kan tàbí àìpé ìròyìn fún àǹfààní ọ̀rọ̀ òṣèlú àti yíyí ìrònú padà níparí.

English: Justifiable fears emerged surrounding 2019 elections because online disinformation and propaganda incites electoral violence but also poses "a threat to reconciliation after the elections."
Yoruba: Ìbẹ̀rùbojo ọkàn bẹ́ sílẹ̀ látàrí ìbò ọdún-un 2019 nítorí ìròyìn irọ́ àti ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn ń ṣe àgbédìde àìbalẹ̀ ọkàn tí ó ti ọ̀rọ̀ ìbò bẹ̀rẹ̀ àmọ́ tí ó ń fa "ìdẹ́rùbà fún ìparí-ìjà tí ìbòó bá kásẹ̀ ńlẹ̀ ."

English: Part II of this essay will examine how this played out online, especially on Twitter, with specific examples.
Yoruba: Apá kejì àròkọ yìí yóò ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò bí èyí ṣe wáyé lórí ayélujára, pàápàá lóríi gbàgede Twitter, pẹ̀lú àwọn àpẹẹrẹ mélòó kan.

English: This article is part of a series of posts examining interference with digital rights through methods such as network shutdowns and disinformation during key political events in seven African countries: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.
Yoruba: Àpilẹ̀kọ yìí jẹ́ ara àtẹ̀jádé ìròyìn oníṣísẹ̀ntẹ̀lé tí ó ń ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò ìṣúsí pẹ̀lú ẹ̀tọ́ ìlò ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá nípa àwọn ìlànà bíi ìṣánpa ìṣàsopọ̀ ẹ̀rọ ayélukára-bí-ajere àti ìròyìn ẹlẹ́jẹ̀ lásìkò ètò ìṣèlú tí ó pọn dandan ní orílẹ̀-èdè méje ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nàìjíríà, Tunisia, Uganda, àti Zimbabwe.

English: The project is funded by the Africa Digital Rights Fund of The Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA).
Yoruba: Africa Digital Rights Fund àti The Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA) ni agbátẹrù iṣẹ́ àkànṣe yìí.

English: From Kenya to Ethiopia, these men received divine dream "maps" to carve caves
Yoruba: Ní Kenya àti Ethiopia, àwọn ọkùnrin wọ̀nyí ríran "àwòrán-ìtọ́nà" àt'ọ̀run wá láti gbẹ́ ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀

English: Both men say they received explicit instructions from God
Yoruba: Àwọn ọkùnrin méjèèjì sọ wípé Ọlọ́run ló yọ sí àwọn

English: Dunbar caves in southern Ethiopia were dug by Mohammed Yiso Banatah with his bare hands.
Yoruba: Ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ẹ Dunbar ní gúúsù Ethiopia tí Mohammed Yiso Banatah gbẹ́ jáde pẹ̀lú ọwọ́ọ rẹ̀ láì lo ohunkóhun.

English: He was instructed by Allah to create underground wedding chapels.
Yoruba: Allah l'ó pa á láṣẹ láti gbẹ́ ilé Ọlọ́run fún ètò ìgbéyàwó sísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀.

English: Photo by Amanda Leigh Lichtenstein, used with permission.
Yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Amanda Leigh Lichtenstein, a fi àṣẹ lò ó.

English: On December 26, 2019, BBC Swahili released a video featuring Francisco Ouma, an elder from Busia, western Kenya, who received a message from God to carve a cave.
Yoruba: Lọ́jọ́ 26 oṣù Ọ̀pẹ, BBC Swahili gbé àwòrán-àtohùn kan tí ó ṣe àfihàn-an Francisco Ouma, ẹni àgbà kan láti Busia, ìlà-oòrùnun Kenya, ẹni tí ó gbọ́ ohùn Ọlọ́run láti gbẹ́ ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ jáde.

English: The message came in the form of a map that he received through his dreams.
Yoruba: Ìran náà wá nípasẹ̀ àwòrán ìtọ́nà tí ó rí lójú àwọn àláa rẹ̀.

English: Since February 1967, Ouma has followed the divine map delivered in his dream.
Yoruba: Láti inú oṣù kejì ọdún-un 1967, ni Ouma ti ń tọ ipasẹ̀ẹ ìtọ́nà látọ̀run wá náà tí ó gbà Iójú àláa rẹ̀.

English: Today, his cave has 24 rooms and counting.
Yoruba: Lónìí, ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ẹ rẹ̀ ti ní yàrá 24 tí ó sì ń lé sí i.

English: Screenshot of Francis Ouma, who received a message from God to carve a cave with 24 rooms via BBC Swahili / Instagram.
Yoruba: Àgékù àwòrán-an Francis Ouma, tí ó gbọ́ ohùn Ọlọ́run láti gbẹ́ ihò sísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ tí ó ní 24 ìyàrá lóríi BBC Swahili / Instagram.

English: Throughout history, many have questioned the veracity of divine intervention through dreams, even casting doubt on one's mental health and stability.
Yoruba: Láti ayébáyé, ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn ló ti ní kò sí ẹ̀rí tí ó dájú wípé ìran àt'ọ̀run wá ni àwọn irú àlá báwọ̀nyí, tí wọn ń dẹ́jàá ìlera ọpọlọ irú ẹni bẹ́ẹ̀ tí ó pé òún ríran lójú àlá.

English: But prophets from Islam, Judaism and Christianity have all testified to messages from God sent through dreams for millennia.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ àwọn òjíṣẹ́ ẹ̀sìn Ìmàle, Júù àti Onígbàgbọ́ gbogboó ti jẹ́rìí sí ìran láti ọ̀dọ̀ Ọlọ́run ent tí ó wá lójú àlá fún ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún ọdún.

English: "God brought me something like a map," Ouma told BBC Swahili.
Yoruba: "Ọlọ́run fi nǹkankan bí àwòrán-ìtọ́nà hàn mí," Ouma sọ fún BBC Swahili.

English: Then, when I was digging, this map is what I followed.
Yoruba: Nígbà yẹn, nígbà tí mò ń wa ilẹ̀, àwòrán-ìtọ́nà yìí ni mo tẹ̀lé.

English: It wasn't just that when I was digging, better to keep digging, no.
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe nígbà tí mò ń walẹ̀ nìkan, ó dára jù kí n máa walẹ̀ lọ, rárá.

English: Using just a plow and his own two hands, Ouma faced trial and error as he hit on stones that prevented him from digging.
Yoruba: Ìtúlẹ̀ àti ọwọ́ọ rẹ̀ méjèèjì ni ó lò, Ouma kan àwọn òkúta abẹ́lẹ̀ tí kò mú ìwalẹ̀ náà rọrùn fún un.

English: He finally found the right spot to manifest God's cave map in his mind.
Yoruba: Àṣẹ̀yìnwá àṣẹ̀yìnbọ ó rí ibi tí yóò ti mú àwòrán-ìtọ́nà ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ẹ Ọlọ́run tí ó wà ní ọkàn-an rẹ̀ wá sí ìmúṣẹ.

English: In one room, there's a stone with writing on it with the words of Jesus.
Yoruba: Nínú ìyẹ̀wù kan, ó ní òkúta kan tí a kọ ọ̀rọ̀ọ Jésù sí lára.

English: Jesus Christ was the one who brought me this news, Ouma said, and then he explained it to me as it was with Moses.
Yoruba: Jésù Kristì ni ẹni tí ó mú ìròyìn yìí wá fún mi, Ouma sọ, ó sì ṣàlàyée rẹ̀ fún mi gẹ́gẹ́ bí ó ti ṣe ṣe fún Mósè.

English: Ouma believes he is bringing back another covenant with God to the world.
Yoruba: Ouma gbàgbọ́ wípé òun ń mú májẹ̀mú mìíràn pẹ̀lú Ọlọ́run padà wá sílé ayé.

English: The second stage is coming.
Yoruba: Ìpele kejì ń bọ̀ lọ́nà.

English: This is the first stage of the covenant.
Yoruba: Èyí ni ìpele àkọ́kọ́ ti májẹ̀mú náà.

English: The second is coming.
Yoruba: Ìkejì ń bọ̀ lọ́nà.

English: I can't say for sure what it is now because if I announce it, I may be cheating humanity.
Yoruba: Mi ò leè sọ ní pàtó ohun tí yóò jẹ́ báyìí nítorí bí mo bá kédee rẹ̀, mo lè máa yan ìṣẹ̀dá ẹ̀dá ọmọ ènìyàn jẹ.

English: Therefore, I will wait for the report to be given at last, Ouma told BBC Swahili.
Yoruba: Toríi bẹ́ẹ̀, mo máa dúró fún ìjábọ̀ náà bí ó bá tó àsìkò, Ouma wí fún BBC Swahili.

English: The BBC Swahili video has been viewed nearly 50,000 times with over 100 comments and counting.
Yoruba: Àwòrán-àtohùn-un BBC Swahili ti di wíwò fún ìgbà 50,000 pẹ̀lú èsì tí ó tó 100 tí ó sì ń lé sí í.

English: While some have raised questions about the mental stability of those who claim to receive messages from God through dreams, including a professor quoted in the video, many comments supported people of faith who tune into messages shared through dreams.
Yoruba: Níwọ̀n-ọn bí àwọn kan ti sọ nípa àìlera ọpọlọ àwọn t'ó ń sọ pé àwọn gbọ́hùn Ọlọ́run lójú àlá, tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ èsì àdásí gbè lẹ́yìn àwọn ẹni Ọlọ́run tí ó sọ sí ìran ojú àlá.

English: One Instagram user wrote:
Yoruba: Òǹlòo Instagram kan kọ:

English: Translation Original Quote
Yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

English: For me, people like these, usually I believe them a lot, much more than those who fill us [up] from continuous contributions of words of hope from houses of worship, 52 years a person just digs - if he didn't have his mind, wouldn't his community or the government not recognize this?
Yoruba: Fún èmi, àwọn ènìyàn báyìí, mo máa ń gbà wọ́n gbọ́ gidi gan-an, ju àwọn tí ó máa ń fi ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́run [rọ] wá nílé ìjọsìn, fún ọdún 52 èèyàn-án wa ilẹ̀ - bí kò bá tẹ̀lé ọkàn-an rẹ̀, ṣé kò yẹ kí àdúgbòo rẹ̀ àti ìjọba ó dá a mọ̀?

English: He hasn't even asked for the help of a tractor or money for his labor. We should not judge this person.
Yoruba: Kò tilẹ̀ béèrè fún ìrànwọ́ fún katakata tàbí owó fún làálàáa rẹ̀. A kò gbọdọ̀ dájọ́ ẹni yìí.

English: Mohammed Yiso Banatah in 2012 explains the ten dreams through which Allah instructed him to dig underground wedding chapels.
Yoruba: Mohammed Yiso Banatah lọ́dún-un 2012 ṣàlàyé àlá mẹ́wàá tí Allah yọ sí òun lójú àlá láti gbẹ́ ilé Ọlọ́run fún ìgbéyàwó sábẹ́ ilẹ̀.

English: Photo courtesy of Amanda Leigh Lichtenstein.
Yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Amanda Leigh Lichtenstein.

English: Ethiopia's underground wedding chapels
Yoruba: Ilé Ọlọ́run fún ètò ìgbéyàwó Ethiopia

English: In southern Ethiopia, a similar testimony exists from an elder named Mohammed Yiso Banatah, who said back in 2012 that he was visited by Allah 33 years ago in a series of ten dreams.
Yoruba: Ní gúúsù Ethiopia, ẹ̀rí tí ó jọra á wá láti àgbàlagbà kan tí orúkọ rẹ̀ ń jẹ́ Mohammed Yiso Banatah, tí ó ní lọ́dún-un 2012 wípé Allah yọ sí òun ní ọdún 33 sẹ́yìn lójú àlá lẹ́ẹ̀mẹwàá ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀.

English: Through the dreams, he received explicit instructions from Allah to ultimately create underground wedding chapel caves.
Yoruba: Lójú àwọn àlá náà, ó gbọ́ ohùn-un Allah láti gbẹ́ ihò ilé Ọlọ́run fún ètò ìgbéyàwó nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀.

English: Known as Dunbar Caves, these elaborate chapels exist on Banatah's roadside property halfway between Hawassa and Shashamene.
Yoruba: Ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ẹ Dunbar ni a mọ̀ ọ́ sí, ilé Ọlọ́run fẹ̀nfẹ̀ wọ̀nyí wà ní ẹ̀bá ọ̀nàa Banatah tí í ṣe ìlàjì ọ̀nàa Hawassa àti Shashamene.

English: Banatah said it was in his third dream that the blueprint for these chapel caves was burned into his consciousness.
Yoruba: Banatah sọ wípé nínú àláa rẹ̀ kẹ́ta ni ó ti rí àwòṣe fún àwọn ilé Ọlọ́run wọ̀nyí.

English: You can read my full narrative account of Banatah's dream sequence and what prompted him to start digging what would become his life's work here:
Yoruba: O lè ka ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́ àkọsílẹ̀ àláa Banatah ní ṣísẹ̀-n-tẹ̀lé àti ohun tí ó gùn ún kí ó tó bẹ̀rẹ̀ iṣẹ́ ìwalẹ̀ ayée rẹ̀ níbí:

English: In his final dream, the tenth one in a series back in 1979, a man appeared in his dream who took Mohammed to a small tree on his property and pointed to its roots.
Yoruba: Lójú àláa àsèkágbáa rẹ̀, èyí tí ó jẹ́ ìkẹwàá nínú àkọsílẹ̀ oníṣísẹ̀ntẹ̀lé ọdún-un 1979, ọkùnrin kan fara hàn tí ó mú Mohammed lọ sí ibi igi kékeré kan nínúu ọgbàa rẹ̀, ó sì tọ́ka sí egbòo rẹ̀.

English: The man showed him exactly where to start digging and told him that his life would depend on it.
Yoruba: Ọkùnrin náà fi ojú ibi tí yóò ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ìwalẹ̀, ó sì tún sọ fún un pé lórí iṣẹ́ ìwalẹ̀ náà ni yóò ti là.

English: At midnight, he saw visions of gold.
Yoruba: Ní ọ̀gànjọ́, ó ríran rí wúrà.

English: Surroundings up close appeared far away and objects farthest away were pulled up close to him.
Yoruba: Agbègbè tí ó sún mọ́ jìnà, àwọn ohun tí ó jìnà di fífà sún mọ́ ọ.

English: He was told where, when, and how to begin digging.
Yoruba: A sọ ibi tí yóò ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ìwalẹ̀, ìgbà tí yó bẹ̀rẹ̀ àti bí yóò ṣe bẹ̀rẹ̀ .

English: The next day, when he woke up, he began to dig into the earth with his bare hands.
Yoruba: Lọ́jọ́ kejì, nígbà tí ó lajú sáyé, ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ síí gbẹ́lẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ọwọ́ọ rẹ̀ nìkan láì lo ìtúlẹ̀.

English: These sunlight-flooded caves have been somewhat of a tourist attraction where people stop, pay a modest fee, and tour the quiet stillness at least four meters underground.
Yoruba: Ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ tí ìmọ́lẹ̀ oòrùn tán sínúu rẹ̀ wọ̀nyí ti di ibi ìgbafẹ́ olówó kékeré fún àwọn èèyàn láti ṣe ìrinsẹ̀ máìlì mẹ́rin lábẹ́ ilẹ̀ tí ó pa lọ́lọ́.

English: Some couples have even arranged wedding ceremonies there.
Yoruba: Àwọn àfẹ́sọ́nà kan ti ṣe ètò ìgbéyàwó níbé.

English: The architectural genius of these spaces reveals the finery and steadiness of Mohammed's hand - he's spent careful hours carving, smoothing, cutting, digging, and designing an intricate series of archways, cosy nooks and hidden rooms within rooms, some that have been furnished with soft mattresses and simple earth-slab shelves, while others are stark and cool with tiny, rounded windows flooding through with secret rays of sunlight appearing out of nowhere.
Yoruba: Bí a ṣe kọ́ àwọn ìyẹ̀wù wọ̀nyí fi iṣẹ́ ọpọlọ àti itú ọwọ́ọ Mohammed hàn - ó ti fi ìfarabalẹ̀ lọ ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wákàtí fún gbígbẹ́, dídán, àti ṣíṣe iṣẹ́ ọnà sí gbogbo kọ́lọ́fín inú iyàrá àti ògiri, pẹ̀lú àwọn tìmùtìmù, àti pẹpẹ tí a fi iyẹ̀pẹ̀ mọ nínúu rẹ̀, tí àwọn yàrá mìíràn ní fèrèsé tí ìmọ́lẹ̀ oòrùn ń tàn gbà láti ibi tí ẹnìkan kò mọ̀.

English: Caves have carried deep spiritual and metaphorical significance throughout history.
Yoruba: Láti ayébáyé ni ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ ti jẹ́ ibi àpẹẹrẹ tí a kà sí gẹ́gẹ́ bí ibi ti ẹ̀mí.

English: A whole chapter called "Al Kahf" or "The Cave" appears in the Quran.
Yoruba: Odindin ìwé kan gbáko tí a pè ní "Al Kahf" tàbí "Ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ " jẹyọ nínúu ìwé mímọ́ọ Kuran.

English: It features a Christian folktale known as the "People of the Cave," in which youth, tortured for their beliefs, fled their city to find refuge in a cave and fell asleep.
Yoruba: Nínúu rẹ̀ ni a ti bá ìtàn Ẹ̀sìn ìgbàgbọ́ kan tí a mọ̀ sí "Àwọn ẹni Ihò-òkúta," which nínú èyí tí àwọn ọ̀dọ́, jìyà àìṣẹ̀ nítorí ìgbàgbọ́ọ wọ́n sá kúrò nílùú, wọ́n sì wá ibi ihò-òkúta kan sùn sí.

English: When they awoke and returned, they realized the entire city had become believers.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí wọ́n jí, wọ́n padà sílé, wọ́n sì ṣàkíyèsí wípé gbogbo ọmọ ìlú ti di ònígbàgbọ́.

English: Why is Donald Trump so popular in Nigeria?
Yoruba: Kíni ìdí irẹ̀ tí Donald Trump ṣe l'ókìkí ní Nàìjíríà?

English: Trump has so many fans in southern Nigeria
Yoruba: Trump ní ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ olólùfẹ́ ní gúúsù orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà

English: President Donald Trump returns to the White House in Washington on August 19, 2018.
Yoruba: Ààrẹ Donald Trump padà sí Ilé Agbára Funfun ní Washington lọ́jọ́ 19 oṣù Ògún, ọdún-un 2018.

English: Image by Samira Bouaou/The Epoch Times, CC BY 2.0.
Yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Samira Bouaou/The Epoch Times, CC BY 2.0.

English: United States President Donald Trump has received low ratings across the world for his handling of international affairs - but not in some African countries like Nigeria.
Yoruba: Ààrẹ orílẹ̀-èdèe Amẹ́ríkà Donald Trump ti ré sí ipò ìsàlẹ̀ lójú àwọn ènìyàn kárí ayé látàrí àwọn òfin rẹ̀ àti bí ó ṣe ń ṣe ìṣàkóso ọ̀ràn tí ó jẹ mọ́ orílẹ̀-èdèe òkèèrè - àmọ́ kò rí bẹ́ẹ̀ ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè bíi Nàìjíríà.

English: According to a recent survey by the Pew Research Centre most Nigerians "have confidence" that Trump "will do the right thing in world affairs."
Yoruba: Ní kò pẹ́ kò pẹ́ yìí ni ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò tí Pew Research Centre ṣagbátẹrùu rẹ̀ fi hàn wípé ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ ọmọ Nàìjíríà "fi Ògún-un rẹ̀ gbárí" wípé Trump "yóò gbé ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó lààmìlaka nípa ti ọ̀ràn àgbáyé."

English: The Pew survey results were gathered from telephone and face-to-face interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup - a Washington, DC, based analytics and advisory company.
Yoruba: Orí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ àti ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò ojúkorojú ni Gallup - iléeṣẹ́ aṣàgbéyẹ̀wò fínnífínní àti iléeṣẹ́ olùdámọ̀ràn tí ó wà ní Washington, DC fi gba èsì jọ nínú ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò èrò àwọn ènìyàn-an fún Pew.

English: Tweepsmap analysis of on Trump's total followers on Twitter shows that Nigerians ranked in the top five across the world:
Yoruba: Àgbéyẹ̀wò Tweepsmap kan tí ó dá lóríi iye àwọn tí ó ń tẹ̀lé Trump lóríi ẹ̀rọ alátagbà Twitter ṣe òfófó wípé ipò karùn-ún ni Nàìjíríà dúró sí nínú àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè márùn-ún lágbàáyé:

English: Nigerian writer Adaobi Tricia Nwaubani explained to The World, a public radio show co-produced by the BBC, that Trump's "tough guy image" strikes a chord in Africa's most populous country:
Yoruba: Òǹkọ̀wé tí í ṣe ọmọ bíbí orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà Adaobi Tricia Nwaubani làdíi rẹ̀ fún àgbáyé lórí ètò ẹ̀rọ agbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ kan tí ó jẹ́ àbáṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú BBC, wípé ìrísíi Trump gẹ́gẹ́ bí "ọkùnrin alágídí" mú kí àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó kún fún ènìyàn jù lọ ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ó fẹ́ràn-an rẹ̀ dé góńgó:

English: People admire his tough guy image and his bluntness is entertaining.
Yoruba: Àwọn ènìyàn fẹ́ràn-an ìhùwàsí alágídíi rẹ̀ àti pé àìfọ̀rọ̀ sábẹ́ ahọ́n-ọn rẹ̀ dùn ún gbọ́ sétí.

English: He's weird to Americans.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ Amẹ́ríkà rí i bí àkàndá ènìyàn.

English: He's strange.
Yoruba: Ìhùwàsíi rẹ̀ kò bá tayé mu.

English: He's different from what you've had.
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe ẹni tí wọ́n sọ pé ó jẹ́.

English: But we're used to leaders who speak without restraint, who are verbally abusive when they please.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ irú olórí tí kì í lọ́ra sọ̀rọ̀ bí ó ti wù ú kò jẹ́ tuntun sí wa.

English: And so, he's not as outlandish to us as he may appear to an American.
Yoruba: Torí ìdí èyí, ìhùwàsíi rẹ̀ kò bàjẹ́ tó bẹ́ẹ̀ bí àwọn ọmọ Amẹ́ríkà ṣe ń rí i.

English: The other reason is religion.
Yoruba: Ìdí mìíràn ni ẹ̀sìn.

English: Nigerian Christians love Trump.
Yoruba: Àwọn Ọmọ lẹ́yìn-in Krístì nífẹ̀ẹ́ẹ Trump

English: Cheta Nwanze, Head of Research at SBM Intelligence told Global Voices:
Yoruba: Cheta Nwanze, Olórí Ìwádìí ní SBM Intelligence sọ fún Ohùn Àgbáyé:

English: I'd like to see exactly WHERE in Nigeria this survey was conducted.
Yoruba: Ó hùn mí láti mọ IBI tí wọ́n ti ṣe ìwádìí-àyẹ̀wò yìí ní Nàìjíríà.

English: I'm willing to bet that it was largely in southern Nigeria, which explains the love of Trump.
Yoruba: Mo mọ̀ dájú wípé kì í ṣe káríi gúúsù orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, tí ó ṣàlàyé ìfẹ́ tí ọmọ Nàìjíríà ní sí Trump.

English: A lot of his base are evangelical Christians, from whom many Nigerians draw their inspiration.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ nínú àwọn olólùfẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ l'ó jẹ́ Onígbàgbọ́, tí wọ́n ń gbójú sókè wò ó bí àwòkọ́ṣe rere.

English: Nigeria, with an estimated population of 200 million people, has two major religions: Christianity and Islam.
Yoruba: Nàìjíríà, pẹ̀lú iye ènìyàn ìlú tí ó tó ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 200 èèyàn, ní ẹ̀sìn méjì tí àwọn ènìyàn-án ń ṣe jù: ẹ̀sìn Ìgbàgbọ́ àti Ìmàle.

English: Muslims and Christians make up 50 percent and 48 percent of the Nigerian population respectively.
Yoruba: Ìmàle àti Ìgbàgbọ́ kó ìdá 50 àti ìdá 48 iye gbogbo ènìyàn t'ó ń gbé Nàìjíríà.

English: The methodology of the recent poll states that the study was conducted in Nigerian "local government areas stratified by geopolitical region."
Yoruba: Ìlànà ìwádìí náà fi hàn wípé "iléeṣẹ́ ìjọba Ìpínlẹ̀ tí wọ́n sì pín àwọn ènìyàn sí agbègbè" ni wọ́n ti ṣe ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò yìí.

English: However, Adamawa, Borno, and Yobe states in northwestern Nigeria were excluded from the study due to security concerns.
Yoruba: Bí ó ti wù kíó rí, kò sí ohùn àwọn Adamawa, Borno, àti ìpínlẹ̀ Yobe ní àríwá ìlà-oòrùn Nàìjíríà nínú àbájáde ìwádìí náà nítorí ọ̀rọ̀ ààbò.

English: Nigeria has 774 local government areas, the grassroots arm of executive governance structure in the country.
Yoruba: Nàìjíríà ní ìjọba ìbílẹ̀ 774, tí í ṣe ẹ̀ka aláṣẹ ìjọba ìbílẹ̀. Bákan náà ni ó ní ẹ̀ka àkóso mẹ́fàá.

English: There are also six geopolitical regions: North Central, Northwest, Northeast, South-south, Southeast, and Southwest.
Yoruba: Àárín gbùngbùn Àríwá, Àríwá Ìlà-oòrùn, Àríwá Ìwọ̀-oòrùn, Àjìǹdò-gúúsù, Ìwọ̀-oòrùn gúúsù, àti Ìlà-oòrùnun gúúsù.

English: Nwanze's position that Christians in southern Nigeria must have formed the core of the sample size for the Pew Research results are not unfounded.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ọ Nwanze pé àwọn Onígbàgbọ́ ní gúúsù Nàìjíríà ló pọ̀ jù lọ nínú ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò Pew Research kò ṣe é má gbàgbọ́.

English: The survey also showed that Nigerian Christians also "have a more favorable opinion of the US (69 percent) than do Muslims (54 percent)."
Yoruba: Ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò náà tún fi hàn pé ọ̀pọ̀ ọmọ lẹ́yìn Krístì ní Nàìjíríà "rí orílẹ̀-èdèe US bí ìlú tí ó dára (ìdá 69) ju bí àwọn Ìmàlé ṣe rí i lọ (ìdá 54)."

English: After the killing of top Iranian General Qasem Soleimani, by the United States, Nigeria's police chief issued a national security alert to forestall any disturbances by "domestic interests."
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn tí orílẹ̀-èdèe Amẹ́ríkà pa Ọ̀gágun ọmọ Iran Qasem Soleimani, ọ̀gá ọlọ́pàá tẹ ìkéde ìṣọ́ra ẹni jákèjádò orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà jáde kí ó ba ti ilẹ̀kùn "ogun."

English: The Islamic movement in Nigeria described the US airstrike that killed Soleimani as a "declaration of war on Iran."
Yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ Ẹ̀sìn Ìmàle ní Nàìjíríà ṣàpèjúwe ikú oró òjò ọta ìbọn láti òkè wá tí US fi pa Soleimani gẹ́gẹ́ bí "ìpè ogun sí Ìran."

English: Trump has been described as "one of the most controversial world leaders in modern times."
Yoruba: A ti ṣe àpèjúwe Trump gẹ́gẹ́ bí "ọ̀kan lára àwọn olórí àgbáyé sáà tí a wà yìí tí ó ní ọkàn líle."

English: Yet, he is clearly adored by many in Nigeria.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀, ọ̀pọ̀ ọmọ Nàìjíríà ló fẹ́ràn-an Trump.

English: Twitter was a minefield of false information during the 2019 Nigerian elections
Yoruba: Twitter di pápá ìròyìn ayédèrú lásìkò Ìdìbò ọdún-un 2019 ní Nàìjíríà

English: Ethnic hate speech and disinformation were rife on Twitter
